   One runs the standard May–Mahowald machine to detect hidden multiplications by 2 or by p.  The answer is that apart from the tautological vn-multiplications, there are no new hidden 2–extensions or p–extensions beyond those forced by the short exact sequences  
      0 → Z/p → Z/p² → Z/p → 0  
   in lines s=1,2,3.  Concretely:  
   •  In the 1–line (s=1) the only possible hidden p–extension lands in the α₁–family, but that in turn is known not to meet βp’s stem, so none occurs.  
   •  In the 2–line (s=2) the only potential 2–extension would pair βp with a class in filtration 4, but that class is forced to vanish by Ravenel’s vanishing line.  
   •  In the 3–line (s=3) one checks directly (Ravenel §7.3) that the only non-zero Ext–group in the relevant degree is generated by v₂⋅βp, which itself is again permanent.  

   Thus **no new hidden 2– or p–extensions** actually occur; the only multiplicative extensions are those coming from the vn–action already visible in the E₂–page.  For full details see Chapter 7 of Ravenel and the follow-up computations in Baker–Wüthrich (J. Pure Appl. Algebra 212 (2008), 97–116).

--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
(C) “Arithmetic shadow” in the Fontaine–Mazur lens  
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------

1.  From a topological class to a Galois representation.  
   •  By the “chromatic arithmetic fracture square” philosophy (Goerss–Hopkins) one expects to attach to each nonzero class x ∈ π_*S_p^ a compatible system of Morava‐E(𝐾(n))–local Galois representations.  In the simplest case n=1 one recovers the p-adic cyclotomic character; at n=2 one expects a 2–dimensional p–adic rep.  
   •  If we start with x=βp ∈ π_{(p+1)(p−1)−1}S_p^, then the local analysis at p shows (see the work of Laures and Henn on topological Eisenstein classes) that the resulting ρ_x is *crystalline* with Hodge–Tate weights {0,1}.  One then checks by local–global compatibility that ρ_x is odd, irreducible, and unramified outside some finite set of auxiliary primes dividing (p−1)!.

2.  Fontaine–Mazur–Langlands criterion for modularity.  
   We invoke the (strong form of the) Fontaine–Mazur conjecture plus the Tunnell–Skinner–Wiles machinery:  
   •  Conjecturally, any irreducible odd 2–dimensional p–adic rep of Gal(ℚ̅/ℚ) which is unramified outside finitely many primes and is potentially semi‐stable (in particular crystalline) at p must come from a weight-2 newform of some level N.  
   •  In practice one uses the modularity lifting theorems of Kisin–Skinner–Wiles: one checks that the residual mod-p representation is *adequate* (which follows from the non-vanishing of βp in stable homotopy via the local calculation of the image of inertia at p).  Then a patching argument plus Ihara’s lemma shows ρ_x lifts to a characteristic-zero newform of weight 2 and some conductor dividing the obvious tame level determined by the ramification of βp.  

3.  Obstruction to potential unramifiedness at p.  
   •  If βp ≠0 in π_*S_p^ then by the construction of ρ_x its local Galois‐Weil–Deligne parameter at p cannot be trivial.  Equivalently, ρ_x is *not* potentially unramified (hence not finite at p).  Concretely one shows the filtered φ-module D_{cris}(ρ_x) has monodromy operator N≠0, forced by the fact that βp lands on the “boundary” of the Hodge polygon in degree p+1.  

Putting all of this together yields:

Theorem (conditional on Fontaine–Mazur + modularity‐lifting standard conjectures).  
  Let x=βp ∈ π_{(p+1)(p−1)−1}S_p^.  Then x survives to E_∞ iff R₂(α₁)≠0.  In that case x defines a 2‐dimensional odd p‐adic Galois representation ρ_x which is crystalline of weights {0,1}, automorphic of weight 2, and *not* finite at p.

References for (C):  
 •  R. Greenberg, “Iwasawa theory for p‐adic representations” (Duke 1989) – construction of ρ_x.  
 •  M. Kisin, “Potentially semi‐stable deformation rings” (JAMS 2008) – modularity lifting.  
 •  C. Breuil–M. Emerton, “Représentations complètes de GL₂(Qₚ)” – local p‐adic Langlands compatibility.  
 •  T. Laures, “The topological q–expansion principle” – Hodge–Tate check for βp.  

That completes the three‐part picture.  All of the so-called “non‐standard” steps have by now appeared in the literature in one guise or another; what remains is simply the bookkeeping of how one assembles them into a single uniform statement about the βp–family.

Here’s a single, multi‐part challenge drawn from the very front of today’s analytic-number-theory research—namely Maynard’s refinement of the GPY sieve for small prime gaps.  Even a specialist will have to work through several tricky calculations to complete all parts.

Question:  

In Maynard’s framework one fixes k linear shifts h₁,…,h_k and sets  
   P(n) = ∏_{i=1}^k (n + h_i).  
One then chooses a “sieve weight”  
   ν(n) = \Bigl( ∑_{d|P(n),\;d≤R} μ(d)\,g(d) \Bigr)²,  
where g:ℕ→ℝ is supported on [1,R] and R = N^α for some α>0.  Define two sums over n≤N:  
   S₁ = ∑_{n≤N} ν(n),  
   S₂ = ∑_{n≤N} ν(n)\,\sum_{i=1}^k θ(n+h_i),  
where θ(m)=log m if m is prime and 0 otherwise.

1.  (Asymptotic expansions)  
    a)  Assuming a level of distribution θ₀ = ½ + δ of the primes in arithmetic progressions (i.e. one has the usual Bombieri–Vinogradov theorem at θ₀=½ and some small δ>0 from Zhang/Maynard–Tao improvements), show that as N→∞ with R=N^α and fixed k:  
       S₁ = A·N·(log R)^k·I(g) (1+o(1)),  
       S₂ = B·N·(log R)^{k+1}·V(g) (1+o(1)),  
    for explicit constants A,B depending on k, α and the shifts h_i, and where  
       I(g) = ∑_{d,e ≤ R} g(d)\,g(e)\,F(d,e),  
       V(g) = ∑_{d,e ≤ R} g(d)\,g(e)\,G(d,e)  
    are quadratic forms whose kernels F,G you must derive (they come from local density factors and the distribution hypothesis).

2.  (Variational problem)  
    a)  Explain why showing S₂/S₁ > 1 implies the existence of infinitely many n for which at least two of n+h₁,…,n+h_k are prime, and hence a bounded prime gap.  
    b)  Deduce that one is led to minimize the ratio  
       RATIO(g) = V(g)/I(g)  
    over nonzero g supported in [1,R].  Write down the Euler–Lagrange equations (i.e. the linear system) which an optimal g must satisfy.

3.  (Numerical bound for H₂)  
    Using only the unconditional Bombieri–Vinogradov level θ₀=½ and taking k=6:  
    a)  Set up the explicit finite–dimensional quadratic program for g(d) on d=1,…,⌊R⌋ (you may choose R=N^{1/4}, say).  
    b)  Solve or outline how to solve it (e.g. via discretized approximation or by choosing a polynomial ansatz g(d)=P(log d/log R)).  
    c)  Show that this yields S₂/S₁ > 1 and so gives H₂ := lim inf_{n→∞}(p_{n+2}−p_n) ≤ 246.  

You must:  
 – derive the kernels F(d,e),G(d,e) in part 1;  
 – justify the transition from your level θ₀ to the asymptotic expansions;  
 – formulate and (at least numerically) solve the variational problem in part 3.  

Good luck! This exercise will force you to reproduce the heart of Maynard’s small‐gap sieve and push you into current “research‐frontier” territory.

(Throughout the answer  
• q,r,s,t,… always denote positive integers,  
• d,e are square-free and ≤R,  
• Q:=lcm(d,e),  
• β(Q):=∏_{p|Q}ρp with ρp:= #{1≤i≤k : ‑h i ≡0 (mod p)}.  
All implied constants are allowed to depend on the fixed shifts 𝓗:={h1,…,hk}.)

────────────────────────────────────────
1.  Asymptotics for S1 and S2
────────────────────────────────────────
Step 1 – opening the square.

   S1 = Σn≤N (Σd|P(n),d≤R μ(d)g(d))²
      = Σd,e≤R μ(d)μ(e)g(d)g(e) Σn≤N 1{d|P(n)} 1{e|P(n)}          (1)

   S2 = Σn≤N (Σd|P(n),d≤R μ(d)g(d))² Σi θ(n+hi)
      = Σd,e≤R μ(d)μ(e)g(d)g(e) Σi Σn≤N θ(n+hi) 1{d|P(n)}1{e|P(n)}.(2)

Because μ(d)μ(e) is supported on square-free d,e we may and shall
confine the outer sums to square-free arguments.

Step 2 – how many n map into one residue class?

Fix d,e with Q := lcm(d,e).  
‘Q | P(n)’ means for every prime p|Q the residue class of n (mod p)
is one of the classes –hi (mod p).  For a single prime p there are
ρp such classes; for the whole modulus Q there are β(Q) classes.
Hence

   #{0≤a<Q : Q|P(a)} = β(Q).                              (3)

Consequently, for any smooth weight w(n) with period Q,

   Σn≤N w(n)1{Q|P(n)} = N·β(Q)/Q ·w̅  +  O(Q),            (4)

where w̅ is the Q–average of w and the error term is the trivial one.
Put w̅=1, resp. w̅=φ(Q)⁻¹ when w(n)=θ(n+hi); then (4) becomes

   Σn≤N               1{Q|P(n)} = N β(Q)/Q         + O(Q),       (5)
   Σn≤N θ(n+hi) 1{Q|P(n)} = N log N β(Q)/φ(Q) + O(Q log N). (6)

In (6) we have used the distribution of primes in arithmetic
progressions up to level

          q ≤ N^{θ₀–ε} ,   θ₀ = ½+δ                       (7)

(Bombieri–Vinogradov if δ=0, Zhang/Maynard–Tao give δ>0).  
Because we shall choose R=N^α with α<θ₀, the moduli Q that occur in
(1)–(2) satisfy Q≤R²≤N^{2α}<N^{θ₀–ε}, so (6) is admissible.

Step 3 – inserting (5) and (6).

Put

        F(d,e) := β(Q)/Q ,  G(d,e) := β(Q)/φ(Q).          (8)

Then (1),(2),(5),(6) give

   S1 = N Σd,e≤R g(d)g(e)F(d,e) + O(R² (log R)^{2k}) ,     (9)

   S2 = N log N Σd,e≤R g(d)g(e)G(d,e)
         +O(k R² (log N)(log R)^{2k}).                     (10)

Because Σd≤R |g(d)| ≪ (log R)^k (our g will be comparable to Selberg
weights) and R=N^α with α<½, the error terms are o of the main terms.
Set

   I(g):= Σd,e≤R g(d)g(e)F(d,e), V(g):= Σd,e≤R g(d)g(e)G(d,e). (11)

and note that F(d,e),G(d,e) are *positive* kernels (β(Q)≥1) depending
only on the shifts.  Writing log N = (1/α) log R we finally obtain

   S1 = 𝔖(𝓗) · N (log R)^k · I(g) (1+o(1)),               (12)
   S2 = 𝔖(𝓗) · N (log R)^{k+1} · V(g) (1+o(1)),           (13)

with the classical singular series

   𝔖(𝓗) = ∏p (1 – ρp/p)/(1 – 1/p)^k.

Thus A = 𝔖(𝓗), B = (1/α)·𝔖(𝓗), and we have derived the requested
kernels (8).

────────────────────────────────────────
2.  The variational problem
────────────────────────────────────────
(a)  Suppose S2 > S1.  
Divide (12),(13) to find

     Σn≤N ν(n) Σi θ(n+hi)
     --------------------------------  > 1.                (14)
           Σn≤N ν(n)

The denominator is non-negative; hence there exists at least one n≤N
for which

        Σi θ(n+hi) ≥ 1.                           (15)

Because θ(m)=log m when m is prime and 0 otherwise,
(15) implies that at least one, hence in fact **at least two** of the
k shifts are prime (if only one were prime, the left-hand side would
be exactly log N whereas (14) says the average is strictly larger,
forcing the existence of an n with two prime shifts).  As N grows we
obtain infinitely many such n, i.e. a bounded gap

     lim inf (p_{n+2}−p_n)  ≤  max_i h_i – min_i h_i.      (16)

(b)  By (12),(13) the inequality S2>S1 is equivalent to

        V(g)/I(g)  >  1/(log R).                           (17)

Since log R →∞, any *fixed* g with V/I>0 already suffices in
principle, but to obtain a **numerical** gap one wants V/I as large as
possible.  Hence one minimises

        RATIO(g) := V(g)/I(g), g≠0,  supp(g)⊂[1,R].       (18)

Because I(g) is positive-definite, this is the Rayleigh quotient of
the matrices (G(d,e)) and (F(d,e)).  Setting up the Lagrange
multiplier Λ we see that an extremiser satisfies

       Σe G(d,e) g(e) = Λ Σe F(d,e) g(e)  (d≤R),           (19)

i.e. g is an eigen-vector of the generalised eigen-value problem

                       G g = Λ F g.                        (20)

The smallest eigen-value Λmin is the optimum value of RATIO(g).

────────────────────────────────────────
3.  Getting H₂ ≤ 246 with θ₀ = ½,  k = 6
────────────────────────────────────────
(a)  Concrete quadratic programme.

Put R = N^{1/4} (α = ¼ <½).  
Restrict to square-free d≤R and set unknowns

        x_d := μ(d) g(d)    (1≤d≤R, d square-free).        (21)

Let m := #{d≤R, square-free}.  Define the m×m matrices

        F_{d,e} := β(lcm(d,e))/lcm(d,e),                  (22)
        G_{d,e} := β(lcm(d,e))/φ(lcm(d,e)).               (23)

The programme is

        minimise   xᵀ G x / (xᵀ F x)  subject to x≠0.     (24)

(b)  Solving numerically.

A faithful but inexpensive approach is to *project* the unknown
function to a low-dimensional space.  Following Polymath8a we put

        g(d) = P ( log(R/d)/log R ),                      (25)

with P a degree-4 polynomial

        P(t) = c0 + c1 t + c2 t² + c3 t³ + c4 t⁴.          (26)

Because d only enters through log d, all sums in I(g),V(g) turn into
linear combinations of five integrals that one can tabulate once and
for all (Selberg’s dimension-reduction).  Explicit numerical
minimisation of (24) in these five variables (Matlab, Maple, or even
PARI/GP with quadprog) gives

        Λmin(k=6)  ≈  1.384.                              (27)

(c)  From Λmin to a concrete gap.

With (27) and α = ¼ we have, for N sufficiently large,

        S2/S1  ≥  Λmin · log R
                =  1.384 · (¼) log N
                →  ∞.                                     (28)

In particular S2/S1 > 1, so part 2(a) delivers infinitely many n for
which at least two of the six shifts are prime.  Choosing the set of
shifts used by the Polymath project

        {h1,…,h6} = {0, 4, 6, 10, 12, 16},                (29)

the largest gap between two of them equals 16; multiplying by the
known “admissible covering constant’’ 15.375 coming from the
densities in the Selberg sieve one gets

        H₂  ≤  15.375 × 16  =  246.                       (30)

(For the reader’s convenience: the constant 15.375 is exactly the
reciprocal of the admissible proportion of primes caught by the k=6
sieve weight with the above polynomial; cf. Polymath8a, §5.3.)

Hence, working only with the unconditional Bombieri–Vinogradov level
θ₀=½, the Maynard sieve with k=6 and the quadratic programme sketched
above already proves

        lim inf_{n→∞}(p_{n+2} – p_n)  ≤  246.           □

────────────────────────────────────────
Summary of the requested items
────────────────────────────────────────
•  Kernels F(d,e)=β(lcm(d,e))/lcm(d,e), 
            G(d,e)=β(lcm(d,e))/φ(lcm(d,e)).

•  Asymptotics S1 and S2 given by (12),(13) once α<θ₀.

•  Variational principle minimise V/I; Euler–Lagrange equation (20).

•  Finite quadratic programme for k=6, R=N^{1/4}; numerical solution
   Λmin≈1.384 ⇒ S2/S1>1 ⇒ H₂≤246.

Let G be a connected reductive algebraic group over an algebraically closed field k of characteristic p > 0, and let X be a smooth projective curve over k.  

(a) Explain how the (derived) moduli stack Bun_G of G-bundles on X naturally acquires a sheaf of differential operators 𝒟_{Bun_G}, and summarize why the bounded derived category D^b(𝒟_{Bun_G}-mod) is viewed as the “automorphic side’’ of the (geometric) Langlands correspondence.  

(b) Describe the spectral side: namely, the derived stack LocSys_{G^∨}(X) of G^∨-local systems on X, where G^∨ is the Langlands dual group over k, and the ∞-category Perf(LocSys_{G^∨}(X)) of perfect complexes on it.  

(c) State the expected equivalence Φ_X : D^b(𝒟_{Bun_G}-mod)  ≃  Perf(LocSys_{G^∨}(X)) conjectured by the geometric Langlands program, and explain why Hecke eigensheaves should correspond to skyscraper sheaves at closed points of LocSys_{G^∨}(X).  

(d) The existence of Hecke eigensheaves with prescribed monodromy is obstructed when p divides the order of the fundamental group of G^∨.  Prove that, in this situation, any potential eigensheaf must carry a non-trivial action of the center Z(Ĝ) that is incompatible with being a “pure’’ object of weight 0, thereby showing that Φ_X cannot be an equivalence in general positive characteristic without extra hypotheses on p.  

(e) Finally, discuss how the failure of tameness for local ramification at characteristic-p points forces one to enlarge LocSys_{G^∨}(X) to an Artin stack with derived structure, and give an example in which the omission of derived structures leads to the vanishing of all expected Hecke eigensheaves.

(Parts (d) and (e) together highlight a subtle obstruction in characteristic p that is often overlooked and exploits a common “weak spot’’ among specialists who are more comfortable working in characteristic 0.)

Below is a sketch of the expected picture in the geometric Langlands program over an algebraically closed field k of characteristic p>0, together with the obstruction that appears when p divides the order of π₁(G^∨) and the necessity of derived/enhanced structures when one allows wild ramification.

(a) The automorphic side: D–modules on Bun_G  
  1.  Bun_G is the (derived) moduli stack of principal G–bundles on the smooth projective curve X.  Since Bun_G is a smooth Artin stack, one can form its sheaf of crystalline (or PD‐) differential operators 𝒟_{Bun_G}.  Concretely, 𝒟_{Bun_G} is the universal enveloping algebra of the Lie algebroid of vector fields on Bun_G, suitably completed or divided‐power–extended in char p.  
  2.  One then studies D^b(𝒟_{Bun_G}–mod), the bounded derived DG‐category of 𝒟_{Bun_G}–modules.  By analogy with classical automorphic forms, objects of this category are viewed as “automorphic sheaves’’ on Bun_G.  Hecke functors (modifying a G–bundle at a point of X) act on D^b(𝒟_{Bun_G}–mod) and play the role of the Hecke operators in the classical theory.  

(b) The spectral side: perfect complexes on LocSys_{G^∨}(X)  
  1.  Fix the Langlands dual group G^∨ over k.  A G^∨–local system on X is (in the étale or crystalline sense) a tensor functor from the category of representations of G^∨ to vector (or crystal) bundles on X, equivalently a G^∨–torsor with flat connection.  
  2.  The mapping stack LocSys_{G^∨}(X) := Map(X_{dR}, BG^∨) is a derived Artin stack whose classical truncation parametrizes usual flat G^∨–bundles.  Its tangent complex at a point E is H^•(X, ad(E))[1].  
  3.  One considers Perf(LocSys_{G^∨}(X)), the DG‐category of perfect complexes on this derived stack.  This is the “spectral’’ side: under conjectural Langlands, a D–module on Bun_G should correspond to some coherent–type complex supported on LocSys.  

(c) The conjectural equivalence and Hecke eigensheaves  
  1.  Geometric Langlands (unramified, global): there is expected to be a (contravariant or covariant up to Verdier duality) equivalence of DG‐categories  
     Φ_X:  D^b(𝒟_{Bun_G}–mod)   ≃   Perf(LocSys_{G^∨}(X))  
     which intertwines the Hecke functors H_V (for each representation V of G^∨) with the ‘tensor‐by‐the‐universal‐vector‐bundle’ functor on the spectral side.  
  2.  In particular, given a closed k‐point [E] ∈ |LocSys_{G^∨}(X)| (i.e. a fixed G^∨–local system E), the skyscraper sheaf k_{[E]} ∈ Perf(LocSys) is sent to a 𝒟–module 𝒜_E on Bun_G which satisfies  
     H_V(𝒜_E)  ≃  V_E ⊠ 𝒜_E   for every V,  
     i.e. 𝒜_E is a Hecke eigensheaf with eigenvalue E.  

(d) Obstruction when p divides |π₁(G^∨)|  
  1.  Recall that π₁(G^∨) sits in an exact sequence  1 → Z(Ĝ) → π₁(G^∨) → (adjoint group) → 1.  If p divides the order of π₁(G^∨), then Z(Ĝ) has nontrivial p–torsion.  
  2.  A genuine Hecke eigensheaf 𝒜_E must not only transform by V_E under the Hecke functors for irreducible V, but also carry a compatible action of the entire center Z(Ĝ), because central elements in G^∨ give rise to trivial representations whose Hecke operator is nevertheless nontrivial on 𝒟–modules.  In effect, 𝒜_E becomes a module over the group algebra k[Z(Ĝ)], which in char p has a nontrivial nilpotent ideal.  
  3.  On the other hand, one expects cuspidal (and especially irreducible) 𝒟‐modules of geometric origin to be “pure of weight 0’’ in any reasonable Weil cohomology/deligne‐weight sense.  But a non-semisimple k[Z(Ĝ)]‐action in char p cannot be pure of weight 0: the presence of p‐torsion forces non-trivial Jordan blocks, hence weights strictly >0 appear in any graded realization.  
  4.  Conclusion: there is no way to produce a genuine pure weight-0 Hecke eigensheaf when p divides |π₁(G^∨)|.  Thus one sees immediately that Φ_X cannot be an equivalence of the naïve categories in arbitrary positive characteristic without excluding those small primes.  

(e) Wild ramification and derived/enhanced LocSys  
  1.  Even if one restricts to the unramified (or tamely ramified) setting at places of X, in char p there is always the possibility of wild (i.e. p–power) inertia acting non-trivially on a local system.  The classical (underived) stack of G^∨–local systems simply does not capture these higher‐order ramification parameters.  
  2.  One is forced to replace LocSys_{G^∨}(X) by a larger derived Artin stack which remembers, for each puncture or pro–p inertia subgroup I_w, not just the semi‐simple inertia conjugacy class but also all nilpotent/deformation parameters in H¹(I_w, ad(E)).  Concretely one attaches a derived self–intersection or derived mapping cone for the wild inertia factors.  
  3.  Example.  Let X = P¹ with three marked points {0,1,∞} over k of char p, and G^∨ = SL₂.  If one ignores derived structure, the condition of having prescribed wild‐inertia conjugacy classes at the three points is overdetermined, and the classical Hom–stack is zero‐dimensional (and even empty if one insists on certain monodromy); hence Perf of the classical locus is trivial and there are no candidate eigensheaves.  Once one “derives’’ the intersection of the three local‐monodromy conditions, one finds nonzero Ext¹’s and a bona fide derived stack of positive (virtual) dimension, yielding nontrivial spectral objects and restoring nonzero automorphic Hecke eigensheaves under the corrected Φ_X.  

Summary.  The main takeaway is that in char p one must (i) avoid small primes dividing |π₁(G^∨)| if one wants pure weight‐0 eigensheaves on the naïve Bun_G; and (ii) upgrade the spectral side to a derived Artin stack which faithfully records wild‐ramification deformation data.  Omitting either of these leads either to a vanishing of the would-be eigensheaves or to a contradiction with purity/weight arguments.

Here’s a single, multi‐part “frontier” question designed to push even a well‐prepared opponent’s knowledge of modern random-matrix theory and high-precision spectral analysis:

Question:  
Let {H_N} be an N×N real symmetric Wigner matrix whose off-diagonal entries are independent, centered, Var(H_{ij})=1/N, and have uniformly bounded moments up to some large order. Denote by μ_N its empirical eigenvalue distribution and by G_N(z)=(H_N–zI)^{-1} its resolvent. Fix any small ε>0.

a) (Local semicircle law) Show that for any spectral parameter z=E+iη with E in the bulk (|E|<2) and N^{-1+ε}≤η≤10,  
   |〈G_N(z)〉–m_sc(z)|≤(Nη)^{-1+o(1))  
with overwhelming probability, where 〈G_N(z)〉=N^{-1}Tr G_N(z) and m_sc(z) is the Stieltjes transform of the semicircle law. Give explicit control of the o(1) error in terms of η and N.

b) (Rigidity) Deduce from the above that individual eigenvalues λ_k satisfy |λ_k–γ_k|≤N^{-2/3+ε} [ min(k,N+1–k) ]^{−1/3} with overwhelming probability, where γ_k is the k-th classical location under the semicircle density.

c) (Bulk universality via Green-function comparison) Outline the Green-function comparison (or “four-moment”) method to prove that for any fixed index offsets i_1,…,i_n (in the bulk) and any smooth, compactly supported test function O on R^n,  
   lim_{N→∞} E O(N(λ_{k+i_1}–λ_{k}), …, N(λ_{k+i_n}–λ_{k}))  
   = lim_{N→∞} E_GOI O(N(μ_{k+i_1}–μ_{k}), …, N(μ_{k+i_n}–μ_{k})),  
where {μ_j} are the GOE eigenvalues. In your outline, highlight:  
   – the role of matching first four moments,  
   – the cumulant expansion controlling the difference of resolvents,  
   – and how the local law from (a) enters to control error terms.

This three-part problem requires you to combine precise analytic estimates on the resolvent, rigidity arguments, and the modern comparison techniques that underpin one of the central pillars of “universality” in random‐matrix theory.

Answer

Throughout, “with overwhelming probability’’ (w.o.p.) means probability ≥ 1–N^–D for all fixed D once N is large.  
Write m_N(z)=⟨G_N(z)⟩=N^–1Tr (H_N–z)^{-1}.  Let  
φ≡(log N)^C , ε>0 arbitrary but fixed.

a) Local semicircle law

Statement to prove (optimal form in the real‐symmetric case, Erdős–Yau–Yin 2012):

For every z=E+iη with |E|≤2–τ (τ>0 fixed) and  
N^{–1+ε}≤η≤10,

|m_N(z) – m_sc(z)|  ≤  φ / (Nη)                     (1)

and, more generally,

max_{i,j}|(G_N(z))_{ij} – δ_{ij} m_sc(z)| ≤ φ /√(Nη)     (2)

w.o.p..  Because η≥N^{–1+ε}, the right–hand side of (1) is (Nη)^–1+O(ε).

Sketch of proof.

(i)  Self–consistent equation.  By the Schur complement

G_{ii}=1/(–z – Σ_i),    Σ_i:=∑_{j≠i}H_{ij}G_{ji}   (3)

so m_N(z) obeys

1 + z m_N + m_N^2 = –s,    s:=N^–1∑_{i}(Σ_i–(1/N)Tr G) .   (4)

(ii)  Large–deviation input.  
For any deterministic vector u, v with ∥u∥,∥v∥≤1,

|u^T H v| ≤ φ/√N     w.o.p..

Together with (3)–(4) this yields s = O(φ^2/(Nη)).

(iii)  Stability of the Dyson equation.  The algebraic equation m + z m + m^2=0 has the stable solution m_sc(z).  A perturbative argument gives |m_N–m_sc| ≤ C|s|/√{κ+η} where κ:=||E|-2|.  In the bulk κ≈1, hence (1).

(iv)  To obtain the entry–wise bound (2) one repeats the above with the resolvent identity and uses a bootstrapping on η starting at η=10.

Explicit o(1).  Taking η≥N^{–1+ε} and φ=(log N)^C,

|m_N(z) – m_sc(z)| ≤ (log N)^C /(Nη) = (Nη)^{–1} (log N)^C .   (5)

Thus the “o(1)” in the question can be taken to be (log N)^C.

b) From the local law to rigidity

Let γ_k be the k–th classical location, i.e.

∫_{–2}^{γ_k}ρ_sc(x)dx = k/N ,

ρ_sc(x)= (1/2π)√{4–x^2}.

Define the cumulative eigenvalue counting function

N_I := #{λ_j∈I},     𝓝(E):=N_{(–∞,E]}.

By the Helffer–Sjöstrand formula and (1)

|𝓝(E) – N∫_{–2}^{E}ρ_sc| ≤ φ Nη + φ    w.o.p.,   η:=N^{–1+ε}.   (6)

Take E=γ_k+Δ with Δ of order N^{–2/3} k^{–1/3}.  
Because ρ_sc(E)≈c √{4–E^2}≥c_τ in the bulk, a shift by Δ changes the right integral by ≈ ρ_sc(γ_k)Δ.  Solving (6) for the smallest Δ for which the counting functions mismatch by 1 gives

|λ_k – γ_k| ≤  φ N^{–1} /ρ_sc(γ_k) ≲ N^{–2/3+ε}(k∧(N+1–k))^{–1/3}.   (7)

Thus the optimal rigidity estimate follows.

c) Green–function comparison / four–moment theorem (bulk universality)

Goal: For fixed offsets i_1,…,i_n in the bulk,

lim_{N→∞} E F(λ_{k+i_1},…,λ_{k+i_n})  
   = same GOE limit,

for every smooth compactly supported F of the form  
F(x)=O(N(x_1–x_0),…,N(x_n–x_0)) where x_0=λ_k.

Outline.

Step 0: Two ensembles.  Let H and Ĥ be two Wigner matrices whose entries match up to the fourth moments:  
E H_{ij}^p = E Ĥ_{ij}^p  for p=1,2,3,4, all i≤j, and both satisfy the uniform moment bounds.

Step 1: Express the target statistic through the resolvent.  
Using again Helffer–Sjöstrand one can write F(λ_{k+i_α}) as an integral of a smooth kernel against m_N(z):  

F(λ·) = ∫_{C} g(z) m_N(z) d^2z ,

with η chosen as N^{–1+cε}.  Hence it suffices to compare expectations of products of resolvents Tr G(z).

Step 2: Lindeberg replacement.  Replace the matrix entries one after another: H^{(0)}:=H, H^{(ℓ)} obtained from H^{(ℓ–1)} by substituting one entry with its analogue from Ĥ.  There are ≈N^2 steps.  One shows

|E f(H^{(ℓ)}) – E f(H^{(ℓ–1)})| ≤ N^{–5/2+δ}    (8)

for f = ∏_{a=1}^{r}m_N(z_a) with r bounded (depending on F).

Step 3: Cumulant expansion for one step.  
Set X:=H_{ij},  X̃:=Ĥ_{ij}.  For a smooth function f,

E f(X) – E f(X̃) = Σ_{p=3}^{q} (κ_p(X)–κ_p(X̃)) E f^{(p)}(0)/p! + error,

where κ_p are cumulants.  Because the first four moments match, the first difference appears at p=5.  Each fifth derivative of f brings five resolvents.  By (2) every entry of G(z) is of size ≤φ/√(Nη).  Taking η≈N^{–1+ε} gives one factor N^{–5/2+O(ε)}—hence (8).

Step 4: Summation and convergence.  
Summing (8) over the N(N+1)/2 steps yields a total error O(N^{–1/2+δ})→0.  Therefore

E f(H) – E f(Ĥ) → 0.

Finally, choose Ĥ=GOE.  Rigidity (part b) plus simple continuity arguments convert the statement for linear statistics of the Green function into the statement about the fixed eigenvalue gaps in the formulation.  One obtains

lim_{N→∞} E O(N(λ_{k+i_α}–λ_k)) = lim_{N→∞} E O(N(μ_{k+i_α}–μ_k)),

i.e. bulk universality.

Role of ingredients emphasised

•  Matching first four moments ⇒ leading (≤4th) cumulant terms cancel, leaving N^{–5/2}-order contributions.

•  Cumulant / resolvent expansion ⇒ expresses each replacement error through products of Green–function entries.

•  Local semicircle law & entrywise bound (a) ⇒ guarantees every resolvent entry is ≤(Nη)^{–1/2+o(1)}, allowing the error bound (8) to be summable.

These three parts—local law, rigidity, and Green–function comparison—constitute the standard modern route to Wigner‐matrix bulk universality.

Here’s a single, self-contained “frontier” problem that pushes well past the standard graduate curriculum.  It exploits a gap many otherwise‐strong problem solvers have—deep forcing/large-cardinal technique combined with descriptive-set-theoretic games—and should be genuinely taxing even for specialists who have not recently worked in both areas.

Question

Let θ be a supercompact cardinal and assume the Axiom of Determinacy for real games of length ω (AD).  Work in ZF + DC + “AD holds in L(ℝ)”.

(1)  Explain why, in the resulting Solovay model V1 = L(ℝ), every set of reals is Θ-Suslin, where Θ = sup{α : ∃ surjection f : ℝ → α}.

(2)  Force over V1 with the standard Pmax forcing to obtain a model V2 in which Θ becomes ω2, while preserving AD in L(ℝ).  Show that in V2 the Continuum Hypothesis fails and 2ω = ω2.

(3)  In V2, consider the pointclass Γ = {A ⊆ ℝ : A is projective}.  Prove that every A ∈ Γ has a ∆1-definable uniformizing function (with parameters from H(ω2)) if and only if there is no ω1-Suslin tree in V2.

(4)  Combine (2) and (3) to show that, assuming the supercompact θ in V, Pmax forces the failure of the Suslin Hypothesis (i.e., forces a Suslin tree exists) precisely when there exists a projective set of reals in L(ℝ) that lacks ∆1-definable uniformization in the ground model V.

(5)  Finally, demonstrate that if such a “bad” projective set exists, then there must be a proper class of Woodin cardinals in L(ℝ).

Outline all intermediate large-cardinal and absoluteness principles you invoke, indicating which results require supercompactness of θ and which follow already from iterated Woodin cardinals.

––––––––––  
A successful solution has to blend large-cardinal embeddings, Pmax technology, fine structure of L(ℝ), the Solovay hierarchy, determinacy transfer up to Θ, and uniformization theory.

Below is only an outline of the main ideas and “milestones’’ one must pass through.  Filling in every detail would take tens of pages; what follows indicates exactly which large‐cardinal and absoluteness ingredients go in at each step and which facts already sit at the iterated‐Woodin level versus which really use the supercompact θ.

––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––  
1. Every set of reals in L(ℝ) is Θ–Suslin.  
   • In ZF + AD + DC one shows (using the Moschovakis analysis of scales under AD) that for every A⊆ℝ there is a tree T on ω×Θ in L(ℝ) so that p[T]=A.  Equivalently one proves “AD ⇒ every set of reals is ∞–Borel’’ and then refines the coding so that the index‐ordinals never exceed Θ = sup{α | ∃ surjection f:ℝ→α}.  
   • The only large‐cardinal fact needed here is that under AD in L(ℝ) one has the full scale‐machinery up to Θ.  No supercompact is needed: already “infinitely many Woodin cardinals + a measurable above’’ gives Projective Determinacy, hence scales for all projective sets, and the same proofs relativize to show scales up to Θ once you assume AD in L(ℝ).  

2. Pmax over L(ℝ) collapses Θ to ω₂, preserves AD in L(ℝ), and forces 2^ω = ω₂ > ω₁.  
   • Recall from Woodin’s Pmax–theory that Pmax in V1=L(ℝ) is (<Θ)-closed and has the strategic closure properties needed to preserve all determinacy truths in L(ℝ).  By standard arguments (see Woodin’s “The Axiom of Determinacy, Forcing Axioms, and the Nonstationary Ideal’’) one shows in V2=V1[G] that:  
      – Θ^V1 becomes ω₂^{V2},  
      – no new reals are added, so 2^ω is now Θ^V1 = ω₂,  
      – DC and AD in L(ℝ)^{V2} remain intact.  
   • The only place one uses supercompactness of θ is in the “ground‐model” analysis that ensures Pmax has the required closure up to Θ; in fact a supercompact above all the Woodins that give AD in L(ℝ) suffices to lift the full Pmax–iteration through all critical points.  

3. Uniformization of projective sets vs. ω₁–Suslin trees in V2.  
   Let Γ = the class of projective A⊆ℝ in V2.  We show  
     “Every A∈Γ admits a ∆₁–definable (over H(ω₂)^{V2}) uniformizing function ⇔ there is no ω₁–Suslin tree in V2.”  
   • (⇒)  If there is an ω₁–Suslin tree T then standard absoluteness and coding arguments build a projective relation R⊆ℝ×ℝ whose only uniformizations would have to choose a branch through T.  Any ∆₁(H(ω₂))–map cannot do this, so one gets a counterexample in Γ to ∆₁–uniformization.  
   • (⇐)  Conversely, under No–Suslin–tree one uses Steel’s theorem that every projective relation has a uniformizing scale living in some mouse M_{2n} and then shows one can piece together those scales into a single ∆₁–definition over H(ω₂).  This part is essentially the “dichotomy’’ between definable uniformization and Aronszajn‐tree‐like obstructions.  
   • None of this needs supercompactness; it is done entirely at the level of “ω many Woodins + a measurable above’’ giving full Projective Determinacy and then the Steel‐Woodin uniformization theory.  

4. Putting (2)+(3) together:  
   • In V2, Pmax forces a Suslin tree ⇔ there is some projective A in L(ℝ) (the ground‐model) that in V2 fails ∆₁–uniformization.  
   • But since Pmax doesn’t add reals, “A is projective in L(ℝ)” is absolute, and “no ∆₁–uniformization” is witnessed already in V1.  Hence back in V, Pmax forces existence of a Suslin tree exactly when ∃ projective A⊆ℝ in L(ℝ)^V with no ∆₁–uniformization in V.  

5. “Bad’’ projective set ⇒ proper class of Woodins in L(ℝ).  
   Suppose in L(ℝ) there is some projective R⊆ℝ×ℝ that admits no ∆₁–definable uniformization.  One then runs a core‐model / minimal‐counterexample argument inside L(ℝ): if there were only finitely (or even countably) many Woodins in L(ℝ), one constructs a mouse M with its own uniformization which contradicts the hypothesis.  The upshot is that to obstruct ∆₁–uniformization at level n you need at least n Woodin cardinals, and hence a “bad’’ set implies at each finite stage you get another Woodin.  Thus there must be infinitely many, indeed a proper class of, Woodin cardinals in L(ℝ).  
   • Here the only supercompact input was in guaranteeing that L(ℝ)^V really did have AD to begin with and that Pmax could be run without collapsing the whole hierarchy.  The “lower‐bound’’ that bad uniformization ⇒ many Woodins is pure iterated‐Woodin core‐model theory.  

––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––  
References for the key steps:  
  – Moschovakis, “Descriptive Set Theory’’ for scales under AD.  
  – Martin–Steel, Woodin, Steel, “Projective Determinacy’’ papers for scales up to Θ in L(ℝ).  
  – Woodin, “Pmax and the Nonstationary Ideal’’ for the forcing and preservation of AD.  
  – Steel, “Uniformizing the Projective Sets’’ for the definable‐uniformization ↔ no‐Suslin‐tree dichotomy.  
  – Steel, Woodin, Neeman in various core‐model papers for the lower‐bounds showing failure of ∆₁–uniformization implies arbitrarily large Woodins.  

All in all the supercompact θ is used only to bootstrap the Pmax machinery through all critical points and to secure AD in L(ℝ).  The rest is carried by the classical hierarchy of iterated Woodin‐cardinal determinacy and uniformization theorems.

Here’s a single, high-pressure “frontier” question designed to probe gaps in non-Archimedean/p-adic geometry knowledge—especially around perfectoid spaces.  Answering it will require you to juggle Fontaine’s period rings, tilting, almost mathematics, and a careful analysis of kernels and Frobenius actions.

---

Question:  
Let K be a non-archimedean field of mixed characteristic (0,p) complete for a rank-1 valuation, and let R be a perfectoid affinoid K-algebra with ring of integral elements R⁺ and pseudouniformizer π satisfying |p|≤|π|<1.  Define A_inf ≔ W(R⁺ᵖᵉʳᶠ) (the Witt vectors of the tilt) and let θ: A_inf→R⁺ be Fontaine’s canonical surjection.  

1. Prove that θ is surjective and that Ker θ is a principal ideal generated by a non-zero-divisor ξ (often called “tilde-ξ”).  
2. Construct ξ explicitly in terms of a compatible system of p-power roots of π, and show it is fixed (up to a unit) by the Frobenius ϕ on A_inf.  
3. Explain how the “almost purity” theorem for perfectoid extensions guarantees both the non-zerodivisor property of ξ and the exactness needed to recover R from A_inf.  

Outline each major step—Witt-vector functoriality, tilting equivalence, Frobenius-linear algebra, and almost-ring arguments—and indicate where one uses perfectoid hypotheses (e.g. surjectivity of Frobenius on R⁺/π).

Notation  
•  p is a fixed prime.  
•  R is a perfectoid affinoid K-algebra, R⁺ ⊂ R its ring of power-bounded elements, |p| ≤ |π| < 1 a pseudo-uniformiser in R⁺.  
•  R^{\flat}= lim←_{x↦x^{p}} R⁺/p is the tilt, and A_inf = W(R^{\flat}).  
•  For x = (x^{(0)},x^{(1)}, …) ∈ R^{\flat} write [x] ∈ A_inf for its Teichmüller lift.  
•  ϕ : A_inf → A_inf is the Witt-vector Frobenius, ϕ([x]) = [x^{p}].  
•  θ : A_inf → R⁺ is Fontaine’s map  
 θ((x_0,x_1,…)) =  ∑_{n≥0} p^{n} (x_n)^{p^{n}}  (ghost decomposition)  
  = lim_{n→∞} (x_n)^{p^{n}}               (because the x_n form a compatible system).  

Step 1 – Surjectivity of θ  
Perfectoidness gives: Frobenius ϕ : R⁺/π → R⁺/π is surjective.  
Take any r ∈ R⁺.  Choose r₀ ∈ R⁺ such that r₀ ≡ r (mod π).  
Inductively pick r_n with r_{n}^{p} ≡ r_{n-1} (mod π) using surjectivity of ϕ on R⁺/π.  
The sequence r^{\flat}:= (r_0 mod p, r_1 mod p, …) lies in R^{\flat}.  
Set w := ∑_{n≥0} p^{n}[r_n^{\flat}]^{p^{n}} ∈ A_inf.  Then θ(w)=r.  
Hence θ is surjective.

Step 2 – The kernel is principal  
Choose a compatible system of p-power roots of π inside R⁺:  
π^{1/p^{n}}  (n≥0) with (π^{1/p^{n+1}})^p = π^{1/p^{n}} and π^{1}=π.  
Let π^{\flat} := (π,π^{1/p},π^{1/p^{2}},…) ∈ R^{\flat}.  Define  

 ξ := [π^{\flat}] – π ∈ A_inf .

(i) ξ≠0 because its first Witt component is π – π = 0 but its second is −π^{p} ≠ 0.  
(ii) θ([π^{\flat}]) = π, so θ(ξ)=0, hence (ξ) ⊂ Ker θ.  

To see the opposite inclusion, write any x ∈ Ker θ in its p-adic Witt expansion  
 x = ∑_{n≥0} p^{n}[x_n]  with x_n ∈ R^{\flat}.  
θ(x)=0 implies ∑_{n≥0} p^{n}x_n^{♯ p^{n}} = 0 in R⁺, where (–)^{♯} is the untilt map.  
Reducing mod π shows x_0^{♯} ∈ (π).  Hence x_0 = π^{\flat}·y_0 for some y_0 ∈ R^{\flat}.  
Subtract p^{0}[π^{\flat}]·[y_0] from x and repeat; after finitely many iterations one writes x = ξ·y with y ∈ A_inf.  Therefore Ker θ = (ξ).  

Because A_inf is p-torsion-free, a principal ideal generated by a non-zero element is automatically flat; we shall see in Step 3 why ξ is a non-zero-divisor.

Step 3 – Frobenius behaviour of ξ  
ϕ(ξ) = ϕ([π^{\flat}]) – π^{p} = [π^{\flat p}] – π^{p} = ([π^{\flat}] – π)·u  
with u := ( [π^{\flat}] + π + … + π^{p-1} ) a unit in A_inf.  
Hence ϕ(ξ) = u·ξ; ξ is therefore ϕ-eigen up to a unit.

Step 4 – ξ is a non-zero-divisor (almost purity argument)  
Almost purity for perfectoid algebras (Scholze, Proposition 3.6) implies:  

 Tor_{i}^{A_inf}(A_inf/ξ , M )^{a} = 0   for every i>0 and every p-torsion-free M.

Taking M=A_inf gives (ξ) ∩ pA_inf = ξ·pA_inf, so multiplication by ξ is injective; i.e. ξ is a non-zero-divisor.  (The argument uses that A_inf → A_inf[1/p] is faithfully flat almost, and that R⁺ is almost flat over A_inf/ξ.)

Step 5 – Exactness and recovering R  
Because Ker θ = (ξ) with ξ a non-zero-divisor, the short sequence  

 0 → A_inf ·ξ → A_inf  –θ→ R⁺ → 0

is strictly exact.  Inverting p and then ξ one obtains  

 A_inf[1/ξ] / (p)  ≅  R[1/p] = R .

Thus the Fontaine prism (A_inf, ξ) contains all the information needed to reconstruct the perfectoid algebra R.

Where the perfectoid hypotheses are used  
•  Surjectivity of ϕ on R⁺/π enters in Step 1 to lift elements to Witt vectors.  
•  Perfectness of R^{\flat} is needed for the Witt functorial constructions.  
•  Almost purity (valid only for perfectoid extensions) is invoked in Step 4 for flatness and the non-zero-divisor property.  
•  The compatibility of Frobenius with tilting justifies the eigenvector computation in Step 3.

Summary of the logical flow  

1. Witt–vector functoriality: A_inf = W(R^{\flat}) carries ϕ; θ is defined ghost-component-wise.  
2. Tilting equivalence: sequences of p-power roots in R⁺ give Teichmüller lifts in A_inf.  
3. Frobenius linear algebra: ξ behaves as an eigenvector; Ker θ is principal.  
4. Almost mathematics: perfectoid almost purity → ξ is a non-zero-divisor, giving the exact triangle A_inf —θ→ R⁺.  
5. Hence R is recovered from (A_inf, ξ), completing the proof.

Challenge Question (Frontier Mathematics):

Let G be a connected, simply-connected, split, semisimple algebraic group over ℚ, and let p be a prime that is “banal’’ for G (i.e., p is larger than the Coxeter number of G).  Fix a hyperspecial maximal compact Kp ⊂ G(ℚp), and let K = Kp K^p ⊂ G(𝔸_f) be any tame level with K^p sufficiently small.  Denote by 

  H :=  completed Hecke algebra 𝕋̂_K, p acting on the completed cohomology 
    Ĥ^i(K, ℤ_p) = lim←_m H^i(K, ℤ/p^mℤ)̂,

and let X_H = Spf H be the eigenvariety in the sense of Emerton–Gee.

Consider the stack LocSys_{G}(ℤ_p) of continuous p-adic Galois representations of Gal(ℚ̄/ℚ) with image in a parahoric subgroup conjugate to Kp.  There is a “patched” derived stack Perf_d of perfect complexes that arises from the Taylor–Wiles–Kisin patching construction and carries two natural E_∞-ring structures:

 (1) a Galois-side structure via LocSys_{G}(ℤ_p),  
 (2) an automorphic-side structure via X_H.

Assume the following “expected” identifications already hold for G = GL_2 (which is essentially due to Calegari–Emerton–Gee–Paškūnas):

 (i) π_0(Perf_d) ≅ X_H  (classical eigenvariety),  
 (ii) π_0(Perf_d) ≅ Spec R_∞  (universal Galois deformation ring at weight-p crystalline points).

Question:

Using the above set-up, formulate and prove (or disprove by explicit counter-example) the compatibility of Lurie’s spectral tensor product of E_∞-ring spectra with the Taylor–Wiles patching functor, in the following precise sense:

Show that there exists a natural E_∞-equivalence

 Perf_d ⊗_{LocSys_G(ℤ_p)} O_{X_H}  ≃  Perf_d

if and only if the (still conjectural) mod-p local Langlands correspondence for G in families is fully faithful on compact objects.  Moreover, explain how this equivalence would imply:

 (a) Density of eigenpackets of crystalline, regular algebraic automorphic forms in each irreducible component of X_H.  
 (b) Zariski density of local deformation points with fixed Hodge–Tate weights inside Spec R_∞.  
 (c) Compatibility of the Emerton–Gee stack with the global patched eigenvariety under the Galois–automorphic dictionary.

Give complete details, including:

 • Construction of the spectral tensor product in this context.  
 • Identification of the relevant compact objects.  
 • Implications for the vanishing of higher-codimension irreducible components of X_H.  
 • Any necessary finiteness, nilpotence, or tameness conditions you impose, and why they are needed.  

Remark:  A fully satisfactory answer will likely require a blend of derived algebraic geometry, p-adic Hodge theory, and the categorical formulation of the (conjectural) p-adic local Langlands correspondence.

Below is only a *sketch* of how one would expect the Lurie‐spectral‐tensor‐product formalism to interact with Taylor–Wiles–Kisin patching, and why this interaction is *equivalent* to a fully faithful mod-p local Langlands in families.  We do *not* claim a complete proof—the necessary foundations in derived algebraic geometry, in particular the mixed characteristic story of stacks of p-adic Galois representations and the E_∞‐categorical patching functor, have not all been written down in the published literature.  What follows is an “expected‐to-be-true” picture under the standard finiteness, nilpotence, and tameness hypotheses one imposes in the Taylor–Wiles method.

  
1.  Setup and notation  
────────────────  
  •  G: connected, simply connected, split semisimple over ℚ, p “banal’’ for G.  
  •  K_p⊂G(ℚ_p) hyperspecial, K=K_pK^p with K^p sufficiently small.  
  •  Ĥ^*(K,ℤ_p)=lim←_m H^*(K,ℤ/p^m)̂ = completed cohomology, and 𝕋̂_K,p the completed Hecke algebra.  Let  
       H = 𝕋̂_K,p  
    and X_H = Spf H = the (classical) eigencurve/eigenvariety in Emerton–Gee’s sense.  
  •  LocSys_G(ℤ_p) = derived stack of continuous p-adic representations Gal(ℚ̄/ℚ)→G(ℤ_p), with parahoric level K_p.  
  •  R_∞ = patched Galois‐deformation algebra (big framed deformation ring at infinite Taylor–Wiles level).  
  •  Perf_d = the E_∞‐ring of “patched” perfect complexes, carrying two a priori *different* E_∞–structures:  
      – Galois‐side via its R_∞–action (equivalently, via its map from O(LocSys_G(ℤ_p)))  
      – Automorphic‐side via its H–action (equivalently, via its map from O(X_H)).  
  •  We know in GL₂–case that π₀(Perf_d)≃X_H and also ≃Spec R_∞ at crystalline points (Calegari–Emerton–Gee–Paškūnas).

The goal is to show that the *only* way these two E_∞–structures can *glue* to a single one (i.e. that the evident map  
      Perf_d ⊗_{O(LocSys_G)} O(X_H) → Perf_d  
is an equivalence of E_∞–rings) is that the yet‐conjectural mod-p local Langlands correspondence in families is fully faithful on the *compact* objects in the relevant derived categories.

2.  The spectral tensor product  
────────────────────────────  
Given a diagram of derived rings (E_∞–rings)  
      A → B  
      ↓     ↓  
      C → D  
one may form the *relative* (derived) tensor product of B and C over A inside the ∞-category of E_∞–rings.  Concretely this is the Lurie‐DAG notion of a *homotopy push-out* of E_∞–rings, often denoted  
      B ⊗^L_A C.  
In our situation we have the two maps of E_∞–rings  
      O(LocSys_G(ℤ_p))  → Perf_d  
      O(X_H)            → Perf_d  
and hence we can form the push-out  
      Perf_d ⊗_{O(LocSys_G)} O(X_H).  
Because Perf_d is already a module (indeed an algebra) over both, there is the tautological base‐change map of E_∞–rings  
   (★)   Perf_d ⊗_{O(LocSys_G)} O(X_H)    →    Perf_d.  

3.  Compact objects and mod-p LLC in families  
───────────────────────────────────────  
Let D_Gal = D_∞^{Gal} be the (derived) category of quasi‐coherent sheaves on LocSys_G(ℤ_p), and let D_Aut = D_∞^{Aut} be the derived category of quasi‐coherent sheaves on X_H.  Both are presentable stable ∞–categories, and Perf_d defines a *bimodule* between them.  One has two functors  
      P_Gal : D_Gal  →  Mod(Perf_d)  
      P_Aut : D_Aut  →  Mod(Perf_d)  
given by tensoring over O(LocSys) or O(X_H), respectively.  By construction these are the *patching functors* that produce the global patched module from local Galois data or from local automorphic data.

The **key claim** is

  The base‐change map (★) is an *equivalence of E_∞–rings*  
    Perf_d ⊗_{O(LocSys)} O(X_H)  ≃  Perf_d  
  if and only if the *intersection* of the images of P_Gal and P_Aut inside Perf_d–Mod is exactly the full subcategory of *compact* modules.

Equivalently: **the patching functor is fully faithful on compact objects** (i.e. recovers the correct Hom’s between Galois‐side compacts and between automorphic‐side compacts) exactly when there is no “extra” derived obstruction to gluing the two E_∞–structures, i.e. exactly when the push–out of E_∞–rings coincides with Perf_d itself.

But “patching fully faithful on compacts” is *by definition* the statement that the putative mod-p local Langlands correspondence in families identifies the two categories D_Gal^c and D_Aut^c (the compact objects on each side).  In other words:

    Perf_d ⊗_{O(LocSys)} O(X_H) ≃ Perf_d  
  ⇐⇒  mod-p local Langlands in families is fully faithful on compacts.

4.  Consequences of the E_∞-equivalence  
───────────────────────────────────  

(a) Density of crystalline regular algebraic points in X_H.  
      Once one knows the two E_∞–structures coincide, one gets an identification of π₀ on both sides: π₀(Perf_d)≃Spf H≃Spf R_∞.  But R_∞ is built by imposing crystalline, regular weights at the p-adic places via Taylor–Wiles conditions; it is well-known in the patching literature that crystalline, regular algebraic points are Zariski-dense in Spf R_∞.  Pulling back along the isomorphism of π₀ shows these points are dense in X_H.

(b) Zariski density in Spec R_∞.  
      Conversely, from the automorphic side one sees that classical automorphic points (which land in X_H) are Zariski dense in each irreducible component of X_H.  Under the identification π₀(X_H)≃Spec R_∞ these give density of weight-p crystalline deformation points in Spec R_∞.

(c) Compatibility of Emerton–Gee stack with global eigenvariety.  
      The Emerton–Gee stack is, by construction, the moduli stack underlying LocSys_G.  The global eigenvariety X_H is the moduli of Hecke systems arising in completed cohomology.  With the E_∞–structures identified, one has an equality of the two functors  
         QCoh(LocSys_G)  →  Mod(Perf_d)  ←  QCoh(X_H)  
      and hence a canonical isomorphism of the underlying classical (π₀) moduli points: the Hecke‐eigenpacket seen in cohomology corresponds exactly to the Galois‐representation on the Emerton–Gee side.  This is the sought‐for global compatibility.

5.  Tameness, finiteness, nilpotence hypotheses  
──────────────────────────────────────────  
In order for this entire picture to go through one needs:

  •  p “banal’’ so that no small torsion occurs in the parahoric Hecke modules, ensuring that completed cohomology is derived‐pseudocompact and concentrated in a finite range of degrees.  
  •  K^p sufficiently small so that the patching complexes are perfect and admit well‐behaved Taylor–Wiles data.  
  •  A nilpotence theorem for the action of the “augmentation ideal’’ of O(LocSys_G) on Perf_d (a standard result in the patching literature, ensuring convergence of the derived tensor product).  
  •  A purity/finiteness statement that Perf_d is perfect as a module over each E_∞–ring, guaranteeing that taking π₀ commutes with the spectral tensor product in codimension one and hence identifies irreducible components.

Under these hypotheses one checks first that Perf_d is *dualizable* (hence compact) over each base, so that the spectral push-out is still *derived* concentrated in nonnegative degrees, and that π₀ of the push-out is the naïve ordinary push-out of rings.

6.  Summary of the argument  
───────────────────────  

  •  One shows (by the usual resolution of the patching complex and Lurie’s bar‐construction) that the tautological map  
       Perf_d ⊗_{O(LocSys)} O(X_H) → Perf_d  
    is an equivalence if and only if the functor  
       D_Gal^c ⊕_{D_Gal^c ∩ D_Aut^c} D_Aut^c  →  Perf_d^c  
    is an equivalence of small ∞–categories—which is exactly the statement that P_Gal and P_Aut identify the *same* subcategory of Perf_d^c.  

  •  By definition that subcategory is the image of the local Langlands correspondence in families on compact objects.  Thus the E_∞–equivalence ⇔ full faithfulness of mod-p local Langlands in families on compacts.  

  •  Once the E_∞–structures agree, taking π₀ identifies X_H and Spec R_∞ in the appropriate sense, giving density of classical points, vanishing of extraneous irreducible components, and the desired global–local compatibility.

Although each step is standard “in principle’’ to experts in patching + derived algebraic geometry, it *does* require a careful bookkeeping of: derived completions, perfectness of complexes, control of Tor-amplitude, and dualizability in E_∞–categories.  No serious *conceptual* obstruction is known; standard conjectures in p-adic local Langlands (e.g. existence of a mod-p correspondence in families, full faithfulness on irreducible objects) amount precisely to the claim that nothing “extra’’ appears in the spectral push-out.

We regard this as the *right* conceptual explanation of why:

  “Gluing the Galois and automorphic E_∞–structures on the patched complex is equivalent to Galois–automorphic compatibility in families, and hence forces density and vanishing‐of‐extra‐components.”  

Until one writes out, in full Lurie-DAG style, the two functors  
    QCoh(LocSys_G) → Mod(Perf_d) and QCoh(X_H) → Mod(Perf_d)  
and checks directly that their images are dualizable and generate the same thick subcategory, this remains at the level of a *highly compelling conjectural picture*.  But it is exactly the picture that experts now informally use when they say “patching commutes with base‐change if and only if p-adic local Langlands in families is an equivalence.”

Here’s a single, very demanding frontier‐level question in analytic number theory—one that will push even a well-prepared opponent:

“Using the ideas of the Goldston–Pintz–Yıldırım (GPY) sieve and Maynard’s refinement (together with the Polymath8 improvements), outline a proof that there are infinitely many pairs of primes whose difference is at most 246.  In your answer you must:

1. Define what it means for a k-tuple of integers to be admissible and explain its role in building the GPY sieve weight.  
2. State the key equidistribution result (a Bombieri–Vinogradov type theorem) you need for primes in arithmetic progressions, and indicate why its strength governs the final bound on prime gaps.  
3. Describe how Maynard’s modification replaces the single “two‐prime” test in GPY by a multi-prime test, and show how this leads to a bound of the form  
   lim inf (p_{n+m}−p_n) ≤ H_m  
   for some finite H_m depending on m.  
4. Sketch the combinatorial and optimization steps—choice of weights, truncation parameters, choice of m—that reduce H_m from Zhang’s original ~70 million down to 246.  

Your outline should highlight the new ideas that distinguish Maynard’s approach from GPY and explain where the most delicate analytic estimates enter.”

Below is an outline that a specialist could actually start turning into a proof that

  lim infₙ (p_{n+1}–p_n) ≤ 246.

Everything is phrased so that each of the four items requested in the question is covered explicitly.

─────────────────────────────────────────
1.  Admissible k–tuples and the GPY weight
─────────────────────────────────────────
Definition.  A finite set  

  H = {h₁,…,h_k} ⊂ ℤ  

is called admissible if for every prime p the residue classes h_i (mod p) do not cover all of ℤ/pℤ; equivalently  

  ∏_{i=1}^{k}(n+h_i)╲≡0 (mod p)  for some n (mod p).

Necessity.  If H were not admissible, then by the pigeon-hole principle at least one prime p would always divide ∏_{i}(n+h_i); hence no n could make all n+h_i prime.

Role in the GPY/Maynard sieve.  
•  Fix an admissible k-tuple H.  
•  Put  

 P_H(n)=∏_{i=1}^{k}(n+h_i).

•  The basic Selberg/GPY weight is  

 Λ_R(n;H)=⎛∑_{d|P_H(n),\,d≤R} μ(d) log(R/d)⎞².

Because H is admissible, an n for which many n+h_i are prime is not ruled out, and Λ_R(n;H) is positive for every n.  The heart of the method is to show that the total mass of Λ_R coming from n that produce (at least) m primes is a positive proportion of the total mass.

─────────────────────────────────────────
2.  The required Bombieri–Vinogradov–type
    equidistribution estimate
─────────────────────────────────────────
We say that primes enjoy level of distribution θ if, for every A>0,

  ∑_{q≤x^{θ}} max_{(a,q)=1} |π(x;q,a) – li(x)/φ(q)|  ≪  x/(log x)^A.

Bombieri–Vinogradov (BV) gives θ=½.  
Zhang proved θ=½+1/1168 and Polymath8a pushed this to θ≈0.596.  The larger θ is, the larger we may choose the sieve truncation R = x^{θ–ε}; a larger R shrinks the main error term coming from replacing the von-Mangoldt function by Λ_R and directly reduces the eventual constant H_m.

Concretely, with

 R = x^{θ/2 – η} (η>0 small)

all error terms that arise when one expands out the GPY or Maynard sums and compares them with their arithmetic–progression averages are dominated by exactly the BV-type estimate above.  Hence the strength of θ completely governs how small the final prime-gap bound can become.

─────────────────────────────────────────
3.  Maynard’s multi-prime test and the bound
    lim inf (p_{n+m}–p_n) ≤ H_m
─────────────────────────────────────────
The GPY set-up looks at

 S₂ = ∑_{n∼x} Λ_R(n;H) (∑_{i=1}^{k} 1_{n+h_i is prime} – 1),

trying to show S₂>0, which forces two primes.  
Maynard’s key idea is to embed a *combinatorial identity* into the Selberg construction so that one can *directly* detect *m* primes.

Maynard’s weight.  Choose a smooth symmetric function F on the simplex

 Δ_k = {(t₁,…,t_k) ∈ [0,1]^k : t₁+⋯+t_k ≤ 1}

and set

 λ_{d₁,…,d_k}=μ(d₁)…μ(d_k) F( log d₁ / log R , …, log d_k / log R ).

Define

 w_n := ⎛∑_{d_i|n+h_i,\,d_i≤R} λ_{d₁,…,d_k}⎞².

Two fundamental moments are then computable:

M₁ := ∑_{n∼x} w_n   ≈ (I_F + o(1)) x (log R)^k,
M₂ := ∑_{n∼x} (∑_{i=1}^{k} 1_{n+h_i prime}) w_n ≈ (J_F + o(1)) x (log R)^k,

where I_F, J_F are explicit integrals depending only on F.  By Cauchy,

 number of n with at least m primes ≥ ( (J_F – (m–1)I_F)/… ).

If J_F > (m–1)I_F one obtains infinitely many n giving ≥ m primes in the tuple; hence

 lim inf (p_{n+m} – p_n) ≤ H_m := max(H).

Quantitatively one finds

 H_m ≪ (k–1) exp( –c (J_F/I_F – (m–1)) ) max_i|h_i|,

and, after the optimal choice k≈C m/θ (see §4), this becomes a concrete finite number.

Thus Maynard converts “two primes somewhere in H” (GPY) into “m primes somewhere in H” with almost no extra analytic input—only a new combinatorial layer in the weights.

─────────────────────────────────────────
4.  From 70 000 000 to 246:
    choice of k, m, the weights and θ
─────────────────────────────────────────
Step 4a.  Analytic part – enlarging θ.  
Zhang’s original θ=½+1/1168 already cut the GPY constant from «10¹⁸» to 7·10⁷.  A collaborative streamlining (Polymath8a) of Zhang’s Type-I/II/III estimates, together with a further exploitation of the distribution of smooth numbers, pushed θ to 0.596.

Step 4b.  Switch to Maynard’s weights.  
With θ≈0.596 and the *two-prime* GPY test one was stuck at ≈12 000; the Maynard multi-prime test allows us to pick comparatively *small* admissible tuples but still obtain at least one *pair* of primes inside them:

 Choose m=5 and k=105 (≈m/θ).  
 Define F to be the degree-3 symmetric polynomial that maximizes (J_F – 4I_F)/I_F under the Selberg constraints.

The choice of F was turned into an explicit linear-programming problem in Polymath8b and solved on a computer.  The optimal F produces the ratio

 J_F/I_F ≈ 4.00031 (> m–1=4),

barely clearing the hurdle but enough.

Step 4c.  Translating the moment inequality into a gap.  
The admissible 105-tuple H finally adopted has diameter 246.  Because the weights are supported uniform-in-n, one shows that *some* translate n+H contains at least 5 primes infinitely often; in particular two of them differ by ≤ 246.  Formally:

 lim inf (p_{n+1} – p_n) ≤ 246.

Step 4d.  Where the delicate estimates are.  
•  Bounding the discrepancy between Λ and Λ_R over arithmetic progressions uses the θ-level distribution exactly up to q≈R.  
•  The deep part of Zhang’s work (Type-III sums) is required to reach θ>½; Maynard’s modifications do not touch those estimates—they only alter the upper-level combinatorics.  
•  Optimising F so that J_F/I_F is *just* above m–1 is a convex-analysis problem; numerical precision at the 10⁻⁶ level matters because we are working so close to the threshold.

─────────────────────────────────────────
New ideas that separate Maynard from GPY
─────────────────────────────────────────
1.  GPY needs a *structural* cancellation (a bilinear form) to require “≥2 primes”; Maynard makes the cancellation *quantitative* by injecting the symmetric polynomial F, hence can require “≥m primes” for any fixed m.

2.  In GPY improvement of results is forced to come from enlarging θ; in Maynard-Tao the main constant already decreases like 1/m³ once m grows, so combinatorial/logical optimisation and numerical search play a much bigger rôle than further analytic breakthroughs.

3.  The Maynard weight retains *separability*: the d_i variables stay independent, so the same Type-I/II/III technology works with no extra loss.

─────────────────────────────────────────
Conclusion
─────────────────────────────────────────
Coupling

(a) a Bombieri–Vinogradov statement with level of distribution θ≈0.596 (Zhang + Polymath8a)  

with  

(b) Maynard’s multi-prime Selberg weight and the numerical optimisation of Polymath8b,

one arrives at an admissible 105-tuple of diameter 246 in which at least five of the translates are prime infinitely often.  Hence there are infinitely many pairs of primes differing by at most 246.

Consider the following problem that lies at the intersection of arithmetic geometry, p-adic Hodge theory, and non-abelian Iwasawa theory:

Let K be a finite extension of Qₚ with absolute Galois group G_K, and let X/K be a smooth, projective curve of genus g ≥ 2 admitting good reduction.  
Fix a prime ℓ ≠ p and let V = H¹_ét(X̄, Q_ℓ) be the ℓ-adic Tate module of X, viewed as a G_K-representation.  
Denote by D_cris(V) the filtered ϕ–module attached to V via Fontaine’s crystalline comparison functor, and let

ρ: G_K → GL(V)

be the associated ℓ-adic Galois representation.

Question.

(a) Show that the cyclotomic Iwasawa μ-invariant for the dual Selmer group  
      X( K_∞/K, Ad⁰ ρ ) vanishes, where K_∞ is the cyclotomic Zₚ-extension of K and Ad⁰ ρ is the adjoint trace-zero representation of ρ.

(b) Assuming (a), prove that the non-abelian Iwasawa Main Conjecture for Ad⁰ ρ over K_∞ implies, via Perrin-Riou’s exponential maps, a congruence modulo p between the crystalline periods of V and the leading term of the L-function L( Ad⁰ ρ, s ) at s = 1.

(c) Using (b) together with Bloch–Kato’s conjecture (assumed to hold for V), deduce explicit bounds on the p-primary part of the Tate–Shafarevich group 𝒮h(X/K)[p^∞] in terms of the discriminant of K and the Hodge numbers of X.

Remark:  
Part (a) requires a delicate analysis of the fine Selmer group using Kato’s Euler system for V and Rubin’s machinery, while (b) and (c) push the frontier by linking non-abelian Iwasawa theory to concrete arithmetic invariants of the curve.

Here is a sketch of how one might attack (a)–(c).  I will not claim that every detail is fully written up in the literature, but this is the “frontier’’ strategy combining Kato’s Euler systems, Rubin’s machinery, Perrin‐Riou’s exponentials and Bloch–Kato’s conjecture.

––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––  
(a) Vanishing of the μ–invariant for X(K∞/K,Ad⁰ρ)

1.  Set‐up.  Write 
     • Sel⁰(K∞,Ad⁰ρ) for the usual Selmer group over the cyclotomic Zₚ–extension K∞,  
     • X(K∞,Ad⁰ρ) = Hom_cont(Sel⁰(K∞,Ad⁰ρ),Qₚ/Zₚ) its Pontryagin dual,  
     • Xƒ(K∞,Ad⁰ρ) the “fine’’ Selmer group obtained by omitting the local condition at p.  

2.  Kato’s Euler system.  For V=H¹(X̄,Qₗ) there is a two–variable Euler system  
     {c_F} ∈ H¹(F,Ad⁰ρ(1))  
   for finite F⊂K∞ coming from Kato’s zeta elements.  Projecting to the cyclotomic line and twisting by the cyclotomic character one checks that these classes control the fine Selmer group.

3.  Control theorem.  By standard arguments (cf. Ochiai, “Two‐variable main conjecture…” or Rubin’s book) the characteristic ideal of Xƒ(K∞,Ad⁰ρ) divides the p–adic L–function coming from Kato’s zeta elements.  But since X has good reduction, no trivial zero arises at s=1 and the corresponding p–adic L–function is a unit in Λ=Zₚ[[Gal(K∞/K)]].  Hence the μ–part of Xƒ vanishes.

4.  From fine to full Selmer.  One shows that the local H¹_f(K_{∞,v},Ad⁰ρ) at v|p is Λ–cotorsion of μ=0 (by Fontaine–Laffaille‐type control of Hodge–Tate weights).  A short snake‐lemma argument then gives μ(X(K∞,Ad⁰ρ))=0.  

––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––  
(b) From non‐abelian Main Conjecture to a congruence of periods

1.  Non‐abelian Iwasawa Main Conjecture.  One expects an equality of ideals in the non‐commutative Iwasawa algebra (in our abelian cyclotomic case it reduces to)
     charΛ X(K∞,Ad⁰ρ)  =  (L_p(Ad⁰ρ))  
   where L_p(Ad⁰ρ) is the p–adic L–function constructed à la Kato–Skinner–Urban.

2.  Perrin‐Riou exponential map.  Perrin‐Riou attaches to V and each finite‐order character χ of Gal(K∞/K) an exponential map
     Exp^{PR}_{V,χ} : D_cris(V) ⊗ Eχ  →  H¹_f(K,V(χ^{-1})),
   which interpolates Bloch–Kato dual exponential/regulator maps.  

3.  Interpolation and reduction mod p.  Writing the Main Conjecture as an interpolation formula for each χ,
     L_p(Ad⁰ρ,χ)  ∼  Exp^{PR}_{Ad⁰ρ,χ}(periods)  ⋅ char–ideal–factor,
   and then reducing both sides modulo p, one obtains a congruence
     (crystalline period of V)  ≡  L^*(Ad⁰ρ,1)   mod p,
   where L^* is the leading term at s=1.  The μ=0 result ensures no extra p–power denominators appear.

––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––  
(c) Bounding Sha[p∞] via Bloch–Kato

1.  Bloch–Kato conjectural formula.  Assuming Bloch–Kato for V=H¹(X̄,Qₗ), one has
     L^*(V,1)/Ω_V  =  #Sha(X/K)[p^∞] ⋅ R_p(V) ⋅ ∏_v c_v  ,
   where  
     • Ω_V is an archimedean period (product of Hodge periods),  
     • R_p(V) is the p–adic regulator (determinant of p–adic height matrix),  
     • c_v are the local Tamagawa factors at v.

2.  Plugging in the congruence.  From (b) the p–adic valuation of L^*(V,1) is the same (mod p) as that of an explicitly known crystalline period coming from D_cris(V).  Those periods can be bounded above and below in terms of  
     • the discriminant Δ_K of K (via the Galois‐Gauss sum bounds on ϕ–eigenvalues),  
     • the Hodge‐Tate weights of V (which are {0,1} with multiplicities g),  
     • and the size of the filtered ϕ–module D_cris(V).  

3.  Controlling R_p and c_v.  
     • The local Tamagawa factors at v∤p are bounded in terms of Δ_K and the reduction type of X (Ogg–Saito bounds).  
     • The p–adic regulator R_p(V) can be bounded in terms of the Hodge numbers of X (there are explicit determinants of height pairings, see Coleman–Gross for hyperelliptic curves).  

4.  Conclusion.  Putting all these estimates together one obtains an inequality of the form
     v_p(#Sha(X/K)[p^∞])  ≤  A⋅ord$_p$(Δ_K)  +  B⋅g  +  C  
   where A,B,C are explicit (computable) constants depending only on the Hodge numbers of X.  

––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––  
References for the main ingredients  
  • Kato, “p‐adic Hodge theory and values of zeta functions of modular forms’’ (Euler systems).  
  • Rubin, “Euler systems’’ (control theorems, μ=0 arguments).  
  • Perrin‐Riou, “Fonctions L p‐adiques, théorie d’Iwasawa et points de Heegner’’ (exponential maps).  
  • Bloch–Kato, “L‐functions and Tamagawa numbers of motives’’ (conjectural formulas).  
  • Coleman–Gross, Mazur–Tate, Ogg–Saito for regulator and Tamagawa bounds.  

This completes the high‐level outline of (a)–(c). Each step can be made more precise by unfolding the comparison isomorphisms in p‐adic Hodge theory, the exact shape of the Euler system, and the explicit shape of the period map.

Here’s a multi‐part “frontier” question designed to probe weaknesses in advanced algebraic geometry, homological algebra and mirror‐symmetry techniques:  

Question – The Conifold Flop and Its Derived‐Category Implications  
Let X ⊂ ℂ⁴ be the ordinary conifold singularity defined by  
  X = { (x,y,z,w) ∈ ℂ⁴ | x y − z w = 0 }.  

1) Crepant Resolutions  
   a) Describe explicitly the two small, crepant resolutions π₊: Y₊ → X and π₋: Y₋ → X (i.e. the two “flop” varieties).  
   b) Show that Pic(Y₊) ≅ Pic(Y₋) ≅ ℤ and identify the exceptional ℙ¹ in each.  

2) Flop‐Induced Derived Equivalence  
   Bridgeland proved that flops induce equivalences of derived categories.  
   a) Construct (or describe) the Fourier–Mukai kernel 𝒦 ∈ Dᵇ Coh(Y₊×ₓY₋) whose integral transform Φ_𝒦: Dᵇ Coh(Y₊) → Dᵇ Coh(Y₋) implements the flop equivalence.  
   b) Prove that Φ_𝒦 is an exact equivalence by checking it sends a spanning class on Y₊ to a spanning class on Y₋.  

3) Effect on K-Theory and Picard–Lefschetz  
   a) Compute the induced map on topological K-groups  
  Φ_*: K⁰(Y₊) → K⁰(Y₋)  
      and show it acts by the Picard–Lefschetz reflection across the class of the exceptional ℙ¹.  
   b) Deduce from this computation how the flop interchanges certain spherical objects in the derived category.  

4) Homological Mirror Symmetry Perspective  
   The conifold is its own “local” Calabi–Yau mirror.  
   a) Describe the expected mirror Landau–Ginzburg model (W: M → ℂ) and identify the vanishing cycles corresponding to the two small resolutions.  
   b) Explain how the derived‐category flop equivalence Φ_𝒦 matches under HMS to monodromy around a conifold point in the complex‐structure moduli of the mirror.  

Even outlining full, rigorous proofs of (2) and (3) requires mastery of Fourier–Mukai transforms, spanning‐class arguments and Picard–Lefschetz theory—and tying it all back to homological­mirror symmetry in (4) demands fluency in both algebraic and symplectic sides of the story.

(The notation DᵇCoh(–) means the bounded derived category of coherent sheaves,  
K⁰(–) denotes (complex) topological K–theory, and all varieties are over ℂ.)

──────────────────────────────────  
1)  The two small, crepant resolutions

1a  Explicit equations.  Introduce the incidence correspondence

  Z := {((x,y,z,w),[u:v]) ∈ X × ℙ¹ | xu = zv, yu = wv }.

Projection to the first factor is birational and crepant; projection to the second makes
Z → ℙ¹ the vector bundle 𝒪_{ℙ¹}(−1) ⊕ 𝒪_{ℙ¹}(−1).  
Choosing the ordered homogeneous coordinates ([u:v]) gives two ways to read the same
incidence variety as a graph:

 Y₊ := Proj ℂ[x,z,u] ⊕ ℂ[y,w,v]   (take ([u:v]) as homogeneous coords),  
 Y₋ := Proj ℂ[x,w,u] ⊕ ℂ[y,z,v].

Equivalently, in affine charts

 U₊ (u ≠ 0):   x = z t, y = w t        (with t = v/u),  
 U₋ (v ≠ 0):    z = x s, w = y s        (with s = u/v).

Putting the two charts together we get

 Y₊ ≅ Tot(𝒪_{ℙ¹}(−1) ⊕ 𝒪_{ℙ¹}(−1)) ⇢ X,  
 Y₋ ≅ Tot(𝒪_{ℙ¹}(−1) ⊕ 𝒪_{ℙ¹}(−1)) ⇢ X,

but the two bundles are glued with opposite rulings; π₊ and π₋ are exchanged by
flopping the ruling.

1b  Picard group.  Because Y_± are total spaces of rank-2 bundles over ℙ¹ with
c₁ = 0, their only effective divisors come from the zero‐section E_± ≅ ℙ¹.
Hence

 Pic(Y_±) ≅ Pic(ℙ¹) ≅ ℤ,

generated by 𝒪_{Y_±}(E_±).  
The exceptional ℙ¹ is exactly that zero section; contracting it in either ruling
recovers the node of X.

──────────────────────────────────  
2)  Bridgeland’s derived equivalence

2a  Fourier–Mukai kernel.  Let

 W := Y₊ ×_X Y₋,  p₊: W→Y₊, p₋: W→Y₋.

W is the common blow‐up of the two resolutions; its exceptional divisor is
E₊ ×_{ℙ¹} E₋ ≅ ℙ¹ × ℙ¹.
Take the kernel

 𝒦 := 𝒪_W ∈ DᵇCoh(Y₊ × Y₋).

The integral transform

 Φ_𝒦(–) := Rp_{–*}(Lp₊^*(–)⊗𝒪_W)  
implements the flop equivalence (Bridgeland).

2b  Exactness.  A spanning class for Y₊ is

 𝒮₊ := {𝒪_{Y₊}, 𝒪_{E₊}(−1)}   (Bondal–Orlov).

Pull them through Φ_𝒦:

 Φ_𝒦(𝒪_{Y₊}) ≅ 𝒪_{Y₋},  
 Φ_𝒦(𝒪_{E₊}(−1)) ≅ 𝒪_{E₋}(−1)[1].

Because {𝒪_{Y₋},𝒪_{E₋}(−1)} is a spanning class of Y₋ and the images generate
Ext’s isomorphically, Φ_𝒦 is fully faithful and essentially surjective; hence an
exact equivalence.

──────────────────────────────────  
3)  Action on K–theory and Picard–Lefschetz reflection

Let e_± := [𝒪_{E_±}(−1)] ∈ K⁰(Y_±) and 1 := [𝒪_{pt}].  One has

 K⁰(Y_±) ≈ ℤ·1 ⊕ ℤ·e_±,   χ(e_±,e_±) = −2, χ(1,e_±) = 0.

3a  Applying the Grothendieck–Riemann–Roch form of Φ_𝒦 we get

 Φ_* : 1 ↦ 1, e₊ ↦ e₋ + ⟨e₋,e₋⟩·1 = e₋ − 2·1.

In the lattice (1,e) this is the matrix

 [ 1  0 ]  
 [−2  1 ],

the Picard–Lefschetz reflection across the root e.

3b  Spherical objects.  𝒪_{E_+}(−1) and its shift are spherical (Ext¹ = ℂ²).
Φ_𝒦 carries them to the corresponding spherical objects on Y₋, so the flop sends
the spherical twist

 T_{𝒪_{E₊}(−1)}   to   T_{𝒪_{E₋}(−1)}.

──────────────────────────────────  
4)  Homological Mirror Symmetry viewpoint

4a  Mirror LG model.  A toric (local) mirror of the conifold is

 M = (ℂ^*)²,   W(x,y) = x + y + 1/x + 1/y.

Critical locus: x = y = ±1 gives the same conifold
monodromy.  The two vanishing 3-spheres L₊, L₋ ⊂ {Re W ≪ 0} are mirror to the
two small resolutions; their intersection number is −2.

4b  Under HMS we have

 DᵇCoh(Y_±) ≅ Fuk^•(M,W),

and Φ_𝒦 corresponds to the symplectic Picard–Lefschetz (Dehn) twist around Lagrangian
vanishing cycles.  Indeed the monodromy T_L acting on Fuk^• is mirrored by the
spherical twist T_{𝒪_{E}(−1)} on DᵇCoh.  Transporting once around the conifold
point swaps the two vanishing cycles, perfectly matching the derived flop
equivalence.

──────────────────────────────────  
Summary.  The conifold flop is realised by the incidence variety kernel
𝒪_{Y₊×_X Y₋}; it acts on K–theory as the Picard–Lefschetz reflection and, under
mirror symmetry, matches the Dehn twist monodromy around the conifold
singularity.

Challenging Frontier-Level Question

Let X be a smooth, projective, geometrically connected variety over ℚ of dimension n ≥ 2 that is of general type and admits a nowhere-vanishing holomorphic n-form (so K_X is big but numerically trivial on some sublocus).  Denote by 𝔽 = D^b Coh(X) its bounded derived category of coherent sheaves, and let Aut(𝔽) be the group of exact ℂ-linear, Fourier–Mukai auto-equivalences of 𝔽.

Consider the subgroup Γ ⊆ Aut(𝔽) generated by

• the Serre functor S = (–) ⊗ K_X [n],  
• a finite collection {T_L₁, …, T_L_m} of spherical twists about mutually orthogonal spherical objects L_i ∈ 𝔽 that lift vanishing cycles arising from a maximal boundary divisor in a minimal model program for X, and  
• the shift functor [1].

Question.  Prove or refute (with rigorous counter-example or conditional argument) the following “Non-abelian Torelli–Fukaya Conjecture” for X:

For every algebraically closed field k of characteristic p ≫ 1, any k-rational point of the stack of Bridgeland stability conditions Stab_k(𝔽_k) that is fixed by Γ_k (the base-change of Γ to k) corresponds, via homological mirror symmetry, to a point in the stringy Kähler moduli space whose p-adic Galois representation ρ_p : Gal(ℚ̄_p / ℚ_p) → π₁(Aut(𝔽)) factors through a finite quotient if and only if X admits a special Lagrangian torus fibration with integral affine base exhibiting a maximally unipotent monodromy point.

Outline precisely which steps of the argument depend on:

(a) the degeneration of the Hochschild–Kostant–Rosenberg spectral sequence at E₂,  
(b) the existence of unobstructed deformations of the spherical objects L_i, and  
(c) the p-adic Hodge-theoretic comparison isomorphisms for log-rigid cohomology of the mirror Landau–Ginzburg model.

Explain why any failure of (a)–(c) would obstruct the equivalence posed in the conjecture.

(This problem sits at the intersection of derived categories, mirror symmetry, p-adic Hodge theory, and birational geometry, and is open in general.  A complete solution would require state-of-the-art techniques; partial progress that precisely isolates the dependence on (a)–(c) will be considered significant.)

Below is an outline of how one would prove (or see the obstruction to) the “Non‐abelian Torelli–Fukaya Conjecture” under hypotheses (a)–(c), and why failure of any one of them kills the argument.  We do not claim a full proof—rather, we isolate exactly where (a), (b), (c) enter.

1.  Sketch of the Conditional Argument  
    We wish to attach to each Γ‐fixed Bridgeland stability condition σ on 𝔽 = D^b Coh(X) (over an algebraic closure k of char p≫1) two parallel “period‐maps”:  
      • a map   σ  ↦  [p–adic Galois representation ρₚ(σ)] into finite‐quotient points of  π₁(Aut 𝔽), and  
      • a map   σ  ↦  [SYZ/LG mirror point y(σ)] in the (rigid) stringy Kähler moduli.  
    Then one must show that “ρₚ(σ) is finite” ⇔ “y(σ) is maximally unipotent,” and furthermore that both period‐maps agree on all Γ‐fixed σ.  The three inputs (a)–(c) come in as follows:

2.  Role of (a) Degeneration of the Hochschild–Kostant–Rosenberg (HKR) spectral sequence  
    •  To build a local period‐map on the space of stability conditions one needs an identification  
         Ext¹_𝔽(𝟙,𝟙)  ≃  HH²(𝔽)  ≃  ⨁_{i+j=2} H^i(X, Λ^j T_X).  
       Here 𝟙 is the identity kernel and the right‐hand side is the sheaf of polyvector fields.  
    •  Degeneration at E₂ of the HKR spectral sequence guarantees the above identification is exact (i.e. no higher differentials).  This makes the tangent to Stab(𝔽) into the familiar “tangent to complex moduli” on the B‐side.  
    •  Without (a), one loses control of the Zariski (or rigid analytic) structure on Stab and cannot even write down the period differential equations whose monodromy one wants to compare to Γ.  In particular one cannot single out the maximally unipotent locus.

3.  Role of (b) Unobstructed deformations of the spherical objects L_i  
    •  The conjecture singles out a finite set of spherical twists T_{L_i}.  To know how these autoequivalences vary in families of stability conditions one must know that each L_i deforms unobstructedly over the local moduli of objects.  Concretely, one uses  
         Ext²(L_i, L_i) = 0  
       to extend L_i over any first‐order deformation of σ.  
    •  This unobstructedness is needed at two points: (i) to show the subgroup Γ acts locally freely on the appropriate branched cover of Stab (so that fixed‐point loci are cut out transversely), and (ii) to identify the associated local system of spherical objects with vanishing‐cycle local systems on the mirror LG model.  
    •  If (b) fails—i.e. if some L_i has Ext²(L_i,L_i)≠0—then the twist T_{L_i} cannot be transported along the period‐map, so the local Γ‐monodromy on Stab cannot be matched to monodromy of the mirror family.  Consequently one cannot characterize “Γ‐fixed” in terms of “unipotent monodromy.”

4.  Role of (c) p‐adic Hodge‐theoretic comparison for the mirror LG model  
    •  On the A‐side (stringy Kähler moduli of X) the maximally unipotent point is detected by having a rank‐one unipotent local monodromy operator N on H^\ast_{rig,log} of the mirror LG family over the p‐adic disc.  
    •  To compare this with the p‐adic Galois representation ρₚ on π₁(Aut 𝔽) arising from the B‐side period–map, one needs a full‐faithful embedding of the rigid cohomology of the LG model into (φ,Γ)–modules.  Equivalently one uses the log‐rigid/de Rham comparison isomorphism  
         H^i_{rig,log}(mirror) ⊗_{K₀} B_{cris}  ≃  H^i_{dR}(mirror) ⊗_K B_{cris}  
       and Fontaine’s theory to identify monodromy N with the nilpotent operator on the filtered φ‐module of ρₚ.  
    •  Absent (c), there is no bridge from the “A‐side unipotent monodromy” to the “B‐side Galois finiteness.”  One loses the fundamental equivalence  
         “maximal unipotence”  ⇔  “ρₚ factors through a finite quotient of π₁(Aut 𝔽).”  

5.  Conclusion and “Obstruction‐if‐Failure” summary  
    •  (a) is needed to set up a well‐behaved period‐map out of Stab(𝔽) and to identify its local monodromy with Action(Γ).  
    •  (b) is needed to lift the generators T_{L_i} through families of stability conditions so that Γ‐fixed σ cuts out exactly the “vanishing‐cycle‐enhanced” locus.  
    •  (c) is needed to translate A‐side unipotent monodromy into B‐side Galois‐finiteness.  
    Thus failure of any one of (a),(b),(c) kills one arrow in the chain  
       Stab(𝔽)  —period→  mirror‐moduli  —p‐adic Hodge→  π₁‐representations,  
    and so the equivalence “finite‐quotient Galois ⟷ maximally unipotent SYZ” collapses.
