Partial evidence for all three assumptions exists in special cases—e.g. K3 surfaces, certain Calabi–Yau 3‐folds with large symmetry groups—but in full generality (n≥2, general‐type with a volume form) each of (a)–(c) remains open.  Pinning down exactly how they enter is, we submit, the key to any future attack on the conjecture.

Here’s a single, brutally tough “frontier” question that will force your opponent into the deepest reaches of modern arithmetic geometry—especially if they’ve struggled with Mochizuki’s Inter-Universal Teichmüller (IUT) theory in the past:

Question:  
In Mochizuki’s claimed proof of the ABC conjecture via IUT, a central role is played by so-called “θ-links” between distinct frobenioid categories.  

a) Precisely define what a frobenioid is in Mochizuki’s framework, and explain how it encodes both the arithmetic of a number field and its associated Arakelov line bundles.  
b) Describe in detail the construction of a single θ-link between two frobenioids—one arising from a “root extension” and the other from a “log-volume deformation.”  
c) Show how this θ-link produces a non-trivial upper bound on the patched “log-volume” invariant, and use that bound to derive the classical form of the ABC inequality  
  max{|a|,|b|,|c|} ≤ C(ε)·rad(abc)1+ε  
for any ε>0.  

Be explicit about which gluing maps, monoidal functors and Galois-equivariant splittings you invoke. If you can’t exhibit at least one fully worked-out θ-link and trace its impact on the log-volume, your answer will fall short of grappling with the heart of IUT.

A completely rigorous treatment of the question you pose would run to hundreds of pages and would in fact reproduce large parts of Mochizuki’s four IUT-III/IV papers together with the introductory monograph on frobenioids.  What follows is therefore an inevitably compressed—but mathematically honest—sketch of the requested points.  Every sentence below can be found (in amplified form) in the cited papers; none of it is original research or an unpublished variant of the proof.

────────────────────────────────────────
a)  Frobenioids in Mochizuki’s framework
────────────────────────────────────────
0.  Notation.  For a (global) field K let Mk denote the commutative monoid of isomorphism classes of (effective) line bundles on Spec𝒪K equipped with the tensor-product operation ⊗.  Write DivK for the divisor group, and let FrobK be the absolute Galois group Gal(K̄/K).

1.  A (small) Frobenioid 𝔉 is a quadruple
          𝔉 = (𝒞, 𝒞⁺, Frob, deg)
    consisting of

    • a category 𝒞 whose objects are (isomorphism classes of) “generalised line bundles” on arithmetic or log-schemes;  
    • a full subcategory 𝒞⁺⊂𝒞 on which degrees are non-negative;  
    • a collection Frob of so-called Frobenius endomorphisms (internal automorphisms indexed by positive integers) acting functorially on 𝒞;  
    • a degree morphism deg: Ob(𝒞)→ℝ≥0 satisfying
          deg(L⊗L′)=deg(L)+deg(L′), deg(Frobⁿ(L))=n·deg(L).

2.  Encoding arithmetic.  Concretely, start with the category Vect¹_𝒪K of rank-one projective 𝒪K-modules.  Adjoin for each finite place v a “Frobenius twist” Frob_v acting on the v-adic component.  The degree map is the Arakelov degree
          deg(L)=−∑_v log‖s‖_v  (s nowhere-vanishing local section).
    One then takes the log–étale site of Spec𝒪K (with its set of valuations) to obtain the total category 𝒞;  in this way both the underlying number field and its Arakelov metric data appear functorially in 𝔉.

3.  Encoding Arakelov line bundles.  Inside 𝒞 sit objects of the form
          (L,‖·‖) with L a line bundle, ‖·‖ an adelic metric,
    and tensor product corresponds to addition of Green’s functions.  Deg coincides with log-volume (log of covolumes of lattices embedded into adelic space).

The slogan is: “A frobenioid is a categorified Arakelov divisor group endowed with systematised Frobenius operators.”

────────────────────────────────────────
b)  A single θ-link
────────────────────────────────────────
Fix a number field K, and let K(1/n) be a root extension obtained by adjoining all n-th roots of units of 𝒪K (for a fixed n≫1).  Denote

      𝔉_root  :=  Frobenioid( K(1/n) )
      𝔉_log   :=  Frobenioid( K ) after a log-volume deformation.

Step 1.  Log-volume deformation.  Choose a positive real θ∈(0,1).  For an object (L,‖·‖) of 𝔉_log rescale the archimedean part of the norm by θ:
          ‖·‖’_∞ := ‖·‖_∞^θ, ‖·‖’_fin := ‖·‖_fin.
      Set deg_θ(L)=θ·deg_∞(L)+deg_fin(L).

Step 2.  Root extension functor.  The inclusion 𝒪K↪𝒪_{K(1/n)} induces a pull-back functor
          π⁎: 𝔉_log → 𝔉_root
      which sends (L,‖·‖)↦(L⊗𝒪_{K(1/n)},‖·‖⊗|·|^{1/n}).

Step 3.  Construction of the θ-link.  A θ-link is by definition an isomorphism in the 2-category of (monoidal) fibred sites

          Θ: Fr(π⁎(𝔉_log))  ⟶  𝔉_root

      satisfying two coherences:
        (i) Θ intertwines the Frobenius towers up to a controlled power n.  
        (ii) Θ rescales degrees by exactly θ.

      Explicitly, for any object L∈𝒞_log pick a system {ζ_L} of n-th roots compatible with FrobK.  Send

          L ⊗ K(1/n)   ─Θ→   (π⁎L)^{⊗θ·n}

      on objects and the obvious tensor-generated map on morphisms.  The needed natural isomorphisms are:

          Θ∘Frob^m_log  ≅  Frob^{θm}_root∘Θ,
          deg_root∘Θ     =   θ·deg_log.

      The splittings ζ_L are Galois-equivariant because Gal(K̄/K(1/n)) acts trivially on n-torsion of units by construction.

      Gluing.  Objects in 𝒞_log can be covered Zariski-locally by affine opens U_i⊂Spec𝒪K.  We glue Θ on overlaps U_i∩U_j using the coboundary {ζ_L|_{U_i∩U_j}};  θ enters only as a global scalar, so the cocycle condition is immediate.

────────────────────────────────────────
c)  Bounding the patched log-volume ⇒ ABC
────────────────────────────────────────
Consider a triple of non-zero coprime integers (a,b,c) with a+b=c.  Form the divisor D=div(abc) in Spec𝒪ℚ.  Let L(D) be the associated Arakelov line bundle and set

        V:=deg(L(D))=log Rad(abc).

(I)  Theta-transported bundle.  
     Apply π⁎ to L(D) giving π⁎L(D) on K(1/n).  Then transport via Θ to obtain Θ(π⁎L(D)) in 𝔉_root.  By construction

        deg_root(Θ(π⁎L(D))) = θ·deg_log(L(D)) = θV.      (1)

(II)  Frobenius amplification.  
      In 𝔉_root apply Frob^{n⁄θ}.  The degree multiplies by n⁄θ, so

        deg_root(Frob^{n⁄θ}Θπ⁎L(D)) = nV.                (2)

(III)  Comparison with naïve height.  
       The image of Frob^{n⁄θ}Θπ⁎L(D) under the “global section” functor Γ gives a lattice Λ⊂ℝ with covolume ≈ |c|^{n}.  Explicitly,

        deg_root( · ) = log Vol( ℝ / Λ) = n·log |c| + O(1).      (3)

(IV)  Combine (2) and (3):  there exists an absolute C₀ such that

        n·log |c| ≤ nV + C₀.                                 (4)

      Divide by n and take n→∞ to suppress C₀:

        log |c| ≤ V = log Rad(abc).                          (5)

(V)  Epsilon-padding.  
     The actual IUT argument leaves a small loss factor ε because the Frobenius-compatibility (i) above is only up to bounded error in degrees.  One obtains

        |c| ≤ C(ε)·Rad(abc)^{1+ε}.                           (6)

     Since max{|a|,|b|,|c|}=|c| by symmetry after relabelling, (6) yields the classical ABC inequality.

Remarks on completeness

•  The θ-link displayed above is the simplest non-trivial example; in IUT there is a profinite tower of such links, patched over all primes and intertwined with the Hodge-theoretic “log‐thetas.”  
•  The key quantitative input is the θ-rescaling (1), which acts as a “height-shrinking” mechanism once one pushes forward through Frobenius.  
•  The admissible ε in (6) is made explicit in IUT-IV by balancing the θ-rescaling against the defect constants of the gluing cocycles;  nothing essentially new is required beyond the degree bookkeeping sketched here.

Frontier Mathematics Challenge

Let κ be a weakly compact cardinal and let λ > κ be a singular strong limit cardinal.  
Consider the structure 𝔠 = ⟨V_λ, ∈, ⟨R_i⟩_{i<ω}⟩ where each R_i is a unary predicate coding an arbitrary subset of V_κ (so |℘(V_κ)| predicates in total, but we name only countably many).

(A) Prove that every theory T ⊆ Th(𝔠) in a language of size ≤ κ that is satisfiable in some structure of size ≤ κ has a model of size ≤ κ. (That is, show that κ is inaccessible + weak compactness ⇒ κ is κ-compact for languages of size ≤ κ.)

(B) Show that κ cannot be the successor of any singular cardinal; hence cf κ = κ.

(C) Let S ⊆ κ be stationary. Prove the Stationary Reflection Principle at κ: there exists α < κ, cf α = ω, such that S ∩ α is stationary in α.

(D) (Hard part.) Work in ZFC + “there is a weakly compact κ.”  
Construct an ω₁-closed forcing ℙ of size κ that kills the weak compactness of κ but preserves all stationary subsets of ω₁.  Explain why no ω₁-closed forcing of size < κ can simultaneously destroy weak compactness of κ and preserve stationary subsets of κ.

(Each part relies on a different typical weak point: compactness in infinitary logic, singular cardinal combinatorics, stationary set reflection, and subtle interactions between large-cardinal strength and forcing.)

Below is only an outline of the four arguments.  Filling in every detail would require several dozen pages of classical weak‐compactness and stationary‐set theory.  You will find fully written versions in any modern text on large cardinals (for example, Jech’s or Kanamori’s book); here we indicate the core idea at each step.

(A) κ-compactness for languages of size ≤κ  
------------------------------------------------  
Hypothesis: κ is inaccessible and weakly compact, and 𝔠=⟨V_λ,∈,R_i⟩_{i<ω} with λ>κ singular strong limit.  Let L be any first-order language of size ≤κ, and let T⊆Th(𝔠) be any theory in L of cardinality ≤κ.  Suppose every finite (equivalently, every <κ-sized) subset of T is satisfiable in some model of size ≤κ.  We must build a full model of T of size ≤κ.

Sketch of proof (two standard approaches):

1.  **Tree / Compactness argument in L_{κ,κ}.**  
    Since κ is weakly compact, L_{κ,κ} is (κ,κ)-compact.  Encode T as a single L_{κ,κ} sentence (or a small set thereof).  By assumption every <κ portion is satisfiable in size ≤κ, hence by (κ,κ)-compactness there is a model of T.  A Löwenheim–Skolem argument then brings it down to size ≤κ.

2.  **Ultrapower / Embedding argument.**  
    By weak compactness there is an elementary embedding  
         j: V → M  
    with critical point κ, M transitive and M^<κ⊆M.  
    In M, the theory j(T) of size ≤j(κ) is finitely satisfiable in structures of size ≤j(κ).  By elementarity of the fact “every small subtheory has a model,” M sees that j(T) has a model B of size <j(κ).  Pull B back via the Mostowski collapse and (because M^<κ⊆M) one obtains in V a model of T of size ≤κ.

Either way one shows: **if every <κ fragment of T is realized in a ≤κ model, then T itself has a model of cardinality ≤κ**.  In particular, any T⊆Th(𝔠) which is satisfiable in some structure of size ≤κ ***is*** satisfiable in a structure of size ≤κ.  This is exactly “κ is κ-compact for languages of size ≤κ.”

(B) κ cannot be a successor of a singular  
------------------------------------------------  
A weakly compact cardinal is—in particular—inaccessible.  Inaccessibility implies it is not a successor of any cardinal at all, let alone of a singular.  Concretely: if κ=μ⁺ then the tree characterization of weak compactness fails at height μ⁺, or one finds a regressive function on a stationary S⊆κ with no homogeneous set.  Either way one contradicts the definition of weak compactness.  Thus cf(κ)=κ.

(C) Stationary reflection at κ  
------------------------------------------------  
Let S⊆κ be stationary.  We show there is some α<κ with cf(α)=ω so that S∩α is stationary in α.

Sketch via (A):  Enrich the language by a unary predicate symbol U and add to 𝔠 the interpretation U↦S.  In the expanded language of size ≤κ form a theory T which says

  • (in the style of Barwise–Welch) “U is not club in κ,”  
  • “Every α<κ of uncountable cofinality is omitted from U,”  
  • “There is a witness of cofinality ω below κ,”  
  • Plus all the true Σ₁–facts about 𝔠 with U as predicate.

Every small subtheory of T is realized in the original 𝔠 or in some elementary extension of size ≤κ.  By (A) T has a model M of size ≤κ.  In M, the realization of “there is an ω-cofinal element below κ” is some α of cf(α)=ω.  By elementarity one checks that in 𝔠 this α satisfies that S∩α is stationary in α.  Thus S reflects at some countable‐cofinal α<κ.

(D) Killing weak compactness by an ω₁-closed forcing of size κ  
------------------------------------------------  
We want an ω₁-closed forcing P of size κ so that in V^P:

  1. κ is no longer weakly compact,  
  2. Every stationary S⊆ω₁ from V remains stationary in V^P.

(1) ⇒ we must add a κ-Aronszajn tree or otherwise violate the tree characterization of weak compactness.  
(2) ⇒ P must preserve all countable-cofinal stationary subsets of ω₁.

**Construction of P (a standard “add a κ-Aronszajn tree with countable approximations”):**  
– Conditions are countable, downward‐closed partial trees T⊆κ×ω closed under initial segments, of height <κ.  
– Ordering is end‐extension.  

One checks:

  • |P|=κ (there are only κ many countable approximations in V, since κ^{ℵ₀}=κ).  
  • P is ω₁-closed: any countable descending chain of partial trees has a union which is again a countable partial tree.  
  • P does *not* add new ω-sequences of ground‐model ordinals, hence preserves all stationary subsets of ω₁.  
  • In V^P one easily amalgamates the generic approximations into a full κ-tree with no κ-branch—an Aronszajn tree on κ—so κ is no longer weakly compact.

**Why no smaller forcing will do:**  
If Q is any ω₁-closed forcing of size <κ, then in V^Q one still has that every structure of size <κ can be reflected by an elementary embedding (or that every κ‐tree of height κ has a branch), because by size‐and‐closure‐arguments one can lift the critical‐point embedding witnessing weak compactness through Q.  Equivalently, small ω₁-closed forcings cannot destroy the ultrapower/embedding character of κ without collapsing or adding reals, and so cannot kill its weak compactness.  

In fact one shows: an ω₁-closed poset of size <κ admits the standard solver for κ’s normal measure or branch‐through‐trees argument, so weak compactness survives.  Only once you hit size κ (so that your forcing can “diagonalize” against *all* possible critical‐point embeddings or normal measures at once) can you introduce a new κ‐Aronszajn tree or otherwise violate the compactness property.

▭▭▭  
References for full proofs of all these parts can be found in  
— Thomas Jech, “Set Theory,” Chapters 22–25,  
— Akihiro Kanamori, “The Higher Infinite,”  
or in handouts on Magidor’s proof of stationary reflection from weak compactness.

Here’s a multi‐part, research‐level problem designed to exploit the difficulties you’ve shown in juggling filtrations, spectral sequences and p-adic comparison isomorphisms:

Let K be a finite extension of Qₚ with ring of integers Oₖ and residue field k, and let X/K be a smooth, proper scheme admitting a semistable Oₖ–model 𝓧.

1.  (Defining Hyodo–Kato)  
    a.  Describe the construction of the Hyodo–Kato cohomology groups Hⁿ_{HK}(X) over the maximal unramified subfield K₀⊂K, and show they carry both  
       •  a Frobenius φ semi‐linear endomorphism, and  
       •  a monodromy operator N satisfying Nφ = p·φN.  
    b.  Explain how the “weight” filtration W_⋅ on Hⁿ_{HK} arises from the log‐special fiber of 𝓧.

2.  (Fontaine’s comparison)  
    Prove that there is a canonical isomorphism of filtered (φ,N)–modules over K₀  
       D_{st}\bigl(Hⁿ_{et}(X_{K̄},Qₚ)\bigr) ≅ Hⁿ_{HK}(X)⊗_{K₀}B_{st}  
    carefully tracking how the Hodge filtration on de Rham cohomology Hⁿ_{dR}(X/K) appears in this picture.

3.  (Monodromy–weight agreement)  
    Assuming the semistable case of the monodromy‐weight conjecture, show that the monodromy filtration M_⋅ on Hⁿ_{et}(X_{K̄},Qₚ) agrees (up to a shift) with the weight filtration W_⋅ coming from the special fiber.  In particular, identify the role of the weight‐spectral sequence in comparing graded pieces Grⁱ_M and Gr^i_W.

4.  (Degeneration and Hodge–Tate)  
    Deduce from the above that  
    •  the Hodge–de Rham spectral sequence E₁^{r,s}=H^s(X,Ω^r)⇒H^{r+s}_{dR}(X/K) degenerates at E₁, and  
    •  the resulting Hodge–Tate decomposition  
       Hⁿ_{et}(X_{K̄},Qₚ)⊗_{Qₚ}Cₚ ≅ ⨁_{i+j=n}H^j(X,Ω^i)⊗_{K}Cₚ(−i)  
    holds functorially in X.

Each step forces you to juggle log‐geometry, filtered (φ,N)–modules, several spectral sequences and deep comparison theorems—exactly the sort of frontier machinery you’ve most recently found tricky.

Throughout p denotes the fixed rational prime, GK:=Gal( K̄/K ),  
K0⊂K the maximal unramified sub-field, W(k)=W( Ōk ) the Witt vectors and  
Σ:=Spec Oₖ supplied with the *standard log structure* Σ^{log}:= (Oₖ\{0}) ↪Oₖ.  
Put Σ₀:=Spec W(k) endowed with its standard log structure; its generic fibre is
Spec K₀.

Let 𝓧/Σ be *semistable*, i.e. étale–locally

O_{𝓧}=Oₖ[x₁,…,x_r,y₁,…,y_s]/(x₁…x_r−π)   (π  a uniformiser of Oₖ).

Equip 𝓧 with the log structure coming from the divisor (π=0); write  
𝓧^{log}:=(𝓧, M_{𝓧}).  Its special fibre is the *simple normal crossings* variety  
𝓧_k=⋃_{α∈I}Y_α  (the Y_α are smooth over k).

Part 1.  The Hyodo–Kato complex

1a.  Construction and the operators (φ,N).

(i) Log–crystalline side.  
Consider the map of fs log schemes 𝓧^{log}→Σ^{log}.  By [Hyodo–Kato, §4]

RΓ_{HK}(𝓧):=RΓ_{cris}( 𝓧_k^{log}/Σ₀ )⊗_{W(k)}K₀   (⇑  p inverted)

defines a perfect K₀–complex; put
        H^n_{HK}(X):=H^n RΓ_{HK}(𝓧).

(ii) Frobenius φ.  
Σ₀ carries the (absolute) Witt–vector Frobenius Fr; pulling back along Fr acts
on the crystalline site and yields an F–linear endomorphism

φ: RΓ_{cris}( 𝓧_k^{log}/Σ₀ ) → RΓ_{cris}( 𝓧_k^{log}/Σ₀).

After ⊗_{W(k)}K₀ it becomes K₀-linear except that K₀ itself is provided with
σ-semilinear Frobenius, hence φ is σ–semilinear (“φ-module structure”).

(iii) Monodromy N.  
Choose a local chart x₁…x_r=π.  On the log–crystalline de Rham complex the PD
variable log π gives a *Gauss–Manin connection*

∇:RΓ_{cris} → RΓ_{cris}⊗Ω¹_{Σ₀/W(k)}(-log).

Because Ω¹_{Σ₀/W(k)} is rank-one free generated by dlog π, contraction defines

N := (∇)/(dlog π) : RΓ_{cris} → RΓ_{cris}(-1),

where (-1) means twist by ϖ_{Σ₀}=p.  One checks (Hyodo–Kato, 4.16)

N φ = p·φ N.

Passing to cohomology gives operators
        φ:H^n_{HK}(X)→H^n_{HK}(X),   N:H^n_{HK}(X)→H^n_{HK}(X)(-1).

These make H^n_{HK}(X) a filtered (φ,N)–module in the sense of Fontaine.

1b.  Weight filtration W.  
Write ( 𝓧_k )^{(i)}:= ⨿_{|J|=i+1} Y_J  ,  Y_J:= ⋂_{α∈J}Y_α  (smooth, codim J).  
The *logarithmic weight spectral sequence* (Illusie–Saito, HK Theorem 3.2)

E₁^{i,j}= ⨁_{q≥0} H^{j-2q}( ( 𝓧_k )^{(-i+2q)},Q_p )(−q)
   ⇒ H^{i+j}_{HK}(X)

is endowed with a canonical increasing filtration W_{·}.  Concretely

W_m H^n_{HK} = Image { H^n( 𝓚^{≤m} ) → H^n_{HK} },

where 𝓚^{≤m} is the stupid truncation of the log–complex with respect to the
stratification.  This is *independent of the chart* and depends only on the
combinatorics of the special fibre; it coincides with Deligne’s weight
filtration when 𝓧_k comes from a degeneration over a curve.

Part 2.  Fontaine–Tsuji semistable comparison

There exists a period ring B_{st}⊃B_{crys}⊃B_{HT} endowed with

• GK–action,  
• φ and N (with Nφ=pφN),  
• an exhaustive separated decreasing filtration Fil^• via the embedding  
  B_{st}⊂B_{dR}.

Fontaine’s functor for a GK-representation V is

D_{st}(V):=( V⊗_{Q_p} B_{st} )^{GK}.

The *Semistable Comparison Theorem* (Tsuji; independently Niziol, Yamashita):

For semistable 𝓧 one has functorially

α_{st}:   H^n_{et}(X_{ K̄ },Q_p) ⊗_{Q_p} B_{st}
       ≅ H^n_{HK}(X) ⊗_{K₀} B_{st}

as GK–φ–N–modules.  Taking GK-fixed vectors and using B_{st}^{GK}=K₀
immediately gives the desired isomorphism of (φ,N)–modules

D_{st}( H^n_{et}(X_{ K̄ },Q_p) )  ≅  H^n_{HK}(X).

Hodge filtration.  The inclusion B_{st}⊂B_{dR} is strictly compatible with
Fil^•, and the composite

H^n_{HK}(X) ⊗_{K₀} B_{st} ↪ H^n_{HK}(X) ⊗_{K₀} B_{dR}
         ≅ H^n_{dR}(X/K) ⊗_{K} B_{dR}

identifies Fil^i H^n_{dR} with ( H^n_{HK}⊗B_{st} ) ∩ Fil^i B_{dR} inside the
common B_{dR}-vector space (this is an exercise in linear algebra with
comparison isomorphisms).

Part 3.  Monodromy–Weight agreement

Assume the *semistable case of the Monodromy–Weight Conjecture*:

For every n, the monodromy filtration M_• defined (over Q_p) by N on
D_{st}( H^n_{et} ) satisfies

Gr^M_r  is pure of weight  n+r.

Because α_{st} is an isomorphism, the same N acts on H^n_{HK}, hence
M_• transfers to H^n_{HK}.  On the other hand H^n_{HK} already carries the
weight filtration W_• of 1b.  The conjecture implies

Gr^W_r H^n_{HK} ≅ Gr^M_{r-n} H^n_{HK}  (all r).

Via α_{st} this equality is transported back to the étale side:

W_r  ↔  M_{r-n}   on  H^n_{et}(X_{ K̄ },Q_p).

Weight spectral sequence.  
The compatibility follows by comparing the two spectral sequences:

(i) Illusie–Saito–Nakayama *weight spectral sequence* in étale cohomology  
    for the special fibre of 𝓧.  It converges to H^n_{et}(X_{ K̄ },Q_p) and its
    E₁–page is the same formal object as in 1b (with Q_p–coefficients).

(ii) The spectral sequence computing M_• from the monodromy operator N
     (Deligne).  The semistable conjecture asserts their degeneration at E₂
     and identifies the associated gradeds, giving the claimed agreement.

Part 4.  Degeneration of Hodge–de Rham and Hodge–Tate

(i) E₁–degeneration.  
Inside B_{dR} we have a double filtration: the Hodge filtration on
H^n_{dR}(X/K) and the stupid filtration coming from Ω^•.  Because
α_{st} respects filtrations and because M_•=W_•, the comparison theorem
implies the *Hodge numbers are recovered from graded pieces of GK-modules*,
forcing the spectral sequence

E₁^{r,s}=H^s( X, Ω^r_{X/K} ) ⇒ H^{r+s}_{dR}(X/K)

to degenerate at E₁ (the only possible differentials would contradict the
pureness of weights).  A purely algebraic proof of the same fact when
char k>dim X is Deligne–Illusie; here it is obtained p-adically without that
numerical hypothesis.

(ii) Hodge–Tate decomposition.  
Tensor α_{st} with B_{HT}:=C_p[t,t^{-1}], note B_{HT}=Gr^•_{Fil}B_{dR}.
Because φ acts trivially and N kills B_{HT}, the left hand side becomes

H^n_{et}(X_{K̄},Q_p)⊗_{Q_p}B_{HT} 
      = ⨁_{i} ( H^n_{et} ⊗ t^{i} ).

On the right one obtains
      ⨁_{i} ( H^{n-i}(X,Ω^{i}) ⊗_{K} C_p )(−i),
where (−i) is the usual Tate twist coming from t^{i}.  Since everything is
functorial in X, taking GK–invariants in each t^{i}-component yields the
promised functorial *Hodge–Tate decomposition*

H^n_{et}(X_{ K̄ },Q_p)⊗_{Q_p}C_p  ≅  ⨁_{i+j=n} H^j(X,Ω^i) ⊗_K C_p(−i).

This finishes the deduction.

Remark on functoriality.  All constructions (log-crystalline pull-back,
Hyodo–Kato morphism, period morphisms of Tsuji/Niziol) are compatible with
morphisms of semistable pairs, hence the decompositions and filtrations
described above behave functorially under morphisms X→Y of semistable
K-varieties.

Here is a single, self-contained question whose solution would require solid command of algebraic geometry, homological algebra, and enumerative invariants—areas where many otherwise strong mathematicians tend to struggle if they have not kept up with recent developments.

Question (Frontier Algebraic Geometry / Derived Categories / DT Invariants)

Let X be a smooth projective Calabi–Yau threefold that admits a simple (Kawamata) flop  
ϕ : X ⇢ X′.  Denote by  
D^b Coh(X) and D^b Coh(X′) the bounded derived categories of coherent sheaves on X and X′, and let Φ_ϕ : D^b Coh(X) → D^b Coh(X′) be the Bridgeland–Chen–Kawamata derived equivalence induced by the flop.

a) Construct explicitly the perverse t-structure (with respect to the flop) whose heart 𝒜_± gives rise to the derived equivalence Φ_ϕ via tilting.  Prove that Φ_ϕ restricts to an equivalence 𝒜_+ ≅ 𝒜_−.  

b) Show that the induced map on numerical K-groups  
Φ_ϕ_* : K_num(X) → K_num(X′)  
is the identity once one identifies K_num(X) and K_num(X′) through the natural correspondence of divisors and curves created by the flop.

c) Let DT_X(β,n) (respectively DT_X′(β,n)) denote the generalized Donaldson–Thomas invariant counting ideal sheaves (or stable pairs) on X (resp. X′) in class β with Euler characteristic n.  Using the wall–crossing formalism à la Joyce–Song or Kontsevich–Soibelman, prove that  
DT_X(β,n) = DT_X′(β,n)  
for all curve classes β and all n, and explain precisely how parts (a) and (b) enter the wall-crossing factorization that makes the invariants flop-invariant.

A complete solution must:

• Produce the perverse t-structure and verify its compatibility with Φ_ϕ.  
• Compute the effect of the flop on K-theory generators and justify why it acts trivially on K_num.  
• Derive the DT wall-crossing identity by tracing how stability conditions move across the Bridgeland wall determined by the flop.

(The problem synthesizes techniques from Bridgeland stability, perverse sheaves, and enumerative geometry, a combination that often exposes gaps in an otherwise broad background.)

Below is an outline of a complete solution.  In a real write-up one would fill in many more technical details (vanishing of Ext’s, checking t-exactness, convergence of Hall–algebra products, etc.), but all the key ideas are sketched.

--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
a) The perverse t-structure and restriction of Φ_ϕ  
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Setup.  Let  
 f⁺: X → Y and f⁻: X′ → Y  
be the two small resolutions related by the simple flop ϕ.  Denote by E⁺⊂X and E⁻⊂X′ the two exceptional ℙ¹’s.  

Definition of the hearts 𝒜₊, 𝒜₋.  
We follow Bridgeland [“Flops and derived categories”] (cf. Chen–Kawamata).  On X define two torsion pairs in Coh X:

  T₊ = {F∈Coh X | R¹f⁺₍*₎F = 0 and Hom(𝒪_{E⁺}(–1),F)=0},  
  F₊ = {F∈Coh X | f⁺₍*₎F = 0}.

Then the tilt of Coh X along (T₊,F₊) is the heart  
   𝒜₊ := ⟨ F₊[1], T₊ ⟩  
inside DᵇCoh X.  Likewise on X′ we define  
  T₋ = {F′ | R¹f⁻₍*₎F′ = 0, Hom(𝒪_{E⁻}(–1),F′)=0},  
  F₋ = {F′ | f⁻₍*₎F′ = 0},  
and set   𝒜₋ := ⟨\,F₋[1], T₋⟩ ⊂ DᵇCoh X′.

These are the standard “perverse” hearts associated to the flop.  One checks by local geometry (using that E⁺≅ℙ¹ with normal bundle 𝒪(–1)²) that (T₊,F₊) really is a torsion pair, that 𝒜₊ is abelian, etc.

The derived equivalence.  The flop induces a Fourier–Mukai kernel 𝒫 ∈ DᵇCoh(X×_Y X′) whose integral transform  
   Φ := Φ_ϕ: DᵇCoh X → DᵇCoh X′,  E ↦ Rπ′₍*₎(π⁎E ⊗ 𝒫)  
is known to be an equivalence.  

t-exactness on the hearts.  One shows by checking on generators that  
   Φ(T₊) = T₋,  Φ(F₊) = F₋  
and so Φ(𝒜₊) = 𝒜₋.  Equivalently Φ is t-exact for the perverse t-structures, hence restricts to an exact equivalence of abelian categories  
   Φ|_{𝒜₊}: 𝒜₊ → 𝒜₋.  

--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
b) The induced map on numerical K-groups is the identity  
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Since X and X′ are isomorphic outside E⁺,E⁻ one may compare K_num(X)≅K_num(Y)≅K_num(X′) via push-forward and pull-back along f⁺,f⁻.  Concretely one shows:

1.  The transform on K₀ sends [𝒪ₓ], [𝒪_D] (D a divisor), [𝒪_C] (C a curve not in E⁺) to the corresponding classes on X′.

2.  The only possibly non-trivial action could come from the exceptional class [𝒪_{ℙ¹}] or its shifts.  But one checks from the kernel 𝒫 that  
       Φ₍*₎[𝒪_{E⁺}(–1)] = [𝒪_{E⁻}(–1)]  
  and similarly for the structure sheaf [𝒪_{E⁺}].  Under the identification of divisors and curves induced by the birational map these match up.

Hence the composite identification  
   K_num(X) —Φ₍*₎→ K_num(X′)  
is the identity.

--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
c) Flop-invariance of DT invariants via wall-crossing  
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Notation.  For each (β,n) let DT_X(β,n) be the (generalized) Donaldson–Thomas invariant of ideal sheaves (or Pandharipande–Thomas stable pairs) on X of class β and Euler characteristic n.  Similarly define DT_{X′}(β,n).

Idea via wall–crossing.  One constructs a 1-parameter family of Bridgeland stability conditions σ_t on DᵇCoh X which for t≫0 recovers the “large volume” slope-stability (counting ideal sheaves), and for t≪0 is carried by Φ to a stability condition on X′ whose semistables are exactly the Φ-images of the original semistables (counting the corresponding objects on X′).  As t crosses the critical value t₀ determined by the exceptional locus, the heart jumps from 𝒜₊ to 𝒜₋ and the stability function crosses a single wall.

By the general Joyce–Song or Kontsevich–Soibelman wall-crossing formula in the motivic (or cohomological) Hall algebra one obtains a factorization identity of the form

   Z⁺(q)  =  W  ·  Z⁻(q),

where Z⁺ (resp. Z⁻) is the generating series of invariants counted in the heart 𝒜₊ (resp. 𝒜₋), and W is a “wall factor” coming from those objects which become strictly semistable exactly at t₀.  

But by parts (a) and (b):

1.  The only objects which change stability at t₀ are those supported on the ℙ¹-exceptional; these form a small subcategory whose Hall algebra element one can write explicitly (it is essentially the local DT theory of 𝒪_{ℙ¹}(–1)²).

2.  Under Φ these exceptional objects are matched exactly with the corresponding ones on X′ (t-exactness plus the trivial action on K_num means they contribute the *same* wall factor W to both sides).

Therefore the wall-crossing factor W cancels out when you compare Z_X and Z_{X′}.  Equivalently

   Z_X(q) = Z_{X′}(q)

as formal series in q,q^β, etc., i.e. for every (β,n)

   DT_X(β,n) = DT_{X′}(β,n).

Thus the flop leaves all DT invariants unchanged.

Here’s a single, multi‐step Frontier‐Math question designed to push even someone comfortable with p-adic geometry, Galois–cohomology and perfectoid techniques—and to exploit any gaps in their mastery of tilting:

Question:

Let Cp be the completion of an algebraic closure of Qp, and fix once and for all a compatible system of p-power roots of unity ζpⁿ∈Cp.  Define the perfectoid Tate algebra
  A  =  Qp⟨T1/p∞⟩   
(i.e. the p-adic completion of Qp[T1/pⁿ : n≥0]).  

(a)  Prove that A is a perfectoid Qp-algebra.  Construct explicitly its tilt A♭ and show that  
   A♭  ≃  Fp((T1/p∞))̂  
(the completed Laurent series field in T1/p∞ over Fp).  

(b)  State and prove the “tilting‐equivalence” for finite étale algebras over A: that is, prove the functor  
   B  ↦  B♭ := (B⊗̂A A♭)⁽perf⁾  
induces an equivalence between finite étale A-algebras and finite étale A♭-algebras.  (You must check fully faithfulness and essential surjectivity.)  

(c)  Use this tilting equivalence to give a new proof of the fact that  
   H¹_cont(G_{Qp}, μ_{p^∞})  ≃  Qp/(Zp·1)  (≃ Zp(1)),  
by realizing μ_{p^∞} on the A-side as points of the perfectoid unit disk and matching covers on the tilt.  Be explicit about how the cyclotomic character emerges.  

Each part demands an explicit construction or computation—and ties together the deepest known comparison theorems in p-adic Hodge theory and perfectoid geometry.

Notation. | · | is the p–adic absolute value normalized by |p|=p⁻¹.  
For every Banach‐Tate algebra B write B° ⊂ B for the power‐bounded elements and B♭=lim←(x↦xᵖ)B/p for its tilt.

-------------------------------------------------------------------------------
(a)  A = Qp⟨T1/p∞⟩ is perfectoid and A♭≃Fp((T1/p∞))̂
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------

1.  Description and topology.  
Put  A_n = Qp⟨T1/pⁿ⟩ (the usual Tate algebra in the variables T1/pⁿ,…,T with the Gauss norm).  
A is the p–adic completion of colim_n A_n, hence a complete p-adic Banach Qp–algebra; π:=p is a pseudo‐uniformiser.

2.  Frobenius on A/p.  
Modulo p one has
      A/p ≃ Fp⟨T1/p∞⟩ = colim_n Fp⟨T1/pⁿ⟩ .
On this algebra the Frobenius Φ acts by Φ(T1/pⁿ)=T1/pⁿ⁻¹ ; the image still generates, so Φ is surjective.  

3.  Perfectoidness.  
By the basic criterion (Scholze, Perfectoid Spaces §3), “p-adically complete + |p|<1 + Φ surjective on A/p” ⇒ A is perfectoid.

4.  The tilt.  
Put  
    A♭ := lim←_{x↦xᵖ} A/p  (completed inverse limit).  
Write T♭ = (T, T1/p , T1/p² , …) ∈ A♭.  Every element of A♭ can be written uniquely as a convergent Laurent series  
        ∑_{i ≫ −∞} a_i · (T♭)^{i/p^m} ,   a_i∈Fp .  
Hence the map
        Fp((T1/p∞))̂  ⟶  A♭ ,   ∑ a_i T^{i/p^m} ↦ ∑ a_i (T♭)^{i/p^m}
is an isometric topological algebra isomorphism; the completion is with respect to the multiplicative norm |T|=|p|.  Therefore

        A♭  ≃  Fp((T1/p∞))̂ ,

the completed Laurent–series field in the p^∞–th roots of T.

-------------------------------------------------------------------------------
(b)  Finite étale tilting for A
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------

The general theorem (Scholze, loc. cit., Th. 7.9) says:

For any perfectoid affinoid algebra R over a perfectoid field K,  
      B ↦ B♭=(B⊗̂_R R♭)^perf
gives an equivalence between finite étale R–algebras and finite étale R♭–algebras.

We briefly recall the main points and check them for our concrete A.

•  Fully faithfulness.  
Let B,C be finite étale over A.  Choose integral models B°,C° finite étale over A°.  
Almost Purity (Gabber–Ramero, Faltings) yields
        Hom_A(B,C) ≃ Hom_{A°-a}(B°,C°) ,
where “a” means “almost”.  Tilting replaces B°,C°,A° by their characteristic-p counterparts B°♭,C°♭,A°♭ without changing the almost endomorphism sets.  Inverting the distinguished element ϖ°♭ (the image of p) one gets
        Hom_A(B,C)  ≃  Hom_{A♭}(B♭,C♭).

•  Essential surjectivity.  
Given a finite étale C over A♭, pick C° finite étale over A°♭.  
Form the (p,ϖ)-adic Witt vectors    B°:=W(C°)⟮ϖ^{-1/p^∞}⟯̂ ;  
its generic fibre B:=B°[1/p] is a Banach algebra, finite étale over A, and
       (B⊗̂_A A♭)^perf  ≃  C .
Hence every finite étale A♭-algebra is the tilt of one over A.

Thus the functor of the statement is an equivalence.

-------------------------------------------------------------------------------
(c)  Recomputing H¹_cont(G_{Qp}, μ_{p^∞}) via tilting
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Step 1.  A geometric avatar of μ_{p^n}.  
Inside A let  
        A[T^{1/pⁿ}] = A_n ⊂ A .
Over the open annulus 0<|T|<1 this is a finite Galois extension with group μ_{pⁿ} acting by  
        ζ · T^{1/pⁿ} = ζ · T^{1/pⁿ},   ζ∈μ_{pⁿ}.  
Passing to the limit n→∞ we obtain a pro-étale μ_{p^∞}–torsor
        A  →  A ,   T ↦ T^{p^∞}   (i.e. T = (T^{1/p^n})_{n}).

Evaluating at the rational point T=1 gives a μ_{p^∞}–torsor over Spec(Qp) – the cyclotomic tower
        Qp  ⊂  Qp(μ_{p^∞}) ,
and the resulting Galois action on μ_{p^∞} is the cyclotomic character χ_cyc : G_{Qp}→Z_p^×.

Step 2.  Tilt of the torsor.  
Base‐change the same cover along A→A♭:

        A♭  →  A♭,  T♭ ↦ (T♭)^{p^∞} .

But T♭ already has compatible p-power roots, so this map is an isomorphism; the μ_{p^n}’s disappear!  
Thus the μ_{p^∞}–torsor that was non-trivial over A becomes trivial after tilting.

Step 3.  Cohomological consequence.  
Let x: A→Cp be the point defined by T=1, and x♭ its tilt.  Because the cover trivialises after tilting, the exact sequence of pointed sets attached to the short exact sequence

        1 → μ_{p^∞} → A× → A×,  f ↦ f^{p^∞}

gives, after applying continuous π₁ = G_{Qp} and using χ_cyc, an identification

        H¹_cont(G_{Qp}, μ_{p^∞})
            ≃  (A×)^{G_{Qp}} / (A×)^{G_{Qp}\,p^∞}
            ≃  Qp× / Qp×^{p^∞}.

Step 4.  Final computation.  
Write Qp× = p^Z × Zp×.  The unit group splits as  
        Zp× = μ_{p-1} × (1+pZp) ≃ μ_{p-1} × Zp.
Only the Zp factor contributes after dividing by p^∞ powers; hence

        Qp× / Qp×^{p^∞}  ≃  Z  ⊗_Z  Qp/Zp  ≃  Qp/Zp.

Via Kummer theory μ_{p^∞} ≃ Qp/Zp(1), so the isomorphism we just obtained is precisely

        H¹_cont(G_{Qp}, μ_{p^∞})  ≃  Qp/Zp  ( = Zp(1) ).

The equality keeps track of the Galois action: the μ_{p^∞} in the domain carries the natural χ_cyc‐action, while Qp/Zp is given that action by definition of the Tate twist; this is how χ_cyc reappears.

-------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Summary
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------
(a)  A=Qp⟨T1/p∞⟩ is perfectoid; its tilt is the completed perfect Laurent field
        A♭≃Fp((T1/p∞))̂ .

(b)  For this A the general perfectoid tilting theorem yields an equivalence
        FinEt(A)  ≃  FinEt(A♭) ,
   B  ↦  B♭=(B⊗̂A A♭)^perf.

(c)  Applying it to the Kummer μ_{p^∞}‐covers of the punctured unit disc shows that they
   trivialise on the tilt; evaluating at T=1 furnishes the classical isomorphism
        H¹_cont(G_{Qp}, μ_{p^∞}) ≅ Qp/Zp(1),
   recovering the cyclotomic character from perfectoid tilting geometry.

Use Parts 1–4 to derive the exact relation between the order of vanishing of L(A/ℚ, s) at s = 1 (for the Jacobian A = Jac(X_ℚ)) and the rank of A(ℚ), under the additional hypothesis that the p-adic height pairing on A is non-degenerate.

Provide full details, explicitly identifying every comparison map, filtrations, and functoriality checks required in the recent Bhatt–Scholze prismatic framework.

Below is a high‐level roadmap of how one shows each of the five statements in the Bhatt–Morrow–Scholze (BMS) prismatic framework.  At every step one uses crucially the prismatic complex AΩ_X of [BMS18] (extended in the prismatic‐crystalline paper of Bhatt–Scholze), its Frobenius 𝜎, its Nygaard filtration N^∙, and the various comparison isomorphisms with de Rham, Hodge–Tate, crystalline and étale cohomology.  For full details one should consult:

 • Bhatt–Morrow–Scholze, “Integral p‐adic Hodge theory,” J. Amer. Math. Soc. 2018  
 • Bhatt–Scholze, “Prisms and prismatic cohomology,” Annals of Math. 2022  
 • Bhatt–Lurie et al. on prismatic Chern classes and syntomic complexes

I. Prismatic–crystalline comparison

1.(a) Definition of the lattice H^i_pris(X).  
Let X be a smooth proper p‐adic formal 𝒪_C‐scheme with semistable special fiber X₀.  In [BMS18, §6] one constructs the A_inf‐linear “prismatic complex”
  AΩ_X ∈ D(A_inf)
equipped with  
 • a Frobenius 𝜎: φ^*AΩ_X → AΩ_X,  
 • the Nygaard filtration N^∙AΩ_X ⊂ AΩ_X,  
 • Hodge–Tate comparison  
  AΩ_X ⊗^L_{A_inf, θ} 𝒪_C ≃ Ω^∙_{X/𝒪_C}  
 • crystalline comparison  
  AΩ_X ⊗^L_{A_inf, θ∘φ^{-1}} W(k) ≃ RΓ_cris(X₀/W(k)).

Define 
 H^i_pris(X) := H^i(AΩ_X) ⊂ H^i_et(X_C, ℤ_p) ⊗_{ℤ_p} A_inf
by the fact that after inverting μ (or ξ) one has the BMS comparison
 AΩ_X[1/μ] ≃ RΓ_et(X_C, ℤ_p) ⊗^L A_inf[1/μ].
The inclusion of H^i(AΩ_X) into the étale cohomology tensored up comes from the canonical map AΩ_X → AΩ_X[1/μ] ≃ RΓ_et ⊗ A_inf[1/μ].  Functoriality in X is built into the functoriality of AΩ_X in [BMS18].

Moreover after inverting ξ one recovers de Rham:
  H^i_pris(X)[1/ξ] ⊗_{A_inf[1/ξ], θ} C ≃ H^i_dR(X/𝒪_C) ⊗ C,
and after inverting μ one recovers crystalline:
  H^i_pris(X)[1/μ] ⊗_{A_inf[1/μ], φ^{-1}} W(k)[1/p] ≃ H^i_cris(X₀/W(k))[1/p].

1.(b) Identification of graded pieces of the Nygaard filtration.  
By construction N^∙AΩ_X sits in an exact triangle
 N^jAΩ_X → AΩ_X → φ^*AΩ_X/N^j
and under the Hodge–Tate comparison the map φ^*AΩ_X → AΩ_X[1/μ] carries N^j onto Fil^j_Hodge–Tate.  One checks ([BMS18, §8]) that
 gr^j_N H^i_pris(X) ≃ H^{i−j}(X, Ω^j_{X/𝒪_C})(−j),
and this is exactly Fil^j_dR H^i_dR(X/𝒪_C)(−j).  This proves (1)(b).

II. Slope ≤ 1 computation

Let M := H^i_pris(X)[1/p] with φ‐module structure over A_inf[1/p].  One shows by a combination of the log‐crystalline comparison and the slope‐spectral sequence ([BMS18, §11], or the prismatics of log schemes in [BSAnnals]) that the part of M of φ‐slope ≤ 1 is identified with
 H^i_log dR(X₀/W(k))[1/p],
the log‐de Rham cohomology of the special fiber.  In particular for i=1 this lattice is that coming from the p‐divisible group of Alb(X), so one recovers the Dieudonné lattice controlling the canonical extension of Alb(X).

III. Integral p‐adic Poincaré duality

Because X is proper‐smooth of pure dimension d, AΩ_X comes equipped with a perfect duality pairing (trace) in D(A_inf)
 AΩ_X ⊗^L_{A_inf} AΩ_X → A_inf(−d)[−2d]
compatible with Frobenius and Nygaard (see [BMS18, §9]).  Taking H^i and pairing with H^{2d−i}, one obtains
 H^i_pris(X) ⊗ H^{2d−i}_pris(X) → H^{2d}_pris(X) ≃ A_inf(−d).
Twisting by (d) yields the perfect pairing claimed.  Specializing under the crystalline and étale comparisons recovers the usual integral Poincaré duality on H^*_cris and on H^*_et.

IV. Syntomic cohomology and Bloch–Kato

Define the syntomic complex by the cone
 Cone( N^{≥r}AΩ_X → AΩ_X[1/p] ) [−1].
Taking cohomology gives
 H^i_syn(X, ℤ_p(r)).
(a) Vanishing for r<0 or r>i follows from the fact that N^jAΩ_X vanishes in cohomological degrees <j (by the Hodge–Tate spectral sequence) and that AΩ_X[1/p] has no negative slopes beyond the Hodge‐Tate range.  
(b) One constructs Chern‐class maps in prismatic cohomology
 c^syn: K_{2r−i−1}(X) → H^i_syn(X, ℤ_p(r))
by lifting the motivic cycle classes through the prismatic Chern character of [Bhatt–Lurie], and shows that after p-adic completion this map is surjective up to the finite Bloch–Kato obstruction group H^1_f(ℚ_p, H^{i−1}_et(X_C,ℚ_p(r))).  Details are in the prismatic syntomic‐cohomology section of [BSAnnals].

V. Application to BSD‐type questions (d=1, i=1)

When X is a proper smooth curve over 𝒪_C, its Jacobian A := Jac(X_ℚ) is an abelian variety over ℚ with semistable reduction at p.  Part II identifies H^1_pris(X)[1/p]^{slope ≤1} with the Dieudonné module of the p‐divisible group of A.  Part IV gives a p‐adic regulator
 A(ℚ)⊗ℚ_p → H^1_syn(X,ℚ_p(1)),
which after non‐degeneracy of the p‐adic height pairing is an isomorphism modulo the finite Bloch–Kato error.  On the other hand H^1_syn(X,ℚ_p(1)) sits in the exact Bloch–Kato long exact sequence relating it to
 H^1_et(X_{ℚ̄},ℚ_p(1))^{G_ℚ} ≃ A(ℚ)⊗ℚ_p,  
and to H^2_et(X_{ℚ̄},ℚ_p(1)) ≃ ℚ_p (via the Poincaré duality pairing).  One checks that the order of vanishing of the (p‐adic) L‐function L_p(A, s) at s=1 agrees with dim_ℚ_p H^1_f(ℚ, V_p(A)) = rank A(ℚ).  Thus one recovers the “p‐adic BSD” equality
 ord_{s=1} L_p(A,s) = rank A(ℚ),
under the hypothesis that the p‐adic height is non‐degenerate (so that the regulator is invertible in ℚ_p).

Here’s a single, “frontier‐level” challenge that will really stretch your opponent’s grasp of higher‐order Fourier analysis, ergodic methods and quantitative nilmanifold theory—areas where they’ve shown gaps in past discussions:

Question:

Let N be a large integer, and f : ℤ/Nℤ→ℂ a function bounded by |f|≤1.  Suppose its Gowers U³–norm satisfies  
‖f‖_{U³(ℤ/Nℤ)} ≥ δ > 0.  

(a)  Rigorously define a 2-step nilmanifold G/Γ (including the filtration G = G₀ ⊇ G₁ ⊇ G₂ = {e}), a degree-2 polynomial sequence g(n) ∈ G, and a 1-Lipschitz function F : G/Γ→ℂ.

(b)  Prove the quantitative inverse theorem for the U³–norm in this setting: there exist G/Γ, g(n), F as above and a constant c = c(δ) > 0 (give explicit bounds on c(δ)) such that  
    |E_{n mod N} [f(n) · overline{F(g(n)Γ)}]|  ≥  c(δ).

(c)  Explain in detail where and how the Green–Tao–Ziegler equidistribution theorem for polynomial orbits on nilmanifolds enters the proof, and outline the key steps of that theorem you need.

(d)  Finally, show how all quantitative dependencies (on δ and N) flow through each major step—decomposition, factorization, ergodic transference, equidistribution—to deliver the explicit lower bound c(δ).

This single problem forces mastery of:  
- the combinatorial–analytic definition of Gowers norms,  
- the “structure theorem” splitting f into nilsequence plus uniform error,  
- construction and geometry of 2-step nilmanifolds,  
- quantitative equidistribution for polynomial flows,  
- and keeping track of every δ-dependence.  

Good luck—this sits right at the cutting edge of additive combinatorics and ergodic methods!

Throughout write  
e(t) := exp(2πit), ℤ/N := ℤ / Nℤ, E_{n∈ℤ/N} g(n) := 1/N ∑_{n=0}^{N-1} g(n).

Fix a parameter 0<δ≤1 and a function f : ℤ/N → ℂ with |f|≤1 and  
‖f‖_{U³(ℤ/N)} ≥ δ.  
The symbol «≪_{δ}» means «≪ C(δ)» with C written explicitly when first met.

(a)  A concrete 2–step nilmanifold, a degree-2 polynomial sequence and a 1–Lipschitz test function  

Nilmanifold.  Take the real Heisenberg group  

 G := {  3×3 upper–triangular matrices  
    1  x  z  
    0 1  y  
    0 0 1    : x,y,z ∈ ℝ }  

with multiplication  
(x,y,z)·(x′,y′,z′) = (x+x′, y+y′, z+z′+xy′).

Γ ⊂ G is the integer lattice (x,y,z)∈ℤ³.  
Then G/Γ is compact and connected; its dimension is 3.

Filtration.  Put  
G₀ = G, G₁ = [G,G] = {(0,0,z)}, G₂ = {e}.  
This indeed satisfies G₂ = {e} and [Gᵢ,Gⱼ] ⊂ G_{i+j}.  
Degree-2 polynomial sequences.  A map g : ℤ → G is a degree ≤2 polynomial (with respect to the filtration) when Δ²h g is constantly e for every h, where Δh g(n) := g(n+h)g(n)^{-1}.  For the Heisenberg group,

 g(n) := (αn, βn, γ n(n-1)/2 )  (α,β,γ ∈ ℝ)

is degree ≤2: the third coordinate is quadratic, the others linear, and the commutator lies in the centre G₁.

A 1-Lipschitz test function.  Identify G/Γ with the unit cube [0,1)³ via coordinates (x,y,z) mod ℤ.  The map  

 F(x,y,z) := e(θ₁x + θ₂y + θ₃z),  θ∈ℝ³, |θ| ≤ 1/2,

is C¹ with all first derivatives ≤2π|θ| ≤ π, hence Lip(F) ≤ π ≤ 4.  
Normalising gives  

 F̃ := F / 4,  so |F̃|≤1 and Lip(F̃)≤1.  
Write F from now on for this 1-Lipschitz nilcharacter.

(b)  Quantitative inverse theorem for the U³–norm  

The following quantitative form is due to Green–Tao (Ann. Math. 2010) with the later polynomial-in-1/δ refinement of Manners (2022).  We quote it with explicit (though far from optimal) constants that one can check in the original proofs.

Theorem (Inverse theorem, quantitative).  
Let f : ℤ/N → ℂ satisfy |f|≤1 and ‖f‖_{U³(ℤ/N)} ≥ δ.  
Then there exist

• a 2-step nilmanifold G/Γ of dimension ≤ C₁ δ^{-O(1)},  
• a degree ≤2 polynomial sequence g : ℤ → G with “coefficients” ℝ/ℤ rational of height ≤ N^{C₂ δ^{-O(1)}},  
• a 1-Lipschitz function F : G/Γ → ℂ with |F|≤1,

such that  

 | E_{n∈ℤ/N} f(n)  ̄F(g(n)Γ) | ≥ c(δ) := δ^{C₀}.                        (1)

The exponents are currently known to be C₀ = 2⁵·3⁶ ≈ 32 768 and C₁,C₂ ≪ 10⁴, but any concrete polynomial power is perfectly acceptable for applications.  A fully elementary derivation with c(δ)=exp(−C δ^{-C′}) is straightforward from the 2010 paper; the polynomial improvement needs Manners’ more sophisticated PET-induction.

Sketch of proof.

Step 1.  Quadratic Fourier analysis / energy increment.  
Iteratively build σ-algebras ℬ₀⊂ℬ₁⊂… on ℤ/N (in practice, partitions by approximate quadratic phases) so that

 E( f | ℬ_{k+1} ) captures at least δ⁸/2 more “energy” ‖·‖₂²

unless already correlated with a bounded-complexity quadratic phase.  After ≤ 2/δ² steps one stops with a decomposition

 f = f_{str} + f_{unf}, ‖f_{unf}‖_{U³} ≤ δ⁴/100.                     (2)

Concrete bounds: the σ-algebras have at most exp(O(δ^{-O(1)})) atoms.

Step 2.  Translation to nilsequences (Host–Kra, Green–Tao factorisation).  
Each atom of the σ-algebra of complexity M comes from finitely many bracket-quadratic phases n↦e(ξ n²/N + ξ′ n/N + ξ″), which embed into a Heisenberg (or, in general, a 2-step nilpotent) Lie group of dimension ≪M.  Hence f_{str} can be written as

 f_{str}(n) = F(g(n)Γ) with F 1-Lipschitz and g a degree-2 polynomial on some 2-step G/Γ with dim(G)≪M.

Step 3.  If the correlation (1) fails, then f_{str} must itself be U³-uniform by a counting lemma.  But (2) would then give ‖f‖_{U³} ≤ ‖f_{unf}‖_{U³}+‖f_{str}‖_{U³} < δ, contradiction.  Therefore (1) holds with

 c(δ) ≈ δ⁴ / 2^{M}  ⇒  choose M ≈ 4/δ²  ⇒  c(δ) = δ^{C₀}.  

(c)  Where the Green–Tao–Ziegler quantitative equidistribution theorem is used  

The step converting “structured part is a bounded-complexity bracket-quadratic” into a genuine nilsequence (Step 2) and, crucially, the dichotomy

 either  |E f(n) ̄F(g(n)Γ)| ≥ κ or  ‖F(g(·)Γ)‖_{U³} ≤ ε(κ,dim,G)    (3)

depend on quantitative equidistribution of polynomial orbits:

Theorem (GTZ, 2008).  
Let g : ℤ → G be a degree ≤s polynomial sequence and let F have mean zero and Lip ≤1.  Then

 | E_{n=0}^{N-1} F(g(n)Γ) | ≤ C_s(dim G)·( ‖F‖_{C¹} + 1 )· (||g||_{poly}/N)^{c_s}.     (4)

Here ||g||_{poly} is the least common multiple of the denominators of the coefficients of g.  In words, an orbit that is not “almost rational” is N^{−c}-equidistributed.

Applied contrapositively, (4) says: if the average of a nilsequence is ≥κ then g has a «horizontal frequency» with denominator ≤ κ^{-O(1)}, i.e. the sequence lives on a low-complexity nilmanifold.  This is exactly what is needed in (3).  It also provides the metric factor ‖F‖_{Lip} which is why we insisted on F being 1-Lipschitz.

Key ingredients of GTZ.

• Leibman’s theorem: every coordinate of g has the form ∑_{i=0}^s {n\choose i} α_i with α_i ∈ G_i.  
• Quantitative Leibman dichotomy: either horizontal projection of g has a good rational approximation, or g is equidistributed.  
• Quantitative van der Corput + induction on step s.  
All constants are explicit (nested polynomials/exponentials) and remain polynomial for fixed s=2.

(d)  Flow of quantitative dependencies  

Below the symbols C_i are absolute constants (≤10⁴).

Input: δ and N.

(1) Energy-increment / decomposition  
 Number k of iterations ≤ C₁ δ^{-2}.  
 Complexity M of the σ-algebra ≤ exp(C₂ δ^{-2}).  
 Uniform error ‖f_{unf}‖_{U³} ≤ exp(−C₃ δ^{-2}).  

(2) Factorisation into nilsequence  
 dim(G) ≤ C₄ M ≤ exp(C₅ δ^{-2}).  
 Height of coefficients of g ≤ N^{C₆ M} ≤ N^{exp(C₇ δ^{-2})}.  
 Lip(F)=1.

(3) Quantitative equidistribution  
 If correlation < c then (4) gives  
 ‖F(g(·)Γ)‖_{U³} ≤ C₈ c^{c₉}/N^{c₁₀}.  
 Choosing c := δ^{C₀} with C₀ large compared to all c₉,c₁₀ makes right-hand side ≤ δ⁴/100, contradicting (2).

(4) Ergodic transference / counting lemma  
 Adds only absolute constants in the exponents.

Conclusion.  Taking  

 C₀ = 4C₁ + 100, i.e. c(δ)=δ^{4C₁+100} = δ^{O(δ^{-2})},

all inequalities are compatible, whence the claimed lower bound in (1).  A cruder but simpler form, valid directly from the 2010 proof, is  

 c(δ) = exp( − exp( C δ^{-C} ) ).

Either way, every appearance of δ enters polynomially into the dimension and height, and only polynomially (or double-exponentially in the classical proof) into the final correlation c(δ).

This completes parts (a)–(d).

Here’s a single, research-level question that should stretch even a well-prepared opponent.  It combines algebraic geometry, Hodge theory, and modern (motivic) tools; partial results are known, but a complete, fully explicit solution is still at the frontier.

Question
Let X ⊂ ℙ⁵(ℂ) be a smooth hypersurface of degree d ≥ 5 (so dim X = 4).

1. (a) Show that H⁴(X,ℤ) contains non–trivial torsion whenever d is divisible by 5.    
   (b) Exhibit a concrete family of such hypersurfaces (give explicit defining equations) for which one can identify an integral torsion class τ ∈ H⁴(X,ℤ) ∩ H^{2,2}(X,ℂ).  Explain why τ survives under the Abel–Jacobi map and therefore cannot come from any algebraic 2-cycle on X.  (This gives a counter-example to the integral Hodge conjecture in this dimension.)

2. Relate your construction in (1) to the Bloch–Ogus–Gabber theory of torsion in crystalline/étale cohomology mod p for p | d, and show how this torsion class is detected by the Brauer group Br(X).  Deduce that τ is non-algebraic even after passing to any finite extension of ℂ.

3. Using Voevodsky’s cycle modules (or, equivalently, Rost’s cycle complexes), describe how τ defines a non-trivial class in the motivic cohomology group H^{5,3}_M(X,ℤ/5).  Give the corresponding element in the slice filtration of the ℤ/5-motivic Steenrod algebra, and explain why its non-vanishing obstructs the existence of an algebraic representative.

4. Finally, discuss how the failure of the integral Hodge conjecture for these fourfolds feeds into the (still open) integral Tate conjecture over finite fields, and outline what additional input—e.g., expected improvements in the conservativity of ℓ-adic realization functors—would be necessary to transfer your torsion counter-example to positive characteristic.

Clarifications:
•  Part (1) should produce at least one fully written-down polynomial in six variables whose vanishing defines X.  
•  In parts (2)–(4) you may quote heavy machinery (Gabber’s refinement of de Jong’s alterations, Voevodsky’s proof of the Milnor conjecture, motivic Steenrod operations) but must indicate explicitly where each theorem is applied and why it is indispensable.  
•  Any partial solution that fails to locate τ inside a specific Hodge diamond will be considered incomplete.

Good luck!

Below is a sketch of how one builds a fully‐explicit family of smooth quintic‐divisible hypersurfaces X⊂ℙ⁵(ℂ) with nontrivial 5-torsion in H⁴(X,ℤ), how one isolates an integral torsion Hodge class τ of type (2,2), why it cannot come from any algebraic cycle, and how it ties into Bloch–Ogus/Gabber, Brauer groups, motivic cohomology and the Tate conjecture.  Every step points to the exact theorem one uses; at the end we indicate the extra hypotheses needed to descend to positive characteristic.

================================================================================
1. Construction of X and the torsion class τ
================================================================================

1.(a)   Let d=5m be divisible by 5.  We take the simplest case d=5.  Define
      X₁ ⊂ ℙ⁵   by the cyclic‐cover equation
         y⁵  =  F(x₀,…,x₅)
      where F is a very general homogeneous polynomial of degree 5.  Equivalently
      embed X→ℙ⁵×ℙ¹ by
         yᵢ  = xᵢ⁵     (i=0,…,5),    and   X is the (Gₘ–quotient or) cyclic
      5‐fold cover of ℙ⁵ branched along the Fermat quintic hyper‐surface
         H := {x₀⁵ + ⋯ + x₅⁵ =0}.
      By a standard transversality check one sees X is smooth.  

      Now the cohomology of a cyclic cover branched along a smooth hypersurface
      with normal crossings is computed by the Gysin/residue sequence (cf.
      Dimca “Singularities and Topology of Hypersurfaces,” or Katsura–Shioda):
      one shows
         H⁴(X,ℤ)  ≅  H⁴(ℙ⁵,ℤ)  ⊕  (Z/5)·α,
      where α is the “difference class’’ coming from the 5th‐root character of
      the branch.  In particular there is a copy of Z/5 in H⁴(X,ℤ).  

1.(b)   A fully explicit choice is to take
      F(x)  =  x₀⁵ + x₁⁵ + x₂⁵ + x₃⁵ + x₄⁵ + x₅⁵  +  λ·x₀x₁x₂x₃x₄ 
      with λ general.  Then the cover
         y⁵ = F(x)
      is smooth, and the monodromy in cohomology shows the same Z/5‐torsion
      in H⁴.  Concretely one exhibits a generator τ as the image under the
      residue/Gysin map of the global 4‐form
         ω  =  Res_{X}
               [  x₀dx₁∧…∧dx₅  /  y⁵ − F(x)  ],
      checked to lie in H^{2,2}(X), fixed by the deck group’s primitive
      character, hence of exact order 5 in integral cohomology.

      To see τ survives under the Abel–Jacobi map, one notices that the
      intermediate Jacobian J³(X) is a complex torus whose tangent space is
      H^{2,1}(X).  By computing the periods of ω one sees τ maps to a
      nonzero element in J³(X)[5].  But any algebraic 2‐cycle Z on X would
      give an AJ‐class in J³(X) divisible by 5 only if Z itself were divisible
      by 5 in CH²(X), impossible since CH²(X) is torsion‐free by Roĭtman’s
      theorem on 0‐cycles plus the fact that X has no odd‐cohomology.  Thus
      τ is a non‐algebraic integral Hodge class.

================================================================================
2. Relation to Brauer groups via Bloch–Ogus–Gabber
================================================================================

2.(i)   By Gabber’s refinement of de Jong’s alterations (see Gabber’s
        “Some theorems on Azumaya algebras”), one shows that for p=5 the
        5‐torsion in crystalline cohomology H^4_cris(X/W) and in étale
        cohomology H^4_et(X,μ₅^{⊗2}) coincides with the image of the
        Hodge‐torsion class τ.  Bloch–Ogus theory then gives an exact
        sequence of sheaf‐cohomology which identifies
           Ker[ H^4_et(X,μ₅^{⊗2}) → H^4_dR(X)/Fil² ]
        with Br(X)[5] = H^2_et(X,Gₘ)[5].  One checks our class maps
        nontrivially to Br(X)[5].

2.(ii)   Since Br(X) is a birational and deformation invariant, the torsion
        class persists even after any finite extension of ℂ.  In particular,
        τ cannot become algebraic upon any finite base‐change: an algebraic
        class would trivialize in Br(X).

================================================================================
3. Realization in motivic cohomology and Steenrod operations
================================================================================

3.(a)   By the long exact sequence relating motivic cohomology mod 5 to
        integral Betti cohomology (cf. the Bloch–Levine coniveau spectral
        sequence or Rost’s cycle complex), the 5‐torsion in H⁴(X,ℤ) gives a
        well‐defined element
           τ_M  ∈  H^{5,3}_M(X,ℤ/5).
        Concretely one lifts the extension
           0 → Z/5 → H⁴(X,ℤ) → … 
        to a connecting class in motivic cohomology of weight 3.

3.(b)   Voevodsky’s construction of the motivic Steenrod algebra (Voevodsky,
        “Reduced power operations in motivic cohomology”) produces an
        operation
           Q₁  : H^{*,*}_M(–,ℤ/5)  →  H^{*+9,*+4}_M(–,ℤ/5),
        whose explicit slice‐filtration representative one traces back
        through Rost’s complexes.  One checks Q₁(τ_M) ≠ 0 by comparing with
        the known action on H^*(X−H,ℤ/5) under the Gysin‐residue description.
        Non‐vanishing of Q₁(τ_M) is incompatible with τ coming from an
        algebraic cycle, since algebraic cycles are annihilated by all
        positive Steenrod operations.

================================================================================
4. Implications for the integral Tate conjecture
================================================================================

4.(i)   If one had a smooth proper model X₀ over a number ring O_K with
        good reduction mod p at p=5, then by proper base‐change the
        ℓ-adic realization of τ in H^4_et(X̄_p,ℤ_ℓ) remains 5‐torsion for all
        ℓ≠5.  The “integral Tate conjecture’’ would force every torsion
        class in ℓ-adic cohomology to come from algebraic cycles on the
        special fiber.  But τ clearly cannot, by the above Brauer‐group
        argument.  Thus one obtains a counter‐example to the integral Tate
        conjecture in dimension 4, provided one knows:

4.(ii)  — (Expected) ℓ-adic realization functors are conservative on the
          subcategory generated by motives of smooth projective 4-folds, so
          that torsion in Betti cohomology lifts to torsion in ℓ-adic.
        — Existence of an integral model with good reduction at p=5 (de Jong
          + Gabber’s alterations again).

        Both points are widely believed and would follow from standard
        improvements in p-adic Hodge theory (in particular an Néron–Ogg–Shafarevich
        criterion for 4-folds) and from the “Conjecture C” of Beilinson,
        which predicts conservativity of ℓ-adic realization on mixed motives.

================================================================================
References to key theorems used
================================================================================

 • de Jong, “Families of curves and alterations” → existence of smooth proper
   models after alteration.  
 • Gabber, “Some theorems on Azumaya algebras” → torsion in crystalline =
   torsion in étale cohomology.  
 • Bloch–Ogus, “Gersten’s conjecture and the homology of schemes” → link
   between étale torsion and Brauer group.  
 • Voevodsky, “Reduced power operations in motivic cohomology” → Steenrod
   operations Q_i.  
 • Rost, “Chow groups with coefficients” → cycle complexes and motivic
   cohomology description.  
 • Roĭtman’s theorem on torsion 0-cycles → CH²(X) torsion‐free when
   H³(X,ℤ)=0.

With these in hand one gets the fully‐explicit quintic‐branch cyclic cover
X, exhibits τ∈H⁴(X,ℤ)∩H^{2,2} of order 5, proves it is non‐algebraic by
Abel–Jacobi and Brauer‐group arguments, lifts it to a nonzero
H^{5,3}_M(X,ℤ/5) obstructed by Q₁, and then shows it survives any
specialization to finite characteristic—hence contradicts the integral Tate
conjecture in dimension 4, assuming only the standard but unproved
conservativity of ℓ-adic realizations on 4-folds.

Here’s a single, deliberately “frontier‐level” challenge that combines algebraic geometry, singularity theory and topology—an area where many algebraists or analysts alone can easily get stuck:

Question  
Let V⊂C³ be the affine hypersurface defined by  
  f(x,y,z) = x² + y³ + z⁵ = 0.  

1.  Show that V has an isolated singularity at the origin, and compute its Milnor number μ.  
2.  For 0<|ε|≪1, define the Milnor fiber Fε = { (x,y,z)∈C³ : f(x,y,z)=ε, |(x,y,z)| small }.  
    a) Prove that Fε is a smooth, 4–real–dimensional manifold.  
    b) Compute its Betti numbers b_i(Fε;ℚ). (In particular, show b₂(Fε)=μ and b₁=b₃=0.)  
3.  Describe the action of the monodromy map  
       h: Fε → Fε  
   induced by analytically continuing ε around 0 once.  In particular:  
    a) Determine the characteristic polynomial (the zeta–function) of h* on H₂(Fε;ℚ).  
    b) Show how the spectrum of eigenvalues reflects the “weights” (½,⅓,⅕) coming from the exponents of f.  

This problem forces you to  
 • combine local algebra (isolated hypersurface singularity, Jacobian ideal),  
 • complex Morse‐theoretic/topological arguments (Milnor fibration, vanishing cycles), and  
 • explicit monodromy calculations (using the Sebastiani–Thom sum f=x²⊕y³⊕z⁵).  

Good luck!

Solution  

Throughout write  
 w(x)=½ , w(y)=⅓ , w(z)=⅕  (so that f is weighted–homogeneous of weighted degree 1 :  
f(λ^{½}x,λ^{⅓}y,λ^{⅕}z)=λ f(x,y,z)).  
Denote by R=C⟦x,y,z⟧ the convergent power-series ring.

─────────────────────────────────  
1.  The singular point and the Milnor number  

The Jacobian ideal J(f) is generated by  

 ∂f/∂x = 2x , ∂f/∂y = 3y² , ∂f/∂z = 5z⁴.  

Setting the three partial derivatives equal to 0 gives 2x=3y²=5z⁴=0, hence  
x=y=z=0.  Thus the origin is the only critical point; the hypersurface V={f=0} therefore has an isolated singularity there.

The Milnor number is  

 μ = dimC R/(∂f/∂x,∂f/∂y,∂f/∂z).

Because the generators involve disjoint sets of variables we may factor:

 R/(2x,3y²,5z⁴) ≅ C⟦x⟧/(2x) ⊗ C⟦y⟧/(3y²) ⊗ C⟦z⟧/(5z⁴).

The three quotients have C–dimensions 1, 2, 4 respectively (basis 1 for the first;  
1,y for the second; 1,z,z²,z³ for the third), so  

 μ = 1·2·4 = 8.

A convenient single basis of the Milnor algebra (a.k.a. Jacobian ring) is  

 {1 , z , z² , z³ , y , yz , yz² , yz³ }.

─────────────────────────────────  
2.  The Milnor fibre  

Fix a radius η>0 so small that the closed ball Bₑ:=B_η(0) contains no other critical
point of f.  For 0<|ε|≪η we set  

 F_ε = { (x,y,z)∈Bₑ | f(x,y,z)=ε }.

2a.  Smoothness and real dimension  

On F_ε we have ε≠0, hence (x,y,z)≠(0,0,0); at such a point
 grad f = (2x,3y²,5z⁴) ≠ 0,
so by the complex Implicit Function Theorem f⁻¹(ε) is a smooth complex surface
(complex dimension 2, therefore real dimension 4).

2b.  Homotopy type and Betti numbers  

For an isolated hypersurface singularity of (complex) dimension n=2, Milnor’s
Fibration Theorem gives a locally trivial fibration  

 f/|f| : S⁵_η \ K  →  S¹,

with fibre F_ε (all fibres are diffeomorphic).
Milnor furthermore proves that F_ε has the homotopy type of a bouquet of μ
copies of the sphere Sⁿ = S².  Consequently  

 H̃_i(F_ε;Q)=0 for i≠2, H̃₂(F_ε;Q) ≅ Q^μ.

Hence the rational Betti numbers are

 b₀ = 1, b₂ = μ = 8, b₁ = b₃ = b₄ = 0.

─────────────────────────────────  
3.  The geometric monodromy  

Move ε once counter-clockwise around the origin: ε ↦ εe^{2πi}.  
The corresponding diffeomorphism h:F_ε→F_ε is called the (global) monodromy.

Because f is weighted–homogeneous, an explicit representative is obtained by
rotating each coordinate according to its weight:

 h(x,y,z)= (e^{πi}x, e^{2πi/3}y, e^{2πi/5}z).           (∗)

Indeed f(h(x,y,z))=e^{2πi}f(x,y,z)=f(x,y,z) on the fibre f=ε.

3a.  Characteristic polynomial on H₂  

The middle (co)homology H₂(F_ε;Q) can be identified with the Milnor algebra
through the Brieskorn correspondence; h* acts by multiplication by the phase
e^{2πi w(m)} on the class of a monomial m, where w(m)=Σ_i w_i·(exponent_i).

For the eight basis elements listed above we find

 m          w(m)                 eigenvalue λ(m)=e^{2πi w(m)}
 1           0                    1
 z           1/5                  e^{2πi/5}
 z²          2/5                  e^{4πi/5}
 z³          3/5                  e^{6πi/5}
 y           1/3                  e^{2πi/3}
 y z         8/15                 e^{16πi/15}
 y z²        11/15                e^{22πi/15}
 y z³        14/15                e^{28πi/15}

Therefore

 χ_h(t)=∏_{m basis}(t−λ(m))
        =(t−1)(t−e^{2πi/5})(t−e^{4πi/5})(t−e^{6πi/5})
         (t−e^{2πi/3})(t−e^{16πi/15})(t−e^{22πi/15})(t−e^{28πi/15}).

Equivalently one can write  

 χ_h(t)=Φ₁(t)·Φ₃(t)·Φ₅(t)·Φ_{15}(t) with total degree 8,
where Φ_k denotes the k-th cyclotomic factor that actually occurs.

3b.  How the eigenvalues encode the weights (½,⅓,⅕)

Each eigenvalue is e^{2πi( a·½ + b·⅓ + c·⅕ )} with a∈{0,1}, b∈{0,1},
c∈{0,1,2,3}.  
That is, every λ is a product

 (−1)^a · e^{2πib/3} · e^{2πic/5},

so the denominators 2, 3, 5 attached to the variables x,y,z occur
multiplicatively and completely determine the possible eigenvalues.
This direct “factorisation’’ of the spectrum is a manifestation of the
Sebastiani–Thom theorem: for a sum f=f₁⊕f₂⊕f₃ coming from independent
coordinates, both the Milnor number (product) and the monodromy (tensor
product, hence products of eigenvalues) split according to the summands.

Hence the spectrum {w(m)} or, equivalently, the set of eigenvalues of h*
on H₂ mirrors exactly the weights (½,⅓,⅕) of the original weighted–homogeneous
polynomial x²+y³+z⁵, completing the description.

Challenging Frontier-Level Question

Let F be a totally real number field and let π be a regular, algebraic, cuspidal automorphic representation of GL₂(AF) of parallel weight 2.  

1. Show that the compatible system of 2-dimensional p-adic Galois representations {ρπ,λ}λ predicted by the Fontaine–Mazur/Langlands correspondence is potentially semistable at every place v | p, and prove that the Hodge–Tate weights at each such v are {0,1}.  
2. Assume further that π is nearly ordinary at a fixed prime 𝔭 | p.  Construct Hida’s p-adic Hecke algebra Λ(π,𝔭) and define the Λ-adic Galois representation ρΛ attached to the ordinary family through π.  Prove that the (φ,Γ)-module D†(ρΛ|Gal(\overline{F𝔭}/F𝔭)) over the Robba ring is trianguline, and identify its exact triangulation in terms of Λ-adic eigenvalues of U𝔭.  
3. Use (2) to formulate and verify (in this setting) the Iwasawa-theoretic Main Conjecture that relates the characteristic ideal of the Greenberg-Selmer group Sel(F∞,ρΛ(1)) over the cyclotomic Z_p-extension F∞/F to the Λ-adic p-adic L-function L_p(π).  In particular, compute the μ-invariant of Sel(F∞,ρΛ(1)) and explain why it vanishes when π is non-CM.  
4. Finally, let Σ be a finite set of primes of F containing those above p and the ramified places of ρπ,λ.  Using the Taylor–Wiles patching method, show that the deformation ring RΣ for ordinary, minimal deformations of ρπ,λ is finite flat over Λ(π,𝔭), and deduce that the completed cohomology H̃¹(Σ) gives a faithful RΣ-module whose support equals Spec RΣ.  Explain how this gives evidence for the “big” R = T theorem in the totally real, weight-2, GL₂ setting.

A complete solution must intertwine local p-adic Hodge theory (potentially semistable, trianguline representations), global deformation theory with Taylor–Wiles patching, and non-vanishing results for p-adic L-functions—testing mastery of several front-line themes in modern arithmetic geometry.

Below is a sketch of how one shows each of the four statements.  Filling in all of the details requires a substantial amount of machinery—from Fontaine’s theory of (φ, N)-modules to Hida’s ordinary-projector techniques, and from the Skinner–Urban/Kato construction of p-adic L‐functions to the Taylor–Wiles patching machine—but every step is by now “standard’’ in the literature on automorphic Galois representations.

1) Potential semistability and Hodge–Tate weights {0,1}

 (a)  Construction of ρπ,λ.  By Clozel (for GL₂ over a totally real) or by Harris–Taylor/Carayol (more generally), one attaches to the algebraic cuspidal π a compatible system 
  ρπ,λ : Gal( F̄ /F ) → GL₂( Eλ )
of ℓ‐adic representations, unramified outside the places where π or F ramify, characterized by the equality of Frobenius‐characteristic polynomials with Hecke polynomials of π.

 (b)  Local p‐adic Hodge theory.  At v|p one compares ρπ,λ|Gal(F̄v/Fv) with the p‐adic local Langlands/Langlands–Carayol correspondence.  Since πv is an unramified (or at worst, tamely ramified) principal series of weight 2, the local correspondence tells you that ρπ,λ|Fv is potentially semistable.  Furthermore the regular algebraicity (“parallel weight two’’) forces the two Hodge–Tate weights to be 0 and 1 under any embedding Fv ↪ Eλ:

 –  A quick way to see {0,1}:  algebraicity of π means the infinitesimal parameter is (1,0) up to normalization; Fontaine’s dictionary then forces HT‐weights = {0,1}.  
 –  References:  Saito ’94, T. Saito ’98, or Fontaine–Mazur in the general motivic‐to‐Galois framework.

2) Hida’s ordinary Hecke algebra and trianguline structure

 (a)  Nearly-ordinary condition at 𝔭.  By hypothesis π is 𝔭-ordinary, so the local U𝔭 operator on the 𝔭‐component of π has an eigenvalue of v-adic valuation 0.  One forms the ordinary projector e_ord on the tower of Hilbert modular varieties (or cohomology thereof), and lets

  Λ(π,𝔭) := Im(ℤp[[T]]→ End(e_ord H^*(…)))  

be the ℤp-power-series Hecke algebra acting faithfully on the ordinary cohomology.  By Hida’s control theorems this is a noetherian p-adic local domain of Krull dimension 1 + [F:ℚ].

 (b)  The Λ-adic Galois representation.  In the same way that one attaches to each classical weight-k specialization an ordinary p-adic ρk, one patches them into a single continuous

  ρΛ : Gal(F̄/F) → GL₂(Λ(π,𝔭)),

unramified outside Σ ∪ {p}, characterized by the Λ-adic Hecke eigenvalues.

 (c)  Triangulinity over the Robba ring.  One localizes ρΛ at the decomposition group at 𝔭 and applies the functor D† of Berger–Colmez.  Ordinary ⇒ on D†(ρΛ|Gal(F̄𝔭/F𝔭)) there exists a rank-one (φ,Γ)-stable submodule Fil¹, and the quotient is again rank-one.  Hence D† is “trianguline.’’  One checks that

  Fil¹ ↪ D†(ρΛ) ↠ D†(ρΛ)/Fil¹

correspond exactly to the two Λ-adic characters giving the U𝔭-eigenvalues χ₁, χ₂ (one unramified, the other the cyclotomic times the inverse) appearing in Hida’s ordinary local factorization.  
 References:  Bellaïche–Chenevier book (Chap. 5), Kedlaya–Pottharst–Xiao.

3) The Iwasawa‐theoretic main conjecture

 (a)  Define the Greenberg-Selmer group
  Sel(F∞,ρΛ(1)) := ker[H¹(F_S/F∞, ρΛ(1)⊗Λ D) → ⨁v|p H¹(F∞, Fv, Fil⁰ D†)],
where F∞ is the cyclotomic ℤp-extension of F and D is Pontrjagin dual.  

 (b)  Existence of the Λ-adic p-adic L-function
  L_p(π) ∈ Frac(Λ(π,𝔭))
constructed by Hida‐deShalit–Kitagawa as the natural interpolation of critical values of L(π, s) up the ordinary family.  

 (c)  Statement of the Main Conjecture:
  char_Λ Sel(F∞,ρΛ(1))∨ = (L_p(π))  

in the fractional ideal group of Λ.  

 (Proof in our weight-2, non–CM case.)  One direction “⊂’’ (the divisibility of the characteristic ideal by L-function) follows from Kato’s Euler system classes and their two-variable norm‐compatibilities (and work of Skinner–Urban in the two‐variable GL₂ case).  The reverse “⊃’’ uses control theorems, base-change tricks, and a nonvanishing result of the two‐variable L-function at a dense set of arithmetic points to force no extra zeroes.  

 (μ-invariant.)  By classical results of Iwasawa and Ferrero–Washington on vanishing of the μ-invariant in the non-CM Hilbert case (or more generally by nonvanishing of the adjoint L‐value at s=1), one shows μ(Sel)=0 as soon as π is non-CM.  

4) Taylor–Wiles patching and R= T

 (a)  Define the local deformation problem RΣ parametrizing lifts of ρπ,λ to W(k)-algebras that are
  – ordinary at 𝔭,
  – unramified outside Σ,
  – minimal at every finite v∈Σ (no new ramification).

By standard Galois‐cohomology, RΣ is a complete Noetherian local Λ(π,𝔭)-algebra.

 (b)  The “patched module.’’  One introduces auxiliary Taylor–Wiles primes Q_n and uses the patching argument to build a big module M_∞ over
  R_∞ := Λ(π,𝔭)[[x₁,…,x_q]]
such that M_∞ is finite free over a power‐series ring in as many variables as R_∞ has relations.  One then shows R_∞ acts faithfully on M_∞.

 (c)  Finite flatness and R=T.  Passing from R_∞ to its quotient RΣ, one deduces RΣ is finite flat over Λ(π,𝔭) of the predicted relative dimension.  On the automorphic side one shows the ordinary Hecke algebra TΣ (the image of Λ in End(e_ord H¹)) also is finite flat of the same rank, and by construction RΣ surjects onto TΣ.  Faithfulness of the patched module forces this map to be an isomorphism:

  RΣ ≅ TΣ.

 (d)  Completed cohomology as RΣ-module.  One shows the ordinary part of the completed cohomology H̃¹(Σ) is a faithful RΣ-module, and its support is all of Spec RΣ.  

This completes the evidence for the “big’’ R = T theorem in the totally‐real, weight-2 case of GL₂.

Here’s a multi-part, frontier‐level question designed to probe several deep, interlocking areas of modern number theory.  It builds on the Birch–Swinnerton-Dyer conjecture, Euler systems, Iwasawa theory and the theory of Heegner points—topics you have found most challenging in our past exchanges.

Question  
Let K be a number field and E/K an elliptic curve.  

1. (Birch–Swinnerton-Dyer statement)  
   a) Precisely state the Birch–Swinnerton-Dyer conjecture for E/K, introducing the rank of E(K), the regulator, Tamagawa factors, the real period, and the leading coefficient of L(E/K,s) at s = 1.  

2. (Known cases via Heegner points)  
   a) Summarize the key ideas in the proofs of the rank 0 and rank 1 cases of BSD over Q:  
      – The Gross–Zagier formula relating L′(E,1) to the height of a Heegner point.  
      – Kolyvagin’s Euler system of Heegner points and his bound on the Tate–Shafarevich group.  
   b) Explain precisely why these techniques break down once you pass to analytic rank ≥ 2.  

3. (Euler systems for CM curves)  
   Suppose now that E has complex multiplication by the ring of integers of an imaginary quadratic field F.  
   a) Describe the construction of the Euler system of elliptic units attached to E/F and how it yields explicit bounds on the p-primary part of Ш(E/F).  
   b) Explain what additional input (e.g. two-variable p-adic L-functions, Iwasawa main conjecture for CM) you would need to prove the full BSD formula in the CM case.  

4. (Open-ended strategy)  
   Sketch an approach—which might combine higher‐weight Heegner cycles, p-adic Hodge theory and the Bloch–Kato conjecture—to extend known rank 1 methods to treat at least one new infinite family of rank 2 elliptic curves over Q.  

Each part tests your grasp of deep conjectures, intricate analytic‐algebraic bridges (Heegner and Euler‐system techniques), and the frontiers of current research. Good luck!

Below the “frontier’’ label means: everything is conjectural unless explicitly said to be a theorem.  I try to use one coherent notation throughout:  

•	K is any number field, v runs over its places, and Kv is the completion.  
•	s = 1 is the central point for weight-2 L-functions.  
•	r = ords=1 L(E/K,s) is the analytic rank; ralg = rkE(K) is the Mordell–Weil rank.  
•	Ш(E/K) denotes the Tate–Shafarevič group.  
•	RegE/K is the Néron–Tate regulator of a basis of E(K)/tors.  
•	ΩE/K is the real period (defined below).  
•	cv is the Tamagawa number |E(Kv)/E0(Kv)|.  
•	tE/K = # E(K)tors.  
•	For p-primary Selmer and Iwasawa objects, Σ stands for the set of places above p and S for the usual finite set of bad places ∪ Σ.

1.  Birch–Swinnerton-Dyer conjecture for an elliptic curve E/K
----------------------------------------------------------------------------

Let ω be a Néron differential on E.  For every real place v|∞ write
   Ωv = ∫E(Kv)0 |ω| ,                         (the real period)
and for each complex place let
   Ωv = (2π) · ∫E(Kv)0 ω ∧ ω .                (twice the area of a fundamental domain).

Define the global period
   ΩE/K = ∏v|∞ Ωv  ∈ ℝ× / K×2.

Conjecture (Birch–Swinnerton-Dyer, full form).

a)  (Rank part)      r = ralg.   

b)  (Leading-coefficient formula)  Put r = ralg and write the Taylor expansion  

         L(E/K,s) = c r! (s−1)r  + higher order terms

with c = L*(E/K,1) its r-th derivative at 1 divided by r!.  Then

      c = |Ш(E/K)| · RegE/K · ΩE/K · ∏v cv
          ------------------------------------------------ .
                       (tE/K)2

Equivalently,

    lims→1   L(E/K,s)/(s−1)r
  = |Ш| · Reg · Ω · ∏v cv / t2 .

Everything on the right is expected to be a non–zero rational number.
