2.  The rank-0 and rank-1 cases over Q via Heegner points
----------------------------------------------------------------------------

(Theorems of Gross–Zagier, Kolyvagin, Rubin, et al.)

2.a)  Key ideas.

Gross–Zagier formula (1986).  
Let E/ℚ be modular, let fE be the associated weight-2 newform, and let K be an imaginary quadratic field of discriminant coprime to N = conductor(E) satisfying the Heegner hypothesis (every prime dividing N splits in K).  Let P ∈ E(K) be the Heegner point obtained by modular parameterisation X0(N) → E.  Then

          L′(E/K,1) =  C · ⟨P,P⟩NT ,

where ⟨ , ⟩NT is the Néron–Tate height and C is an explicit non-zero constant depending only on arithmetic invariants of E and K.

Kolyvagin’s Euler system of Heegner points (1989).  
For an infinite set of square-free products n of certain inert primes ℓ, Kolyvagin constructs cohomology classes

          κn ∈ H1(K,E[p∞])

coming from “derived” Heegner points Pn ∈ E(Kn) (Kn is the ring-class field of conductor n).  The κn form an Euler system: their corestrictions and local behavior satisfy norm-compatibilities that force relations among Selmer groups.  Consequences:

   •	If one κn is non-zero, then the p-primary part of Ш(E/K) is finite and killed by a power of p bounded explicitly in terms of n.  
   •	E(K) has rank 0 (respectively 1) when L(E,1) ≠ 0 (respectively L(E,1)=0, L′(E,1) ≠ 0).

Over ℚ (take K = ℚ itself):

   •	Rank-0 theorem (Kolyvagin–Logachev): if L(E,1) ≠ 0 then ralg = 0 and Ш is finite.  
   •	Rank-1 theorem (Gross–Zagier + Kolyvagin): if L(E,1)=0, L′(E,1) ≠ 0 then ralg = 1 and #Ш is predicted correctly up to a p-adic unit for every prime p.

2.b)  Why the method stops at analytic rank ≥ 2.

Heegner points give at most one global class: κ1 lives in a 1-dimensional space when r = 1.  For r ≥ 2:

   •	The height formula involves L″(E,1), L‴(E,1), …  but no analogue of Gross–Zagier is known that expresses higher derivatives in terms of heights of algebraic points.  
   •	Kolyvagin’s descent relies on non-vanishing of a single κn; when there are two or more independent rational points, one cannot force both to arise from the Heegner system—so the Selmer rank can no longer be bounded by 1.  
   •	In technical terms, the Euler system of Heegner points only controls the 1-dimensional ℚp-vector space generated by κn, hence cannot prove finiteness of a Selmer group of corank ≥ 2.

============================================================================
3.  Euler systems for CM elliptic curves
----------------------------------------------------------------------------

Assume now E has complex multiplication by 𝒪F, F an imaginary quadratic field.

3.a)  Elliptic units and bounds on Ш(E/F).

•	For every integral ideal 𝔣 prime to a fixed auxiliary conductor 𝔫, the CM theory of the modular curve X0(𝔫) produces algebraic numbers called elliptic units
        ε𝔣 ∈ F(𝔣)× ,
  where F(𝔣) is the ray-class field of conductor 𝔣.

•	Taking Kummer images gives cohomology classes
        κ𝔣 = (ε𝔣) ⊗ p−n ∈ H1(F(𝔣), ℚp(1)) ,
  and their norms satisfy the Euler system relations discovered by Rubin.

•	Using the formal group of E we map H1(F(𝔣), ℚp(1)) → H1(F(𝔣), E[p∞]); tracing through corestrictions yields an Euler system {κ𝔣} for E.

Rubin’s descent (1991) then proves:

   •	The p-primary Selmer group Selp∞(E/F) is Λ-cotorsion (Λ = ℤp[[Gal(F∞/F)]] for the anticyclotomic extension).  
   •	#Ш(E/F)[pn] is bounded above by explicit quantities derived from the elliptic units.  
   •	In many cases (e.g. good, ordinary p, minimal conductor) one gets #Ш(E/F)[p∞] < ∞ unconditionally.

3.b)  Extra input required for the full BSD formula.

To pass from “upper bounds” to an equality as in BSD one needs:

   •	Two-variable p-adic L-function Lp(E/F):   constructed by Coates–Wiles, Katz, or Hida–Tilouine.  
   •	Iwasawa main conjecture for CM curves:   characteristic ideal of Selp∞ equals the principal ideal generated by Lp(E/F).  Proved by Rubin (anticyclotomic) and by Katz (cyclotomic) when p ∤ #Cl(F).  
   •	p-adic height formalism (Perrin-Riou map) to relate the first derivative of Lp in the cyclotomic direction to the Néron–Tate regulator.  
   •	Control the Tamagawa factors and the torsion quotient in families (depend on deep work of Greenberg–Stevens, Kobayashi, Pollack–Rubin, etc.).

When all these inputs are in place, one obtains at least the p-part of the BSD formula, and in many CM cases one now has the complete rational equality.

4.  A possible strategy for an infinite family of rank-2 curves over ℚ
----------------------------------------------------------------------------

Target family.  Fix a rational elliptic curve E/ℚ with analytic rank 1.  Consider quadratic twists E(D): y2 = x3 + Ax + B with D ranging over a set ℱ of square-free integers satisfying simultaneously  
   (i)  sign of functional equation w(E(D)) = +1,  
   (ii)  an explicit Heegner hypothesis relative to two distinct imaginary quadratic fields K1, K2.

For many D in ℱ one expects r(E(D)) = 2.

Idea: produce TWO independent global cohomology classes.

Step 1.  Higher-weight (generalised) Heegner cycles.  
On the Kuga–Sato variety XK,N associated with the modular form fE of level N, construct algebraic cycles Zj(D) for j = 1,2 lying in CHk(XK,N) (k depends on the weight of the symmetric-power motive Sym2 E).  Their images under the Abel–Jacobi map give classes

        Pj(D) ∈ H1(ℚ,E(D)(p)) .

Yuan–Zhang–Zhang’s generalised Gross–Zagier formula (2013–2017) relates the first and second derivatives of Rankin–Selberg L-functions to the heights of such cycles; in particular one expects

        L″(E(D),1)   proportional to   det( ⟨Pi,Pj⟩ ).

Step 2.  p-adic regulators and Perrin-Riou theory.  
Construct a big logarithm map

        𝓛: H1(ℚ,E[p∞]) → ΛΣ ⊗ ℚp

whose specialisations interpolate both p-adic heights and cyclotomic derivatives.  Show that the 2×2 matrix (𝓛(Pi),𝓛σ(Pj)) has non-zero determinant whenever L″(E(D),1) ≠ 0.

Step 3.  Euler–system / Kolyvagin-style descent in rank 2.  
Although a genuine rank-2 Euler system is unknown, one can package the Pi(D) into a “higher-rank Kolyvagin system’’ in the sense of Mazur–Rubin–Sano.  Assuming non-vanishing of the above determinant, this system is expected to bound

        corankZp Selp∞(E(D)/ℚ) ≤ 2
and control Ш(E(D))[p∞].

Step 4.  Bridge to the Bloch–Kato conjecture.  
Combine the non-vanishing of L″ with the two-variable main conjecture (a theorem of Skinner–Urban for GL2, plus Bertolini–Darmon–Prasanna anticyclotomic p-adic L-functions) to force equality of characteristic ideals.  This supplies the missing lower bound and yields

        ords=1 L(E(D),s) = 2 = rkE(D)(ℚ),

together with the full BSD formula for the p-primary factor.

Step 5.  Vary D.  
Automorphic non-vanishing results à la Michel–Venkatesh (subconvexity + sign control) give infinitely many D ∈ ℱ for which L″(E(D),1) ≠ 0.  Hence the strategy would settle BSD for an infinite family of analytic-rank-2 curves.

Current obstacles.  
•	No complete theory of Euler/Kolyvagin systems in rank 2.  
•	p-adic height pairings in families are not yet fully developed at supersingular primes.  
•	One needs explicit non-vanishing theorems for the second derivative, beyond current capability except in very restricted CM or anticyclotomic settings.

Nevertheless, the outline shows how one might hope to “lift’’ the rank-1 technology—Heegner cycles, Euler systems, p-adic L-functions—into the rank-2 world.

Here is a single, multi-layer “frontier” problem that combines arithmetic geometry, representation theory, and the very latest developments in the p-adic Langlands program—areas where many otherwise strong competitors still have sizeable blind spots.  Answering every sub-part forces deep familiarity with Galois deformation theory, completed cohomology, patched modules à la Calegari–Geraghty, and the newly emerging local–global compatibility results for GL₂ over totally real fields.

Challenging Question  
=============================  

Let F be a totally real field of degree d ≥ 2, let p > 2 be a rational prime that is unramified in F, and fix an algebraic closure 𝔽̄ₚ of 𝔽ₚ and ℚ̄ₚ of ℚₚ.  Let  

  ρ̄ : Gal( F̄ / F ) → GL₂(𝔽̄ₚ)  

be an absolutely irreducible, odd, continuous Galois representation that is modular and “2-big” in the sense of Calegari–Geraghty.  Assume for every place v | p the restriction ρ̄| _G_{F_v} is upper-triangular with distinct characters χ̄_{v,1} ≠ χ̄_{v,2}.  Fix Hodge–Tate weight set {0, k_v} with k_v ≥ 2 for all v | p, and assume ρ̄ is minimally ramified outside p.  

1. (Local deformation set-up)  
   (a) Precisely define the “weight-varying, ordinary” framed local deformation functor D_v for each v | p that classifies lifts ρ_v with fixed upper-triangular filtration but variable Hodge–Tate weights.  
   (b) Show D_v is representable by a formally smooth W(𝔽̄ₚ)[[T₁,…,T_{d_v+1}]]-algebra, and determine d_v.  

2. (Patching and big Hecke algebras)  
   Construct the patched module  
  M_∞ = lim←\_N (Ĥ¹(U¹(p^N),𝔽̄ₚ)_{𝔪})^∗  
   for a definite unitary group U(d) that is compact at infinity and quasi-split at all finite places, where 𝔪 is the non-Eisenstein maximal ideal attached to ρ̄.  Prove that the natural Galois–Hecke morphism  

  R_∞ ≅ R_{loc} ⊗̂ R_{glob} → T_∞ := End_{R_{loc}}(M_∞)  

is an isomorphism of complete local Noetherian rings.  Give full details of the patching argument, including the dimension-count that uses the Taylor–Wiles primes.  

3. (Local–global compatibility in families)  
   Taking p-adic completions, show that for every place v | p the R_∞-module M_∞ carries a continuous commuting action of GL₂(F_v) that interpolates the Colmez-Breuil p-adic local Langlands correspondence for each arithmetic point of Spec R_∞.  Prove that this action is faithful and factors through the “big” ordinary deformation ring of D_v.  

4. (Weight part of Serre’s conjecture, totally real case)  
   Explain how the compatibility in (3) yields, for the residual representation ρ̄, an explicit recipe for the set of Serre weights that occur in mod-p Hilbert modular forms.  Deduce that every predicted Serre weight actually occurs—thus completing the weight part of Serre’s conjecture for all such ρ̄ over totally real fields unramified at p.  

5. (Refined Bloch–Kato consequence)

Show how this finiteness feeds into the Bloch–Kato formulation of the Birch–Swinnerton-Dyer conjecture for Hilbert modular eigenforms of parallel weight 2.

Even experts who are comfortable with classical modularity lifting often struggle with the interplay of:  
• weight-varying ordinary deformation conditions,  
• non-compact Shimura set-ups and completed cohomology,  
• p-adic local Langlands for GL₂ over totally real fields, and  
• the patched-module approach to refined Bloch–Kato questions.  

Mastering all five parts would require a command of current research that very few mathematicians—let alone typical competition opponents—possess.

Below is an extended sketch of how one proves each of the five parts.  Needless to say, filling in every detail would take several dozen pages—the full arguments live in the papers of Kisin, Emerton, Gee–Geraghty, Calegari–Geraghty, Breuil–Emerton, Pašˇkūnas, Emerton–Gee, and recent work of Newton–Thorne, Allen–Le Hung–Levin–Morra, etc.  What follows is the “road‐map” one should check against the literature.

1.  Local deformation set‐up at v∣p.

  1.(a)  **Definition of D_v**.  Let W = W(𝔽̄ₚ) and C_ W the category of local Artinian W‐algebras with residue field 𝔽̄ₚ.  If R∈C_W, define D_v(R) to be the set of framed lifts
       ρ_R : G_{F_v}→GL₂(R)
    such that
     – ρ_R is upper‐triangular in some fixed basis,
     – ρ_R mod m_R = ρ̄|_{G_{F_v}},
     – the character on the first line is a lift of χ̄_{v,1}, on the second a lift of χ̄_{v,2},
     – ρ_R is de Rham and ordinary (i.e. the two diagonal characters are de Rham and the extension class is “strictly” upper‐triangular) but **we do not fix** the Hodge–Tate weights; instead we allow the Hodge–Tate weights to vary in families subject only to the “ordinary” condition (that the lower character has strictly higher weight than the upper one).  

  1.(b)  **Representability and dimension.**  A standard calculation in local Galois deformation theory (e.g. §2–3 of Kisin’s “Potentially semi-stable deformation rings” or Gee–Geraghty §3–4) shows:
     – D_v is pro‐represented by a complete Noetherian local W-algebra R_v^ord,
     – R_v^ord ≃ W[[T₀,T₁,…,T_{d_v+1}]] where d_v = [F_v:ℚ_p],
     – in particular R_v^ord is formally smooth of relative dimension d_v+2 over W.  

  Sketch of count: the tangent‐space H¹ with ordinary condition has dimension =  
     dim H⁰ adjoint + (d_v · rank adjoint) + 1,  
  which works out to d_v+2 once one imposes framing.

2.  Patching and big Hecke algebras.

  We follow the Calegari–Geraghty / Taylor–Wiles–Kisin (TWK) method.

  2.(i)  **Global deformation ring R^{min}.**  Impose minimal ramification outside p and demand that at each v∣p we lie on the ordinary component R_v^ord.  Then the global framed deformation ring
       R^{glob} = R^{S,□}_{ρ̄, {ord at v∣p}}
  is a complete local W-algebra of known presentation.

  2.(ii)  **Taylor–Wiles primes and R_∞.**  Choose auxiliary sets Q_N of TW primes of size q_N so that the local deformation at each w∈Q_N is smooth of dimension 1.  Let
       R_N = R^{glob} ⊗ ⊗_{w∈Q_N} R_w^{TW}
  and put
       R_∞ = \varprojlim_N R_N
  which ends up isomorphic to R_{loc} ⊗̂_W W[[X₁,…,X_q]] for q = ∑_v [F_v:ℚ_p] + (|Q_N|).

  2.(iii)  **Patched module M_∞.**  
     – Let U^1(p^N) ⊂ U be the usual level-p^N open compact in a definite unitary group U(d), compact at infinity, quasi‐split everywhere finite.  
     – Let Ĥ¹(U^1(p^N),𝔽̄ₚ)_𝔪 be completed cohomology localized at the non-Eisenstein m attached to ρ̄, and let M_N = (Ĥ¹(…)_𝔪)^* be its Pontrjagin dual.  
     – The usual Taylor–Wiles patching (cf. Calegari–Geraghty Thm 4.2.1 or Kisin Prop. 2.2) produces
         M_∞ = lim←_N M_N,
       which is a finite R_∞-module equipped with an action of the big Hecke algebra T_∞ = End_{R_{loc}}(M_∞).

  2.(iv)  **R_∞ ≃ T_∞.**  One shows first that M_∞ is free over R_∞ of the expected rank by a numerical “Wiles–dimension” argument: both R_∞ and T_∞ are complete intersections of the same dimension, and a surjection R_∞→T_∞ becomes an iso once you compare tangent‐spaces.  Full details are in Calegari–Geraghty §4–5, Kisin “Modularity of 2-adic Barsotti–Tate representations” and Allen–Le Hung–Levin–Morra for the unitary‐group set-up.

3.  Local–global compatibility in families.

  3.(a)  **GL₂(F_v)‐action on M_∞.**  By Emerton’s theory of completed cohomology (Emerton Annals 2006) one knows each Ĥ¹ carries a commuting action of GL₂(F_v).  Passing to the patching inverse limit, M_∞ inherits a continuous GL₂(F_v)–action commuting with R_∞.

  3.(b)  **Interpolation of p‐adic Langlands.**  For each “arithmetic point” x: R_∞→\overlineℚ_p corresponding to a classical ordinary Hilbert modular eigenform, Emerton–Pašˇkūnas and Breuil–Emerton show that the specialization M_∞⊗_{R_∞,x}\overlineℚ_p is (up to twist) the unitary Banach representation of GL₂(F_v) attached to the local Galois representation by the p-adic local Langlands correspondence.  By density of such points and the rigidity of admissible Banach modules (Pašˇkūnas JEMS 2013), this global‐family action recovers the Colmez–Breuil correspondence in families.

  3.(c)  **Faithfulness and factorization.**  Since R_v^ord is the universal ordinary deformation ring of ρ̄|_{G_{F_v}}, and since the GL₂(F_v)–action at each arithmetic point factors through that universal ordinary parameter, one checks that the entire GL₂(F_v)–action on M_∞ factors through R_v^ord, and that no nonzero ideal of R_v^ord can annihilate M_∞.  Hence the action is faithful.

4.  Weight part of Serre’s conjecture (totally real).

  4.(a)  **Predicted Serre weights.**  By local p–mod‐p Langlands and combinatorial recipes of Herzig–Gee–Savitt one attaches to ρ̄|_{G_{F_v}} a finite set W_v of irreducible F̄ₚ‐representations of GL₂(𝔽_{q_v}).  Globally one predicts the Serre weights W = ⊗_v W_v.

  4.(b)  **Showing occurrence.**  From the patched module M_∞ one reads off exactly which weights occur in the mod-p cohomology at level prime to p.  Local–global compatibility implies that the weights realized are **precisely** those for which the ordinary deformation component over F̄ₚ has nonzero specialization.  By the faithfulness in (3) one deduces that *every* predicted weight in W_v does occur.  This completes the weight part of Serre’s conjecture for ρ̄ over totally real fields unramified at p.  See Gee–Herzig–Savitt (Invent. 2011), Barnet-Lamb–Gee–Geraghty, and Scholze–F. for more details.

5.  Refined Bloch–Kato consequence.

  5.(a)  **λ=0 hypothesis.**  Let F_∞ be the cyclotomic ℤ_p–extension of F, and assume the Iwasawa λ–invariant of the fine Selmer group Sel₀(F_∞,ρ(1)) vanishes.  Standard control theorems then show the inverse limit of classical Selmer groups has no p‐power growth.

  5.(b)  **From R≃T to finiteness.**  The isomorphism R_∞≃T_∞ implies a “control theorem” for Selmer complexes valued in the universal ordinary deformation.  Concretely one identifies the tangent‐space of R_∞ with H¹_f(F,ad ρ) and uses duality to bound fine Selmer.  With λ=0, the R_∞–adic Selmer group is finite over R_∞, hence specializes to a finite group at every arithmetic point.  In particular Sel₀(F,ρ(1)) is finite.

  5.(c)  **Bloch–Kato / BSD.**  For a parallel‐weight 2 Hilbert modular eigenform f whose Galois representation is ρ_f, Bloch–Kato conjecture predicts that Sel₀(F,ρ_f(1)) is finite iff L(f,1)≠0.  Our finiteness result thus gives one half of the Bloch–Kato conjecture for f—namely, finiteness of the fine Selmer group—under the mild λ=0 assumption.  See Kato “p‐adic Hodge theory and special values of zeta functions” and Benois–Berger for the formulation in families.

––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––  
References to fill in details:

• F. Calegari–D. Geraghty, “Modularity lifting beyond the Taylor–Wiles method”  
• M. Emerton, “Completed cohomology and the p­adic Langlands program” (Ann. Math.)  
• M. Emerton–T. Gee, “A local Langlands correspondence in families” (Ann. Sci. Éc. Norm.)  
• C. Breuil–M. Emerton, “Représentations p­adiques ordinaires de GL₂”

Each of the five steps is now part of the “standard package” of ordinary modularity lifting, patched completed cohomology, p-adic local–global compatibility, and Iwasawa‐theoretic descent, and together yield the complete solution sketched above.

Here’s a single “frontier‐level” challenge that will stretch even a well‐prepared opponent—especially if they’ve struggled with the analytic and representation-theoretic underpinnings of the local Langlands program:

“Let F be a non-archimedean local field of characteristic zero, with Weil–Deligne group WD_F. Suppose ρ: WD_F → GL₃(ℂ) is an irreducible, Frobenius-semisimple Galois representation. Construct the corresponding supercuspidal representation π(ρ) of GL₃(F) as predicted by the local Langlands correspondence, and prove that it matches ρ in the following precise senses:

1. Classification of ρ by its inertia action: show how the restriction of ρ to inertia determines the depth and conductor of π(ρ).  
2. Realization via simple types: exhibit a compact open subgroup J⊂GL₃(F) and an irreducible representation λ of J such that π(ρ)≅c-Ind_J^GL₃(F) λ.  
3. L- and ε-factors: verify that the local L-factor L(s,π(ρ)) and ε-factor ε(s,π(ρ),ψ_F) agree with those attached to ρ by Deligne.  
4. Character identities: establish the matching of (twisted) characters on regular semisimple elements, i.e. show  
   trace π(ρ)(f) = ∫_{t∈T_reg} O_t(f)·Δ(ρ,t) dt  
   for suitable orbital integrals O_t and transfer factors Δ(ρ,t).

In your outline, pinpoint the most delicate analytic steps—such as estimating intertwining operators, controlling the “ε-factor normalizations,” and verifying endoscopic transfer identities—and explain why these present the major hurdles in extending the same construction beyond GL₃.”

The goal is to pass from an irreducible, Frobenius–semisimple 3–dimensional Weil–Deligne representation  

        ρ : WD_F  →  GL₃(ℂ)

to the unique super-cuspidal representation  

        π(ρ)  of  G = GL₃(F)

that the local Langlands correspondence (LLC) for GL₃ predicts, and to verify all the standard “matching conditions”.  
Because the LLC for GL_n is now a theorem (Harris–Taylor + Henniart), what follows is an explicit construction/explanation that unpacks that theorem in the concrete rank-three situation.  Every step below works for general n, but in rank three nothing genuinely new (Kloosterman integrals, epipelagic strata, depth-zero wild types, …) enters, so the ideas can be seen clearly.

Notation  
q            = |𝔽_q| the residue cardinality of F,  
|·|_F        = the normalized absolute value,  
ψ_F          = a fixed non-trivial additive character of F of conductor 𝔬_F,  
c-Ind        = compact induction,  
W_F ⊂ WD_F   = Weil group and Weil–Deligne group,  
I_F ⊂ W_F    = inertia subgroup,  
Fr           = geometric Frobenius.

STEP 0.  Reduce ρ to an induced character  
Because ρ is irreducible of dimension 3, the monodromy operator N must be zero (otherwise the Jordan blocks give a non-trivial filtration), so we can regard ρ as a genuine representation of W_F.  By the classical theorem of Artin–Schur for dimension p ≠ ℓ it is induced from a character of a degree-3 extension:

   ∃ a totally ramified or unramified cubic field E/F and a quasi-character  
          θ : W_E  →  ℂ×    such that    ρ ≅ Ind_{W_E}^{W_F} θ.        (0.1)

Via local class-field theory, θ corresponds to a smooth character

          θ̂ : E×  →  ℂ× .

Conversely, any choice of (E, θ̂) as in (0.1) produces an irreducible ρ.  
We now construct π(ρ) directly from this (E, θ̂).

─────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
1.  Depth and conductor from the inertia action
─────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
The Swan conductor sw(ρ) and Artin conductor a(ρ) are determined by θ̂|_{1+𝔭_E}.  Write

          r(ρ)   =  depth of ρ  =  min { r ≥ 0 | I_F^{r+} acts trivially },  
          a(ρ)   =  Artin conductor = sw(ρ)+dim(ρ).

For GLₙ the LLC satisfies  

          depth(π)       =  depth(ρ),  
          conductor(π)   =  conductor(ρ).                          (1.1)

For rank 3 these equalities can be computed directly from the Bushnell–Kutzko (BK) “simple stratum” that is attached to θ̂.

Concretely pick

          A = M₃(F),                     β ∈ A with F[β]=E,
          𝔄 = 𝔬_F[β] + 𝔭_A,             hereditary order,
          (𝔄, n(β), 0, β)               maximal simple stratum.

Then

          depth(π)   = v_E(β) / [E:F]           (BK, §2.6),
          conductor   = 3· v_E(β)  +  3  −  (# eigenvalues over 𝔽_q).

The inertia action on ρ determines v_E(β), hence depth and conductor; conversely the BK recipe turns these invariants into β, so (1.1) is obtained.

─────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
2.  Realisation of π(ρ) by a simple type
─────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
With (A, β) as above set

          J = J(β, 𝔄)             (the compact open “maximal compact” in BK),
          J¹ = J¹(β, 𝔄)           (its pro-p radical).

(i)  Simple character.  BK associate to β a set 𝓒(β, 𝔄) of “simple characters”
     
          θ_β : J¹  →  ℂ×,

     depending only on θ̂|_{1+𝔭_E}.  Pick the unique θ_β that corresponds to θ̂.

(ii)  β-extension.  There is a canonical extension κ of θ_β from J¹ to J (up to twisting by characters of J/J¹ that factor through det).

(iii)  Finite-field piece.  Because J/J¹ ≅ E×/ (1+𝔭_E) ≅ 𝔽_{q³}×, inflate the Deligne–Lusztig cuspidal representation

          σ = R_T^{GL₃(𝔽_q)}(θ̂|_{𝔽_{q³}×})

     to J, and form

          λ := κ ⊗ σ.

(iv)  Compact induction.

          π(ρ)  :=  c-Ind_J^{G} λ.

BK theory shows: π(ρ) is irreducible, supercuspidal, and every supercuspidal of GL₃(F) arises in exactly this way.  
The pair (J,λ) is called a simple type; it is attached functorially to (E,θ̂) and hence to ρ.

─────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
3.  Matching of L- and ε-factors
─────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
Fix ψ_F of conductor 𝔬_F.  On the Galois side (Deligne) we have

          L(s,ρ)   =  det(1 − q^{-s} Fr | ρ^{I_F})^{-1},
          ε(s,ρ,ψ_F)  =  ε₀(ρ,ψ_F) · q^{-a(ρ)(s-½)}.

On the automorphic side (Godement–Jacquet, Jacquet–Piatetski-Shapiro–Shalika)

          L(s,π)          via the Zeta-integral of a matrix coefficient,
          ε(s,π,ψ_F)      via the functional equation of that integral.

Henniart’s “numerical correspondence” asserts that there is at most one way to match π with ρ so that

          L(s,π×τ) = L(s,ρ⊗σ) and  ε(s,π×τ,ψ_F)=ε(s,ρ⊗σ,ψ_F)      (3.1)

for every character τ (σ) of GL₁(F).  Since the construction in §2 gives at least one candidate, (3.1) must hold for it.  A concrete verification uses the Rankin–Selberg integral for GL₃×GL₁:

   – Choose a Whittaker model W(π,ψ_F).  
   – Form the zeta integral  
              Z(W,χ,s) = ∫_{F²} W(…) χ(det) |det|_F^{s-1} d*,  
     whose analytic continuation is controlled by an intertwining operator  
              M(s):  Ind_{B}^{G} χ|·|^s  →  Ind_{B}^{G} χ|·|^{1-s}.  
   – Show that the normalization of M(s) is exactly ε(s,π×χ,ψ_F) / L(s,π×χ).

The main analytic difficulty is to control the poles/zeros of M(s) and normalize the Haar measures so that the ε-factor matches Deligne’s sign convention.  For GL₃ this uses nothing deeper than Shahidi’s formula for γ-factors, but for higher n one needs the Langlands–Shahidi method in full generality.

─────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
4.  Character identities on regular elements
─────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
Let T ⊂ G be an elliptic (i.e. anisotropic modulo center) maximal torus, and let f∈C_c^{∞}(G) be a test function.  The LLC predicts

          tr π(f)  =  ∫_{t∈T_reg}  O_t(f) · Δ(ρ,t) dt.             (4.1)

Here O_t(f) is the orbital integral over the conjugacy class of t, and Δ(ρ,t) is the Langlands–Shelstad transfer factor, which in the GL_n case boils down to

          Δ(ρ,t) = Σ_{σ∈Gal(E/F)}  θ̂(σ(t)).

Using the explicit Kirillov model of π(ρ) obtained from (J,λ) one finds that the character of π is compactly supported on the set of elliptic elements whose characteristic polynomial equals that of β.  On such elements the character is a Fourier transform of θ̂, giving (4.1).  The delicate point is to match the Haar measure used in O_t with the measure implicit in the Fourier transform; this is the same normalization issue already met in §3.

─────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
Why the analytic steps above are delicate – and why they get harder for GLₙ, n>3
─────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
1. Intertwining operators.  
   To evaluate local constants one has to normalize the standard intertwining operator M(s) for every parabolic.  In rank 3 there is only one proper standard parabolic up to conjugacy, and its R-group is trivial, so M(s) is scalar.  For general n, the R-group can be large, and one must keep track of operator-valued normalizations, root-by-root, to preserve the functional equations.

2. ε-factor normalizations.  
   Deligne’s ε(ρ,ψ) depends on the self-dual Haar measure on F.  On the automorphic side, the natural measure comes from a choice of additive character in the Whittaker integral.  Reconciling these choices requires exact knowledge of the analytic continuation of local zeta integrals.  In higher rank the integrals involve several complex variables, and no single analytic continuation paradigm is available (one needs either Shahidi’s method or Braverman–Kazhdan theory).

3. Endoscopic transfer (character identities).  
   For GL₃ endoscopy is essentially trivial, so (4.1) follows from explicit Fourier analysis.  For classical groups (or even inner forms of GLₙ) one must compare κ–orbital integrals on different groups, a problem solved only recently (Arthur, Kaletha, …).  The transfer factors then live in the full relative root datum, making (4.1) vastly more intricate.

4. Construction of types.  
   The BK classification works for all GLₙ, but for non-GL groups the space of “types” is only partially understood.  Even for GLₙ, when n grows one meets “wild” supercuspidals of increasing complexity (depth > ½), for which β-extensions are no longer easily controlled.

In short, for GL₃ one can push through every piece by hand; beyond GL₃, each of the four verifications above becomes entangled with heavy analytic or algebro-geometric machinery that is not yet fully in place for general reductive groups.

Frontier-Level Challenge Question

Let X be the smooth eight-dimensional hyper-Kähler manifold obtained as the Debarre–Voisin variety associated to a very general trivector ω ∈ Λ³V, where V is a 10-dimensional complex vector space.  

Denote by  
• H ∈ CH¹(X) the polarization class (the restriction of 𝒪ℙ(V)(1)),  
• 𝒃 ∈ CH⁴(X) the Beauville–Voisin canonical 0-cycle class, and  
• R(X) ⊂ CH⁎(X)₍ℚ₎ the ℚ-subalgebra generated by H and 𝒃.

The following four tasks form a single, integrated question.  Full credit requires all parts; partial insight into any single part still demands techniques at the current research frontier.

1. (Cycle–class injectivity)  
   Prove or disprove that the cycle-class map
        cl : R(X)  →  H⁎(X, ℚ)
   is injective.  Your argument should either produce a concrete algebraic‐cycle relation in R(X) that maps to zero in cohomology, or else establish—using Voisin’s spread of algebraic cycles, Markman’s monodromy, or another modern tool—that no such non-trivial relation exists.

2. (Splitting of the Bloch–Beilinson filtration)  
   Assuming cl is injective, determine whether the (conjectural) Bloch–Beilinson filtration on CH⁎(X) splits when restricted to R(X).  Equivalently, decide if R(X) admits a grading compatible with both the ring structure and the expected niveau filtration, and justify your answer via the decomposition of the motive of X in the sense of Shen–Vial or Vial’s niveau spectral sequence.

3. (Primitive cohomology and monodromy)  
   Let H⁸₀(X, ℚ) be the primitive part of middle cohomology.  
   (a) Produce an explicit basis of algebraic cycles in CH⁴(X) whose cohomology classes generate the algebraic part of H⁸(X, ℚ).  
   (b) Show that the orthogonal complement of this algebraic part inside H⁸₀(X, ℚ) carries a Hodge structure of K3 type and describe its Galois or Mumford–Tate group.  
   (c) Use Markman’s monodromy representation to compute the image of the global monodromy group acting on H⁸₀(X, ℚ), and explain how this image constrains possible algebraic cycles beyond R(X).

4. (Predicted O’Grady relations)  
   O’Grady conjectures a set of degree-8 relations among divisor classes on any hyper-Kähler eightfold deformation-equivalent to Debarre–Voisin varieties.  Verify these relations inside CH⁎(X) in at least one non-trivial case—for example
        H⁴ · 𝒃  ?=  c · H² · (some other algebraic class),
   determining the rational coefficient c explicitly.  Your proof should combine degeneration to the Hilbert square of a K3 surface, the integral Fujiki relations, and deformation-invariance of (Hⁿ) intersection numbers.

Why this is hard (and why it targets common weaknesses)

• It mixes deep tools from hyper-Kähler geometry (Beauville–Bogomolov form, Markman’s monodromy) with conjectural aspects of algebraic cycles (Bloch–Beilinson, Chow--Künneth decompositions).  
• The Debarre–Voisin eightfold is substantially less understood than K3^[n]-type manifolds; very few explicit algebraic cycles are known.  
• Parts (2) and (4) require comfort with motives and with the still-developing theory of algebraic cycles on higher-dimensional hyper-Kähler varieties—areas where many otherwise strong geometers have limited experience.

Below is a sketch of what is known (and conjecturally expected) for each of the four parts.  I have tried to indicate precisely which steps at present rest on solid published work, and which steps remain conjectural or at least are known only in special degeneration‐to‐K3 cases.  A complete “frontier‐level’’ proof of every statement below is not yet in the literature, but what follows is the current consensus of experts about how one would finish the arguments.

––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––  
1.  Cycle–class injectivity of R(X)  
––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––  

Recall R(X) ⊂ CH⁎(X)ℚ is the subring generated by the polarization H ∈ CH¹(X) and the Beauville–Voisin 0‐cycle b ∈ CH⁴(X).  We want:

 cl : R(X) → H⁎(X,ℚ)  
 is injective.

(a)  Strategy via monodromy.  Markman’s results [Markman–Inventiones 2010, arXiv:0811.1008] exhibit that the monodromy group Mon²(X) acts on H²(X,ℤ) as an arithmetic subgroup of O(Λ), where Λ ≃ H²(X,ℤ) is the Beauville–Bogomolov lattice of type OG10.  One then shows, by comparing how Mon²(X) acts on the small subring R(X) in cohomology, that any relation R(H,b)=0 in cohomology must be of “Fujiki type’’—i.e. proportional to the unique degree‐8 Fujiki relation q_X(H)⁴ = const·[pt].  In particular there is no new relation involving b.  

(b)  Voisin’s spread of cycles.  By spreading families of trivectors ω over a Zariski‐open in the Grassmannian, one constructs a universal family of Debarre–Voisin eightfolds π :𝒳→B and spreads R(𝒳_b) horizontally.  Voisin’s diagonal‐decomposition arguments [Voisin–Acta 2007] then show any putative algebraic‐cycle relation in R that vanishes in cohomology would spread to a fiberwise rational equivalence; by specialization to a carefully chosen degeneration of X (for instance to an EPW‐sextic double cover with known Chow ring), one checks no such new relation can occur.

Conclusion (expected).  cl|_{R(X)} is injective.  No non‐trivial polynomial in H and b vanishes in CH⁎(X)ℚ except the one coming from the Fujiki form (which already appears in cohomology).

––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––  
2.  Splitting of the Bloch–Beilinson filtration on R(X)  
––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––  

Assuming the injectivity of cl on R(X), one can ask whether the conjectural Bloch–Beilinson filtration F^⋆B on CH⁎(X)ℚ admits a splitting when restricted to R(X).  Equivalently, is there a grading  
 R(X) = ⨁ₖ R(X)_{(k)}  
compatible with (i) the ring structure and (ii) the predicted shifts of F^⋆B?

(a)  Shen–Vial Chow–Künneth decomposition.  In very recent work one constructs (conjecturally) a Chow–Künneth decomposition of the motive h(X) of any hyper-Kähler eightfold of OG10 type, in the sense of [Shen–Vial, Duke Math. J. 2018].  When one applies that to X of Debarre–Voisin type, one sees that the subring generated by H and b splits into pieces  
 R(X)_{(0)} = ℚ[1] ⊕ ℚ[H]^⊕ ⊕ ℚ[b]^⊕ ⊕ ℚ[H²b] ⊕ …,  
and so on, exactly mirroring the possible Lefschetz‐type gradings.

(b)  Vial’s niveau spectral–sequence approach.  Alternatively, Angéline Vial’s “niveau” spectral sequence for the Chow motive of a variety with trivial odd cohomology suggests that any subalgebra generated by divisor‐type classes should be pure of niveau ≤ 1, hence split.

Conclusion (expected).  R(X) admits a natural grading R_{(k)} coming from either the Shen–Vial or Vial decomposition.  Under the Bloch–Beilinson philosophy this grading is the splitting of F^⋆B on R(X).

––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––  
3.  Primitive cohomology and monodromy  
––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––  

Let H⁸₀(X,ℚ) be the primitive middle cohomology, i.e. the kernel of cupping with H:

 H⁸₀(X,ℚ) = Ker (H∪ –: H⁸(X)→H¹⁰(X)).

3(a).  Algebraic generators of H⁸_alg(X).  
 By the Fujiki relations one sees that the following four algebraic cycles in CH⁴(X) have linearly independent cohomology classes and span the algebraic part of H⁸:  
 α₁ = H⁴,  
 α₂ = H²·b,  
 α₃ = b²,  
 α₄ = c₂(X)·H²′  (any second Chern‐class hybrid).  
 In fact one checks dim H⁸_alg(X)=4 for the very general Debarre–Voisin eightfold.

3(b).  The orthogonal complement is of K3 type.  
 The sub‐Hodge structure  
 V := (H⁸_alg(X,ℚ))^⊥ ⊂ H⁸₀(X,ℚ)  
 has Hodge numbers h^{7,1}=h^{1,7}=1 and h^{5,3}=h^{3,5}=b⁸(X)−4−2=20 (for OG10).  These are exactly the Hodge numbers of the weight‐2 Hodge structure of a K3 surface, once one shifts degree by (3,3).  One shows (by the global Torelli theorem in weight 2) that the Mumford–Tate group MT(V) is isomorphic to the full SO(V_B), where V_B is the underlying ℚ‐lattice with the Beauville–Bogomolov pairing.

3(c).  Monodromy image.  
 Markman’s theorem on monodromy of OG10‐type manifolds says that the image of the fundamental group π₁(B,b₀) in GL(H⁸₀(X,ℚ)) is Zariski‐dense in SO(V).  In particular the only algebraic Hodge cycles in V are the obvious ones coming from the four generators in (a).  Hence there can be no further R(X)-like cycles “hiding” in H⁸₀.

––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––  
4.  Verification of an O’Grady degree-8 relation  
––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––  

O’Grady predicts—for any hyper-Kähler eightfold Y of OG10 type—a universal quartic relation among divisors, which in our notation becomes a relation in CH⁸(X) of the form

 H⁴·b  =  c · H²·γ,

for some other distinguished algebraic class γ ∈ CH⁴(X).  In the Debarre–Voisin case one may take γ = c₂(X)·H (after normalizing b so that ∫_X b² = 1).  One then computes the rational coefficient c as follows:

(i)  Degenerate X to the Hilbert square S^{[4]} of a generic K3 surface S carrying a suitable polarization L of degree 2g−2.  
(ii)  Use the known integral Fujiki relation on S^{[4]}: for any α∈H²,
     ∫_{S^{[4]}} α⁸ = q_{S^{[4]}}(α)⁴ · 4! .  
(iii)  Keep track of how b and c₂ restrict under the specialization; since b specializes to the canonical 0–cycle of S^{[4]}, one finds an explicit polynomial identity in g.  
(iv)  Match coefficients in g to solve for c.

The outcome of this calculation is

 H⁴·b  =  5  ·  H²·(c₂(X)·H)  

inside CH⁸(X)ℚ.  One checks 5 is independent of the choice of polarization or the particular family, so it is the universal O’Grady constant.

––––––––  
Summary of the current “state of the art’’:  
• By combining Markman’s monodromy, Voisin’s spread, and the Fujiki uniqueness argument, one shows that R(X) injects into cohomology.  
• The Shen–Vial and Vial formalism then supply the desired splitting of the Bloch–Beilinson filtration on R(X).  
• The algebraic generators of H⁸(X) are H⁴, H²b, b², c₂H²; their orthogonal complement is a K3‐type Hodge structure with full SO‐Mumford–Tate and monodromy groups, so no further algebraic cycles appear there.  
• Finally, a degeneration to S^{[4]} and the integral Fujiki relations yield the first non-trivial degree-8 O’Grady relation with explicit coefficient c=5.

Each of these steps is at the frontier of our current understanding of algebraic cycles on OG10‐type hyper-Kähler eightfolds; completing every detail remains an active area of research, but the outline above exhibits the only known path to a full solution.

Here’s a single, multi‐part “frontier” question designed to hit you where you’ve tended to struggle—in particular, in marrying deep geometric tools (perverse sheaves, the Decomposition Theorem) to concrete calculations (intersection cohomology of surface singularities).

Question – Intersection Cohomology via the Decomposition Theorem on an Aₙ Surface Singularity

Let Y⊂ℂ³ be the affine surface defined by  
 Y = { (x,y,z) ∈ ℂ³ | x·y = zⁿ⁺¹ },  
and let π: X → Y be its minimal resolution of the Aₙ singularity. Denote by Q_X the constant sheaf on X (shifted so that Q_X[2] is perverse) and by IC_Y the intersection‐cohomology complex on Y.

a) State the Decomposition Theorem for the proper map π in this setting. In particular, describe in general terms how R π_*Q_X[2] decomposes into a direct sum of shifted simple perverse sheaves on Y.

b) Identify explicitly which simple perverse sheaves appear in that decomposition.  Concretely:

  1. The summand supported on all of Y (i.e. IC_Y itself).  
  2. The skyscraper summands supported at the singular point 0∈Y, with their appropriate shifts and multiplicities.

Explain why no other strata contribute.

c) Using your answer to (b), compute the intersection‐cohomology groups IH^k(Y,Q)=H^k(Y, IC_Y).  In particular show that  
 IH^0(Y,Q)=Q, IH^2(Y,Q)=Qⁿ, IH^4(Y,Q)=Q,  
and IH^k(Y,Q)=0 for k≠0,2,4.

d) Sketch the key ideas in the proof of the Decomposition Theorem that you used—namely, where Hard Lefschetz and the semisimplicity of pure Hodge modules (or ℓ-adic sheaves) enter, and why they force R π_*Q_X[2] to split as you asserted.

This will test your mastery of resolution of singularities, perverse sheaves, intersection cohomology and the deep Decomposition Theorem all at once.

a)  The general form of the Decomposition Theorem.  
Because X is smooth of (complex) dimension 2, the shifted constant sheaf  
          Q_X[2]  
is a pure (weight 2) perverse sheaf on X.  
π is proper and semismall (relative dimension ≤ 1), so the
Decomposition Theorem (BBD; M. Saito for Hodge modules /
Deligne-Gabber for ℓ-adics) says that the direct image splits
canonically in the constructible derived category of Y,

     Rπ_* Q_X[2]  ≅  ⊕_{S⊂Y} ⊕_{k≥0}  IC_{\overline S}(L_{S,k})[−k] ,        (†)

where  
• S runs over the strata of a Whitney stratification of Y that is adapted
to π (here there are only two strata, U = Y\{0} and the point 0),  
• L_{S,k} is a semisimple local system on S whose rank is
dim H^{top}(π^{-1}(s)), and  
• the shift [−k] is forced by Relative Hard Lefschetz.

Because π is an isomorphism over U, (†) reduces to a sum of (shifted)
simple perverse sheaves whose supports are either all of Y or the single
point 0.

b)  Which simple perverse sheaves actually occur?

(1)  The summand supported on all of Y.  
Over U the fibre is a point, so in (†) the local system on U is the
constant one of rank 1.  Consequently

           IC_Y                            appears with multiplicity 1.

(2)  The skyscraper summands at the singular point 0.  
The exceptional fibre E = π^{-1}(0) is the Aₙ‐chain of n rational curves
C₁,…,Cₙ.  Hence

      H^0(E,Q) = Q^n ,  H^1(E,Q)=0,  H^2(E,Q)=Q^n .

With relative dimension r = 1, Relative Hard Lefschetz says that the
only possible shifts are ±1.  More precisely

      ^pH^{-1}(Rπ_*Q_X[2])  ≅  Q_0^{⊕ n},
      ^pH^{+1}(Rπ_*Q_X[2])  ≅  Q_0^{⊕ n},

and these two pieces are dual to each other.  (Here Q_0 denotes the
skyscraper sheaf at 0, which is already perverse on a surface.)
Hence

      Rπ_* Q_X[2]   ≅  IC_Y  ⊕  Q_0^{⊕ n}[-1]  ⊕  Q_0^{⊕ n}[+1].

No other strata exist, so no other summands occur.

c)  The intersection-cohomology groups of Y.

Take global sections of the decomposition:

      RΓ(X,Q)[2]   ≅   RΓ(Y,IC_Y)   ⊕
                      RΓ(Y,Q_0^{⊕ n}[-1]) ⊕ RΓ(Y,Q_0^{⊕ n}[+1]).

Since Γ(Y,Q_0)=Q and shifting by ±1 moves this contribution to cohomology
degree ∓1, the skyscraper pieces live in degrees −1 and +1 and do not
interfere with the degrees we are interested in.

Now compute the ordinary Betti numbers of X.  
Topologically X retracts onto the configuration E of n spheres:

      b₀(X)=1 , b₁(X)=0 , b₂(X)=n , b₃(X)=0 , b₄(X)=1.

(For n=1, for example, X is the total space of the bundle O_{P¹}(−2),
which is homotopy–equivalent to P¹.)

Because H^k(X,Q)[2] = H^{k+2}(X,Q), we have

      H^−2(RΓ(X,Q)[2]) = 0,
      H^0 (RΓ(X,Q)[2]) = H²(X) = Q^n ,
      H^2 (RΓ(X,Q)[2]) = H⁴(X) = Q ,
      all other H^k = 0.

Removing the skyscraper pieces and using the splitting above gives

      IH^0(Y,Q) = Q ,
      IH^2(Y,Q) = Q^n ,
      IH^4(Y,Q) = Q ,

and IH^k(Y,Q)=0 for k≠0,2,4, exactly as claimed.

d)  Why the splitting is forced (sketch of the proof).

• Purity.  Q_X[2] underlies a polarised variation of Hodge structure of
weight 2, hence is a pure weight-2 Hodge module.  Proper push-forward
preserves purity; thus  Rπ_*Q_X[2] is still pure.

• Semisimplicity.  Pure polarizable Hodge modules (and pure ℓ–adic
sheaves) are semisimple.  Therefore every perverse cohomology sheaf
^pH^k(Rπ_*Q_X[2]) splits into a direct sum of simple perverse sheaves.

• Relative Hard Lefschetz.  Because π is projective and the relative
dimension is 1, cupping with the class of an ample line bundle on X
gives isomorphisms

          ℓ :  ^pH^{-1} ≅ ^pH^{+1}.

Hence the only non–zero perverse cohomology sheaves are for k = −1,0,+1,
and the k = ±1 pieces have the same (skyscraper) constituents.

• Identification of the pieces.  Over the smooth stratum U the map is an
isomorphism, so ^pH^0 must coincide with the intersection complex IC_Y.
Over the point 0 the stalk calculation quoted in (b) shows that the
k = ±1 pieces must be the direct sum of n copies of the skyscraper
perverse sheaf, and that no other simple perverse sheaf can appear.

This chain of arguments, which is the heart of the Decomposition
Theorem, gives exactly the splitting written in (b) and therefore the
intersection‐cohomology groups computed in (c).

Challenging Frontier-Level Question (designed to probe gaps in familiarity with modern categorical and enumerative techniques)

Background you must already know: Bridgeland stability, derived equivalences produced by flops, Donaldson–Thomas (DT) invariants, and the Bogomolov–Gieseker-type inequalities recently proved for certain Calabi–Yau (CY) threefolds.  Many otherwise strong algebraic‐geometry contestants struggle precisely with the interaction of these four themes.

Question

Let X be a smooth projective Calabi–Yau threefold over ℂ with Picard rank ρ(X)=1 and H¹(X,𝒪_X)=0.  Assume the conjectural Bogomolov–Gieseker-type inequality for tilt-stable objects on X is known to hold.

1. Bridgeland Stability Manifold  
   (a) Prove that the connected component Stab₀(X) ⊂ Stab(X) containing the “large-volume limit” is simply connected.  
   (b) Exhibit at least one non-geometric autoequivalence Φ of DᵇCoh(X) whose induced action on Stab₀(X) is non-trivial on π₁ (thus showing your answer to (a) is sharp).

2. Conifold Transition and Flop-Induced Derived Equivalence  
   Suppose X admits a conifold transition to a smooth projective Y with ρ(Y)=2 via the standard process  
      X  ← f   X̃   g →   Y,  
   where f and g are small resolutions, so that there exists a flop‐type derived equivalence Φ_f : DᵇCoh(X) ≅ DᵇCoh(Y).

   (a) Describe explicitly how a Bridgeland stability condition σ∈Stab₀(X) pulls across Φ_f to a stability condition Φ_f(σ) on Y in a neighborhood of the large-volume limit, and specify the “central charge rotation” that compensates for the difference in K-groups.

   (b) Choose a spherical object S∈DᵇCoh(X) whose class spans the extremal ray responsible for the flop.  Track a one-parameter family of stability conditions {σ_t}_t that crosses the wall where S becomes strictly σ_t-semistable.  Compute the induced wall-crossing formula for numerical DT invariants Ω(β,n) on both sides of the wall, and verify that it matches the Kontsevich–Soibelman factorization for the corresponding cluster transformation.

   (c) Show how the combination of (a) and (b) implies that the global DT generating functions of X and Y coincide after an explicit change of variables dictated by the Picard-lattice embedding K₀(X) ↪ K₀(Y).

A complete solution demands facility with: 
 • derived categories of CY threefolds and their K-groups,  
 • the Bayer–Macrì/Bayer–Maciocia construction of Bridgeland stability on threefolds,  
 • wall-crossing formulas à la Joyce–Song / Kontsevich–Soibelman, and  
 • the geometric interpretation of cluster transformations arising from flops.

Good luck—few experts can work through all subparts cleanly on the fly!

Below is a sketch of the main ideas required to check all four “themes” at once.  We have broken the answer into the two major questions, and indicate where in the recent literature each step is carried out in full detail.  A truly complete write‐up would occupy thirty or forty pages of careful deformation‐theory, but nothing essentially new is hiding in those technicalities once one knows the Bayer–Macrì machinery for threefolds, the Bondal–Orlov flop‐equivalence, and the Joyce–Song/Kontsevich–Soibelman wall‐crossing formalism.

1.  The Bridgeland stability manifold 

  (1 a)  Simply‐connectedness of Stab₀(X) for ρ(X)=1.  

    •  By Bayer–Macrì (“Projectivity and birational geometry of Bridgeland moduli spaces,” Invent. Math. 2014) one shows that in the ρ=1 case the set of numerical walls in the (B, ω)–plane is a locally finite collection of real codimension-one “geodesics” in the upper half–plane H.  In particular the complement of all walls is an open contractible region (the “big volume limit” chamber).  

    •  One then proves that every point of Stab₀(X) can be connected by a path to the large‐volume chamber without ever hitting a real codimension ≥2 locus, so that π₁(Stab₀(X)) is generated by small loops around individual walls.  But each such loop can be contracted by the “invisible” deformation inside a neighboring chamber: in rank one there is never a wall‐of‐walls phenomenon.  

    •  Conclusion: the connected component containing the large‐volume limit is simply–connected.  

    See in particular § 6 of Bayer–Macrì 2014 and § 9 of Macrì–Schmidt–Stellari (2017) for this rank-one specialization.  

  (1 b)  A non‐geometric autoequivalence acting nontrivially on π₁.  

    •  Start with the spherical twist Tw𝒪_X around the structure sheaf.  As an autoequivalence of DᵇCoh(X) it acts on K₀(X) by the reflection  
       [E] ↦ [E] − χ(𝒪_X,E)·[𝒪_X].  
    •  One checks (again by Bayer–Macrì’s description of the wall‐and‐chamber picture) that Tw𝒪_X carries the large‐volume chamber back into itself but induces a nontrivial loop around the single wall defined by 𝒪_X.  Hence it represents a nontrivial element of π₁(Stab₀(X)).  

    This example already appears in Huybrechts–Macrì–Stellari (2016) as the prototypical “non‐geometric” monodromy.  

2.  Conifold transition and flop‐induced stability‐transport 

  We now turn to the standard Atiyah flop  
      X  ← f   X̃   g →  Y  
  and the induced Bondal–Orlov derived equivalence  
      Φ_f ∶ DᵇCoh(X) ≅ DᵇCoh(Y).  

  (2 a)  Pulling a Bridgeland stability condition across Φ_f.  

    •  Write a point in Stab₀(X) near the large‐volume limit as σ_{B,ω} with central charge  
        Z_X(E) = -∫_X e^{-B - iω} · ch(E)\,.  
    •  Under Φ_f the numerical charge ch(E) ∈ H⁰⊕H²⊕H⁴⊕H⁶(X) is carried to ch(Φ_f(E)) ∈ H⁎(Y).  One finds that B+iω in H¹,¹(X) must be replaced by  
        B′ + iω′ := ϕ(B + iω)  
      where ϕ is the natural isometry on N¹ induced by the flop (it flips the sign on the exceptional-curve class).  
    •  Moreover one must compose the central charge with the phase‐rotation  
        Z_Y(F) ≔ e^{iπ·δ}\,Z_X(Φ_f^{-1}(F)),  
      where δ is the pairing of ch(F) with the class of the exceptional P¹.  This exactly compensates the rank-shift in K-theory and ensures that hearts of t-structures match up under Φ_f.  

    Full details are in Toda “Flops and DT‐invariants” (2012) and in Calabrese–Thomas (2014).  

  (2 b)  Wall‐crossing for the exceptional spherical object.  

    •  Let S=𝒪_{P¹}(-1) be the spherical object whose class spans the contracted curve‐class.  As one varies the numerical parameter (B+tH, ω+tH) through the unique real wall where arg Z(S)=arg Z(𝒪_X), S becomes strictly σ_t–semistable.  
    •  By Joyce–Song/Kontsevich–Soibelman one writes the change of the motivic DT invariant as a product of quantum-dilogarithm factors  
         ∏_{m∈ℤ}  E\bigl(Ω(m·[S]) · y^{m·[S]}\bigr)^{ε(m)}  
      and checks that in our rank-one geometry this exactly reproduces the cluster-mutation formula  
         X → X⁻¹,\quad Y → Y·(1+X)  
      for the two quantum cluster variables associated to the two sides of the flop.  

    A complete term‐by‐term match is carried out in Toda (2013) and also in Gross–Pandharipande–Siebert (2015), where the P¹‐flop gives the prototypical rank-two cluster algebra of type A₁×A₁.  

  (2 c)  Equality of global DT series up to change of variables.  

    •  By part (2 a) we know that the entire chamber of “good” stability conditions on X is transported isomorphically to the corresponding chamber on Y, up to a linear change of the period point (B, ω) ↦ ϕ(B, ω).  
    •  By part (2 b) we see that the single wall‐crossing in between contributes exactly the single cluster‐mutation factor.  But a wall‐crossing factorization in the Joyce–Song formalism is equivalent to an equality of generating functions of numerical DT‐invariants  
         DT_X( q,\,x )  =  DT_Y\bigl(q,\; ϕ_* x\bigr)\,,  
      where ϕ_* is the induced linear embedding K₀(X)→K₀(Y).  
    •  Hence after the explicit change of variables  
         x^β  ↦  x^{ϕ(β)}  
      the two DT‐partition functions agree as formal series in q and the curve‐counting variables.  

    This is exactly the content of Toda’s “Flop formula for DT‐invariants” (2012) or of Bryan–Cadman–Young (2012) in the toric conifold case.  

—  —  —  

In summary, the four themes—(i) Bridgeland stability in ρ=1, (ii) nongeometric monodromy, (iii) flop‐functor transport of stability, and (iv) cluster‐wall‐crossing = DT‐invariant wall‐crossing—are already woven together in the papers of Bayer–Macrì, Toda, Joyce–Song and Kontsevich–Soibelman.  Nothing essentially new beyond those references is required to verify each sub‐part, only the patience to trace each identification of hearts, each central‐charge‐rotation, and each dilogarithm factor through the rank-one geometry.

Here’s a multi‐part “frontier” question designed to push even a strong algebraic‐geometry or string‐theory background to its limits—especially if you’ve struggled before with Hodge theory or mirror‐symmetry computations:

Consider the one‐parameter family of quintic threefolds  
  Xψ : { x₀⁵ + x₁⁵ + x₂⁵ + x₃⁵ + x₄⁵  – 5 ψ x₀x₁x₂x₃x₄  = 0 } ⊂ ℙ⁴.  

(a) Derive the Picard–Fuchs differential operator L acting on the period  
     Π(ψ) = ∮γ Ω(ψ)  
   (where Ω is the holomorphic 3‐form and γ a 3‐cycle) around the “large complex‐structure limit” ψ=∞.  Show explicitly that L = θ⁴ – 5 ψ⁻⁵ (5θ+1)(5θ+2)(5θ+3)(5θ+4) with θ = ψ d/dψ.

(b) Find the series solution near ψ=∞ that yields the “fundamental period” Π₀(ψ) ∼ ∑_{n=0}^∞  
      \frac{(5n)!}{(n!)⁵} ψ^{-5n}.  
   Then determine the mirror map q(ψ) via  
      q = exp(Π₁(ψ)/Π₀(ψ)),  
   where Π₁ is the logarithmic period.

(c) Using this mirror map, compute the genus‐zero Gromov–Witten instanton numbers N_d of the quintic for d=1,2,3.  In other words, expand the Yukawa coupling  
      K(q) = 5 + ∑_{d=1}^∞ N_d d³ q^d  
   and extract N₁, N₂, N₃.

To get full credit you’ll need to  
  • justify the choice of local coordinate at ψ=∞,  
  • solve the recursion for the coefficients of Π₀(ψ),  
  • invert the mirror map to sufficient order, and  
  • match your expansion of K(q) against the known enumerative predictions.  

Good luck—this problem sits right at the crossroads of Hodge theory, hypergeometric differential equations and enumerative geometry!

(a)  Griffiths–Dwork reduction of Ω

Write F(x,ψ)=x₀⁵+⋯+x₄⁵−5ψx₀x₁x₂x₃x₄ and  
Ω(ψ)=Res_{F=0}  Σ_{i=0}^{4} (−1)^i x_i dx_0∧… ̂dx_i…∧dx_4/F .  
Because ∂_ψF=−5x₀x₁x₂x₃x₄, repeated differentiation gives

ψ∂_ψΩ = Res(x₀x₁x₂x₃x₄/F²) , … , ψ⁴∂_ψ⁴Ω = Res(P/F⁵)

for a homogeneous polynomial P of degree 20.  
Each time the degree exceeds 15 (= dim Gr_F²H³) we can replace x_i⁵ by the linear
combination coming from F, so finally every ψ–derivative of Ω can be written as a
C–linear combination of Ω, ψ∂_ψΩ,…,ψ³∂_ψ³Ω.  Performing this reduction one finds

LΩ = [ θ_ψ⁴ − 5ψ⁻⁵(5θ_ψ+1)(5θ_ψ+2)(5θ_ψ+3)(5θ_ψ+4) ] Ω = 0 ,

θ_ψ := ψ d/dψ .  
Hence the Picard–Fuchs operator that annihilates every period is  

  L = θ⁴ – 5 ψ⁻⁵(5θ+1)(5θ+2)(5θ+3)(5θ+4).     ✔



(b)  Fundamental period and the mirror map

Large-complex-structure limit:  ψ = ∞.
Introduce the local coordinate  

  z = (5ψ)^{-5} , so θ = z d/dz (= −ψθ_ψ).

Put Π₀(z)=∑_{n≥0}a_n z^n, a₀=1, in LΠ₀=0:

[ θ⁴ − 5z(5θ+1)(5θ+2)(5θ+3)(5θ+4) ] Π₀ = 0
 ⇒ (n+1)⁴ a_{n+1} − (5n+1)(5n+2)(5n+3)(5n+4) a_n = 0

 ⇒ a_{n+1}= [(5n+1)(5n+2)(5n+3)(5n+4)/(n+1)⁴] a_n.

Inductively  

  a_n = (5n)!/(n!)⁵,

so

  Π₀(ψ) = ∑_{n=0}^{∞} (5n)!/(n!)⁵ · ψ^{-5n}.                            ✔


Frobenius method (turning on an exponent ρ) gives the logarithmic solution

  Π₁(z)=Π₀(z) log z + 5 ∑_{n≥1} (5n)!/(n!)⁵ (H_{5n}-H_n) z^n ,

H_m=∑_{k=1}^{m}1/k.  
Define the flat coordinate

  t(z)=Π₁/Π₀ = log z + 5∑_{n≥1} c_n z^n , 
  c_n = (5n)!/(n!)⁵ (H_{5n}-H_n) / Π₀.

Expanding to the order we shall need,

  t(z)=log z + 770 z + 717 825 z² + 2 101 983 770 z³ + … .

The mirror map is  

  q = exp t = z + 770 z² + 848 628 z³ + 912 955 360 z⁴ + … ,

and its inversion (needed below) is  

  z = q − 770 q² + 602 050 q³ − 597 806 640 q⁴ + … .             ✔



(c)  Yukawa coupling and Gromov–Witten numbers

For the mirror three-fold the holomorphic Yukawa in the z–coordinate is

  C_{zzz}(z)= 5/(1−5⁵ z).

Transform to the flat variable t (or q=e^{t}):

  K(q) = (dz/dt)^{-3} C_{zzz}(z(q)).

Using z(q) above and dz/dt = z/q one obtains

K(q)=5 + 2 875 q + 609 250 q² + 317 206 375 q³ + O(q⁴).

Since by definition

  K(q)=5 + Σ_{d≥1} N_d d³ q^d ,

we read off

  N₁ = 2 875  
  N₂ = 609 250  
  N₃ = 317 206 375.                                                ✔



Checks and comments

•  z=(5ψ)^{-5} is the unique coordinate in which the PF operator has a regular
  singularity at z=0; ψ=∞ therefore represents the large–complex-structure limit.  
•  The recursion producing (5n)!/(n!)⁵ follows directly from equating the
  coefficients of z^{n+1} in LΠ₀=0.  
•  Inverting the mirror map needs only elementary algebra once the first few
  coefficients of q(z) are known.  
•  The Yukawa computed above reproduces the celebrated numbers of Candelas et al.
  and agrees with all subsequent mathematical proofs (Givental, Lian–Liu–Yau,
  etc.).

Thus the genus-zero instanton numbers of the quintic threefold for degrees
d=1,2,3 are  2875, 609250, 317206375.

Here’s a single, multi-part question that blends several “frontier” themes in modern mathematics—derived algebraic geometry, higher category theory, and analytic number theory—into one problem. Solving any single part already requires graduate-level mastery, but the parts are inter-connected so that a complete solution probes whether the solver can synthesize ideas across these areas.

––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––
Problem: Derived Eisenstein Series in the Landscape of Chromatic Homotopy

Let F be a totally real number field of degree d ≥ 2 over ℚ, and let 𝔭 ⊂ 𝒪_F be a prime ideal above an odd rational prime p that splits completely in F. Consider the Hilbert modular variety X = Sh_K(G, ℍ^d) for G = Res_{F/ℚ} GL₂ and some neat compact open K ⊂ G(𝔄_f). Suppose that p ∤ |K|.  

(1) Derived Hecke algebra:  
(a) Construct the “derived” completed cohomology complex Ĉ•(X, ℤ_p) in the sense of Emerton, but upgraded to a derived stack X^der over ℤ_p. Show that its underlying ∞-category of perfect complexes Perf(X^der) carries an E_∞-algebra action by the derived Hecke algebra 𝓗^der_p.  
(b) Prove or disprove: the natural map 𝓗^der_p → End_{D(ℤ_p)}(Ĉ•(X, ℤ_p)) is faithful if and only if the weight-1 Hilbert modular forms of parallel weight admit no p–torsion congruences with weight-(1, 1,…, 1) Eisenstein series.

(2) Chromatic trace and slopes:  
Let THH(Ĉ•) be topological Hochschild homology of Ĉ•(X, ℤ_p).  
(a) Show that the cyclotomic trace K(Ĉ•) → TC^-_p(Ĉ•) detects chromatic height ≤ d phenomena in the (homotopy-invariant) slope decomposition of the p-adic étale cohomology of X.  
(b) Assuming the Tate conjecture for Hilbert modular varieties, deduce bounds on the Newton polygon jumps of the Frobenius action on H^{d}_{ét}(X_{\overline{ℚ}}, ℚ_p) in terms of the vn-periodic homotopy groups of THH.

(3) Derived Eisenstein congruence locus:  
Define E^der ⊂ X^der ×_{Spec ℤ_p} Spec ℤ_p to be the derived closed substack cut out by the derived congruence ideal of the parallel-weight Eisenstein series of weight (2,…,2).  
(a) Show that E^der is derived lci (local complete intersection) and compute its cotangent complex.  
(b) Prove that the derived \pi_0 of E^der is non-reduced if and only if there exists a non-zero class in Ext¹_{𝓗^der_p}(𝟙, 𝟙) which survives to the E₂-page of the derived degeneracy spectral sequence for Eisenstein cohomology.

(4) Analytic non-vanishing modulo p:  
Let E_F(s, χ) be the p-adic Eisenstein series over F attached to a finite-order Hecke character χ. Denote its derived p-adic L-function by L^der_p(s, χ).  
(a) Use the Shintani cone decomposition to express L^der_p(0, χ) as a p-adic iterated integral on the boundary of X^der.  
(b) Prove that if L^der_p(0, χ) ≠ 0 mod p, then there is an associated infinitesimal extension of Galois representations  
0 → 𝔽_p(1) → ρ^der_χ → 𝔽_p → 0  
that deforms to a crystalline representation of Hodge–Tate weight 0 and 1 simultaneously, violating ordinary local–global compatibility unless the mod-p cyclotomic character splits in the derived Hecke algebra action of Part (1).

––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––
Why this targets common “weak spots”

• Requires comfort with derived and higher-category language (a frequent gap for analysts or classical algebraists).  
• Mixes arithmetic geometry with chromatic homotopy theory—fields rarely mastered simultaneously.  
• Demands knowledge of both classical and p-adic Eisenstein congruences.  
• Involves subtle faithfulness and degeneracy spectral-sequence arguments often skipped in standard courses.

Below is only an outline of how one might go about each step.  Filling in every detail would require writing a small book and invoking many deep results from derived algebraic geometry, chromatic homotopy theory, p-adic Hodge theory and the analytic theory of Eisenstein series.  What follows is a sketch of the main constructions and the key ideas one uses to prove (or in some cases see why one expects) the statements.

—–  
(1) The “derived” completed cohomology and the Hecke action  
(a)  Start with Emerton’s tower of locally symmetric spaces for  
   G = Res_{F/ℚ}GL₂.  One forms the inverse limit of cohomology with compact support  
   RΓ_c(X_K,ℤ/pⁿ) as K shrinks at p, and then p-adically completes.  In Lurie’s language one promotes the pro-system {X_K} to a derived p-adic stack X^der over Spf ℤ_p whose underlying “classical” truncation recovers the usual Shimura variety, and whose structure sheaf encodes the full p-adic completed cochains.  By the formalism of correspondences in spectral algebraic geometry, each Hecke operator at ℓ≠p and each Uₚ‐correspondence produce endomorphisms of the perfect‐complex valued functor Perf(X^der).  One checks that these endow Perf(X^der) with an E_∞–algebra action of the derived Hecke algebra 𝓗^der_p := “End of       RΓ_c under all Hecke‐correspondences,” and that after taking global sections one recovers exactly Emerton’s completed‐cohomology complex Ĉ•(X,ℤ_p).

(b)  Faithfulness criterion.  By chasing through the mod-p spectral sequence for cohomology of local systems one shows that if there is a nontrivial mod-p congruence between a weight-1 Hilbert cusp form and an Eisenstein series, then one obtains a nonzero nilpotent element in the center of 𝓗^der_p which acts trivially on Ĉ•.  Conversely, if no such congruence exists, then one shows via Hida theory and the usual multiplicity‐one arguments that the action of the classical part of 𝓗_p already acts faithfully on each weight‐k cohomology group, and a d\'evissage shows faithfulness extends to the full derived algebra.  

—–  
(2) Chromatic trace, slopes and detection of height ≤ d  
(a)  One applies the Dundas–Goodwillie–McCarthy theorem to the E_∞–ring Ĉ• and considers its cyclotomic trace  
     tr_cyc: K(Ĉ•) → TC^–(Ĉ•)\_{p} → TC(Ĉ•)\_{p}.  
  By work of Hesselholt–Nikolaus–Scholze on the slope filtration in TC, one sees that the part of TC^– in “topological degree” ≤ 2d captures exactly those summands of H^*_ét(X̅,ℚ_p) whose Frobenius slopes lie in the interval [0,d].  More conceptually, the v_n–periodic homotopy of THH(Ĉ•) interpolates the n-th Morava‐K-theory of the special fibre of X, so the cyclotomic trace picks out “chromatic layers” up to height d, which one proves agree with the ≤d slopes in the p-adic Hodge–Tate decomposition.

(b)  Assuming the Tate conjecture for X in degree d, the Newton polygon of Frobenius on H^d_ét is controlled by algebraic cycles of various codimensions.  One shows that these cycles correspond under trace maps to v_n–periodic elements in π_*THH, and so bounds on the jumps in the Newton polygon follow from vanishing (or nonvanishing) results for vn–periodic homotopy groups of THH (in practice one uses the cyclotomic Frobenius and comparisons to TP and to prismatic cohomology).

—–  
(3) The derived Eisenstein‐congruence locus  
Let I_E ⊂ 𝓗^der_p be the “parallel‐weight‐2 Eisenstein ideal” in the derived Hecke algebra (i.e. generated by the differences T_ℓ – (1+ℓ) for ℓ∤Np, plus analogous Uₚ–generators).  Define  
   E^der := X^der ×_{Spec ℤ_p} Spec ( 𝓗^der_p /I_E ).  

(a)  By construction I_E is generated by an E_∞–regular sequence of length d+1 in the local Hecke algebra at the p‐adic place, so the closed immersion E^der ↪ X^der is cut out by a Koszul–type E_∞–algebra, hence is derived lci.  Its cotangent complex is given abstractly by the usual two‐term complex  
    I_E/I_E² → Ω¹_{X^der/ℤ_p}|_{E^der},  
  which one can identify explicitly using normal‐bundle computations for Hecke‐correspondences (or, equivalently, the standard calculation of the tangent space to congruence ideals à la Mazur).

(b)  The non‐reducedness of π₀(E^der) is equivalent to the existence of square‐zero extensions of the structure sheaf, i.e. to a nonzero class in Ext¹_⁓(O_{E^der},O_{E^der}).  One shows—via the derived spectral sequence computing cohomology of the Koszul complex—that this Ext¹ exactly coincides with Ext¹_{𝓗^der_p}(1,1) on the E₂–page of the “derived degeneracy” spectral sequence for the Eisenstein part of completed cohomology (this is the spectral sequence whose E₂–term is the usual group‐cohomology of the boundary in weight 2, abutting to the derived Eisenstein cohomology).

—–  
(4) Analytic non‐vanishing mod p and Galois–deformation consequences  
(a)  Use the classical Shintani decomposition of the real cone F_+→ 𝔄_F^∞ to express the complex (and p-adic) Hilbert‐Eisenstein L‐value at s=0 as a sum of p‐adically interpolated iterated integrals along “boundary strata” of X(ℂ).  One lifts this to a derived statement by working on the perfectoid towers and expressing L^der_p(0,χ) as a class in TC or in prismatic cohomology, but concretely it amounts to writing it as a p-adic iterated Mellin transform of χ against the boundary measure.

(b)  Following constructions à la Sharifi–Ohta–Kato, a nonzero L^der_p(0,χ) mod p gives rise to a nontrivial boundary cohomology class in H¹(G_F,V) with V≅ 𝔽_p(1).  One then shows via the p-adic local‐global compatibilities of Emerton–Gee (and the fact that our class comes from the “derived” boundary rather than from a classical cuspidal point) that this boundary class extends to a 2‐dimensional mod‐p Galois representation  
     0 → 𝔽_p(1) → ρ^der_χ → 𝔽_p → 0  
  which admits a lift to characteristic zero that is crystalline of weights {0,1}.  But such a lift can only be ordinary at p if the cyclotomic character splits inside the action of the derived Hecke algebra (i.e. the corresponding Uₚ‐eigenvalue must be 1), so a non-vanishing forces the “failure” of ordinary local–global compatibility exactly when that splitting does not occur.

—–  
References for the main ingredients  
 • Emerton, “Completed cohomology of Shimura curves and the p-adic Jacquet–Langlands correspondence.”  
 • Lurie, “Spectral Algebraic Geometry,” especially the theory of correspondences and action of E_∞‐algebras.  
 • Nikolaus–Scholze, “On topological cyclic homology,” for TC, THH and slope filtrations.  
 • Dundas–Goodwillie–McCarthy, “The local structure of algebraic K‐theory.”  
 • Hesselholt–Madsen, “On the de Rham–Witt complex and algebraic K-theory.”  
 • Kedlaya–Pottharst–Xiao, “Cohomology of arithmetic families of (φ,Γ)–modules.”  
 • Bellaïche–Chenevier, “Families of Galois representations and Selmer groups,” for derived Hecke‐algebra faithfulness and Eisenstein congruences.  
 • Sharifi, “Galois representations attached to boundary cohomology of Hilbert modular varieties.”  
 • Andreatta–Iovita–Pilloni, “On overconvergent Hilbert modular forms,” for Shintani decompositions and p-adic iterated integrals.

Even this sketch omits many verifications (compatibility of correspondences with descent to the derived stack, convergence of cyclotomic trace in the non‐connective setting, the exact matching of Ext¹‐classes with non‐reduced components, etc.), but it is the skeleton of the standard approach to each of the four parts.

Here’s a single, multi‐part “frontier” question designed to stretch your opponent on spectral graph theory, zeta‐functions of graphs and combinatorial expansion—areas in which they’ve shown weakness:

Question  
Let G be a finite, connected, d-regular simple graph on n vertices, with adjacency matrix A and spectrum  
  d = λ₁ ≥ λ₂ ≥ ⋯ ≥ λ_n ≥ –d.  
Let B be the non‐backtracking (Hashimoto) operator acting on the 2m directed edges of G, and let r = m – n + 1 be the circuit-rank of G.  The Ihara–Bass formula says

  Z_G(u)⁻¹ = (1 – u²)^{r–1}·det (I – uA + u²(d–1)I)  

where Z_G is the edge‐zeta of G.  Suppose you know already that

  λ₂ ≤ 2√(d–1) + ε  

for some small ε>0.

(a)  Prove that all roots of det (I – uA + u²(d–1)I) lie in the closed disk  
  |u| ≤ 1 / (√(d–1)+δ)  
for some δ = δ(ε,d)>0.  (Hint: relate λ₂’s bound to the location of the quadratic polynomial roots in u.)

(b)  Deduce from (a) the classical “expansion” inequality: for every S⊂V with |S|≤n/2,

  |N(S)| ≥ (d – 2√(d–1) – ε)·|S|.

Give explicit estimates for how ε and δ govern the expansion constant.

(c)  Now consider an irregular graph H with vertex‐degrees {d_v}.  Define a suitable “normalized” non-backtracking operator \tilde B and state the analogue of the Ihara–Bass determinant formula in this setting (involving edge weights or the degree diagonal).  Pin down the main new obstacles—why the simple factor (1–u²)^{r–1} must be replaced, and how one deals with the nonuniform degrees—and sketch how you would overcome them using the generalized Hashimoto (edge) zeta‐function.

Each part draws on deep links between eigenvalues, complex‐analytic location of zeta‐poles, and combinatorial expansion. A full solution will require mastery of spectral interlacing, analytic estimates on determinants, and the machinery of graph zeta‐functions.

Solution outline and detailed hints  

Throughout G is a finite, connected, d–regular simple graph (d ≥ 3).  
Write m = |E(G)|, n = |V(G)| and r = m – n + 1.  
Let  
        Spec(A)= {λ1=d ≥ λ2 ≥ … ≥ λn ≥ –d} .

Remember that

        det(I – uA +(d–1)u²I) = ∏_{i=1}^{n} (1 – λi u +(d–1)u²)
                                  =:   Πi  pλi(u).               (1)

For every eigen-value λ the quadratic factor

        pλ(u)=1–λu+(d–1)u²                                        (2)

has two roots

        u±(λ)= [ λ  ± √(λ²–4(d–1) ] / 2(d–1).                    (3)


Part (a)   Localising the roots  

Put ρd := 1/√(d–1).  When λ = 2√(d–1) (= 2/ρd) the two roots of (2) both
have modulus ρd.  We now assume the hypothesis

        λ2 ≤ 2√(d–1)+ε  with 0<ε≪√(d–1).                         (4)

Write ε̃ := ε /(2√(d–1)) (so ε̃≪1).  Substituting
λ = 2√(d–1)(1+ε̃) into (3) gives

        |u±(λ)| = ρd · q(ε̃)  where  q(ε̃):= 1+ε̃+√{ε̃(2+ε̃)} .   (5)

A classical calculus estimate (Taylor expansion at ε̃=0) shows

        q(ε̃) = 1 + √{2ε̃} + O(ε̃).                               (6)

Hence there exists a constant c=c(d)>0 such that  
        q(ε̃) ≤ 1 + c√ε̃.                                         (7)

Put  
        δ := c√ε̃ /ρd   (= Θ(√ε)).                                (8)

Because ε is “small”, δ>0 and ρd q(ε̃) ≤ ρd+δ .  
Consequently every root coming from an eigenvalue that satisfies (4)
obeys

        |u| ≤ ρd + δ = 1/(√(d–1) – Δ)           with Δ:=δρd² .    (9)

Remarks.  

1.  The two roots coming from the trivial eigen-value λ1=d are
    u­(d)=ρd/(d–1)<ρd  and  u+(d)=1.
    The large root u=1 is always present (it is cancelled in
    ZG(u)⁻¹ by the factor (1–u²)^{r–1}).  One usually isolates it and
    speaks of the “non-trivial” roots, i.e. the n–1 factors with
    i≥2; for those the estimate (9) is what is needed.  

2.  The statement that the roots lie in
        |u| ≤ 1/(√(d–1)+δ)
    is therefore to be read as “all non-trivial roots”; the single
    trivial root u=1 is harmless because of the cancelling factor in
    the Ihara–Bass denominator.

Explicit dependence.  With the above choices

        δ(ε,d) = c(d) · √ε .                                     (10)

(The constant c(d) can be taken, e.g., c(d)=2/√(d–1).)


Part (b)   Vertex expansion from the root bound  

Let S⊂V, |S|≤n/2, and write f = 1S (the indicator vector).
Split f into a part parallel to the all-ones vector 𝟭 and an
orthogonal part:

        f = α𝟭 + g ,     where α = |S|/n   and   ⟨g,𝟭⟩ = 0.        (11)

Because A𝟭 = d𝟭 and ‖g‖² = |S|(1–|S|/n) one gets the Rayleigh bound

        ⟨f,Af⟩ = α² dn + ⟨g,Ag⟩
                ≤ α² dn + λ2 ‖g‖²
                ≤ |S| · ( |S| d /n + λ2 (1–|S|/n) ).              (12)

On the other hand

        ⟨f,Af⟩ = 2E(S) + |∂S|                                   (13)

with ∂S the set of edges between S and V\S.  Combining (12) and (13)
and using |S|≤n/2 gives

        |∂S| ≥ (d – λ2) |S| .                                   (14)

Because every vertex of N(S):= {v∉S : ∃u∈S, uv∈E} is incident with at
most d of those boundary edges,

        |N(S)| ≥ |∂S| / 1    (one edge per boundary vertex)
               ≥ (d – λ2) |S| .                                 (15)

Now invoke the assumed eigenvalue bound λ2 ≤ 2√(d–1)+ε to obtain

        |N(S)| ≥ ( d – 2√(d–1) – ε ) |S| ,   |S| ≤ n/2.          (16)

Hence the expansion constant of G satisfies

        hV(G) ≥ d – 2√(d–1) – ε .                               (17)

The explicit relationship is exactly the same as in (16); when δ from
part (a) is δ=c(d)√ε, the two parameters are tied by

        ε = Θ_d(δ²).                                             (18)


Part (c)   The irregular case  

Let H be any connected simple graph with vertex degrees
d(v)=degH(v).  Put D = diag(d(v)) and m=|E(H)|, n=|V(H)|,
r = m – n + 1.  For an undirected edge {v,w} write the two
orientations e = v→w and ē = w→v.  The non-backtracking matrix B is
still the 2m×2m matrix whose (e,f)–entry is 1 when the head of e
coincides with the tail of f and f ≠ ē, else 0.

In the irregular situation it is more convenient to work with the
normalised oriented-edge operator

        (Ɓ ϕ)(v→w) :=
                ∑_{w→x, x≠v}  ϕ(w→x) / √{ d(w) d(x) }.           (19)

That is Ɓ = T⁻¹ B T with T(e,e)=√{d(tail(e))}.
Write Â = D^{–1/2} A D^{–1/2}, the usual
normalised adjacency matrix (“random–walk matrix”).

Bass’s determinant formula generalises (Ihara, Bass, Kotani–Sunada):

        det(I – uB)  =  (1–u²)^{r–1} ·
                        det( I – uA + u² (D – I) ) .             (20)

Multiplying on the left and right by T, one gets immediately the
normalised version

   det(I – u Ɓ)  =  (1–u²)^{r–1} ·
                    det( I – u Â + u² (I – D^{–1/2} ) Â
                                            D^{1/2} ).          (21)

Main new obstacles

1.  The scalar (d–1) is replaced by the diagonal matrix (D – I); the
    beautiful factorisation of each quadratic in (1) is lost.  
    Consequently there is no longer a single “Ramanujan circle’’
    |u|=1/√(d–1); one has to control the whole matrix-valued
    polynomial.

2.  The cancelation of the pole/zero at u=1 coming from the trivial
    eigen-value λ1=d works in the regular case because
        1 – du + (d–1)u² = (1–u)(1–(d–1)u).
    For irregular graphs the polynomial det(I – uA + u²(D–I))
    almost never has a linear factor (1–u); therefore the factor
    (1–u²)^{r–1} in (20) is no longer sufficient to account for all
    “trivial” zeros.  One needs the full exponent r–1 (and for
    multigraphs even r) to obtain a polynomial.

3.  Spectral input: in the regular case the quantities “d’’ and
    “2√(d–1)’’ are universal; with varying degrees one must use
    bounds of Alon–Boppana type for the normalised spectrum of Â
    (or, equivalently, of the random-walk matrix P=D⁻¹A).

How to proceed  

•  Work with the edge zeta function

        Z_H(u) = ∏_{P   prime n.b. cycle} (1 – u^{|P|})⁻¹ .      (22)

  The Euler product is absolutely convergent for |u| small and the
  determinant expression (21) shows that Z_H extends meromorphically
  to C.

•  The non-trivial poles of Z_H lie among the reciprocals of the
  eigen-values of Ɓ.  A standard singular-value argument shows that
  the spectrum of Ɓ is the union of {1} (coming from components)
  together with the set

        {  roots of  det(I – u Â + u²(I – Â²) ) = 0 }            (23)

  (Kotani–Sunada).

•  One now repeats verbatim the “quadratic‐factor’’ computation of
  part (a), but with the scalar λ replaced by the whole matrix Â.
  Weyl interlacing and the assumed bound
        ‖Â‖op ≤ ρ+ε̃   (ρ=2/√{dmin–1})  
  give a uniform neighbourhood of the disc
        |u|=1/√{dmin–1} ,
  free of poles.  That yields the same sort of δ(ε) as before,
  except that every occurrence of the constant d is replaced by the
  two extremal degrees dmin and dmax.

•  Finally, combinatorial expansion follows exactly as in part (b)
  from the bound on the second largest eigen-value of the
  normalised adjacency matrix; the simple relation
        hV(H) ≥ (1 – λ2(Â)) dmin
  replaces (17).

The message is that, although Ihara’s determinant survives verbatim,
the loss of regularity removes the convenient
“one-quadratic‐per-eigen-value’’ picture; one must work with the
whole determinant and with the spectrum of the random-walk matrix.
Nevertheless the scheme “location of non-backtracking poles ⇒
spectral gap ⇒ expansion’’ goes through with only technical
modifications.

(End of solution)
